I didn't have high hopes for this, and I must say I'm impressed.

Black Mesa is an outstanding remake of the original Half-Life. It stays true to the original‚Äôs spirit and gameplay, while rounding out the rough edges of the original game.

[b]The Good:[/b]
+Like the original, it‚Äôs a fun, linear first-person-shooter full of scripted events that make the world feel alive. The best parts of the original game are still here.
+Greatly improved graphics, textures, models, sound, music, and physics.
+The Xen chapters are beautiful and the gameplay in Xen has been improved a lot over the original game.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
-Just like the original, there‚Äôs not much story and Gordon is a silent protagonist. Dialogue with other characters is few and far between.
-There‚Äôs so many locked doors and blocked exits, with typically a single path through the entire game.
-New to Black Mesa are the achievements, which are a mixed bag. A lot of them aren‚Äôt close to anything you would call an achievement.

[b]The Ugly:[/b]
---There‚Äôs a game breaking bug involving a puzzle in Xen that still exists years after the game‚Äôs release. I didn‚Äôt realize I had triggered the bug until I spent more than twenty minutes trying to solve the puzzle to no avail. I gave up and went online to find the puzzle‚Äôs solution, only to discover the puzzle was bugged and I had to start it all over again. Good thing it autosaves before the puzzle!

This game really does have a strong answer for the age old question: Are modern games no longer fun or am I just getting older? Obviously, there are some fantastic modern games out there and you cannot paint them all with the same brush. However, playing through Black Mesa, having never really experienced the original Half-life in my youth, regrettably! I didn't have any of the nostalgia bias going in. Just a fresh open mind. And I'm so glad I did, as not only has the team who worked on this project for so many years earned every bit of recognition, it's clear that nothing but love and passion went into this. There is a clearly a reason that not only is the game Overwhelmingly Positive on steam but that the Half-life series is considered some of the best in gaming history. Do yourself a favour and pick up the crowbar.

Too many opportunities for soft locks. I appreciate the remaster of this classic game but cannot recommend except for the most die hard fan or new player. It lacks that Valve polish and clearly missed on playtesting/QA. No fault of the devs, them being fantastic modders and very skilled artists, but the kinks show. Again, I do not fault the devs. I praise them immensely for accomplishing this difficult feat. They definitely did better at creating Half-Life: Source than Valve. I am glad this exists! Still... Play the original first and if you like the original, or are a diehard fan of Half-Life, ONLY THEN try this one. 

tl;dr If there was a neutral option, I'd give it that. Else, it's a 5/10.

To be most specific, it irks me that it plays more like an arena shooter similar to Quake or Doom than the original which was unique in its own gameplay. I mean, from it spawned HL2, TF2, CS, Portal, and more. All of which are mods that find their root in the gameplay of Half-Life. It's hard to explain unless you play it and experience it. It's not quite Halo, definitely not Doom, and not CoD. It's.... well... Half-Life. It's its own genre with its own shooter mechanics. It's a sandbox puzzle platformer shooter with hitscan. Sounds weird when you try to break it down, right? The original is forever perfect. Play the original. Then play this. But, I suggest that you do not play or buy this without having tried the original. 

Lest you experience soft locks (like being trapped in an elevator shaft with no way to exit it) and bugs (like the hitscan boxes being off). 

At the very least download the mods that patch the issues!!!

This is only MY individual opinion!


p.s. I am not a Half-Life fan. I did not grow up with the games. My first HL game was HL2, or particularly TF2 and CS. Heck I only liked HL2 for the story. I am a Halo fan. I say this an an attempt to argue my lack of bias, objective observation, and respect for the Half-Life franchise and its gameplay. Make of this what you will.

A few bugs were encountered by me during my playthrough, but they aren't too gamebreaking. However if you are going for the Hat or Pizza achievements, you most certainly might feel genuine rage during your playthrough, the game wasn't propely tested for these purposes and throughout the game, carrying the props with you just wasn't given enough thought by the developers, therefore props will get stuck in invisible barriers, get lost in unclipped map brushes, and sometimes refuse to stay in your hands during some game sequences.

Considering this is basically an indie take/remake of the first Half Life it's incredibly impressive, however it does by no means replace the original. There's a lot of little things here I personally dislike, the enemy AI, especially the soldiers seems neutered, the weapons also feel a lot worse compared to the original game somehow. The new additions to the weapon roster are actually very nice in contrast. Most of the music here is just pulled straight from the original but re-recorded/re-arranged to mixed effect. Some of it sounds better, some of it sounds worse. 

The changes to the Xen level in particular I'm very conflicted with. There's good ideas there as well as some very tightly designed, engaging sections, but it meanders too much. There was no need to make Xen nearly as long as the "rest of the game" so to speak in my opinion. The puzzles added in these sections would be acceptable if they weren't repeated nearly ad-nauseum 3-4 times in any given level. The final boss is a straight upgrade from the original and deserves praise.

This game is awful.
10 years of development, we waited at a standstill almost a decade ago when it was announced.
The source engine this game is run on is beyond dated. When Half Life was first released, at the date it was put out, it had set a standard for gaming that words can not describe. 
I've followed the Black Mesa team for nearly a decade. 
Where Half life had set a standard and made a name for itself within the gaming industry, with groundbreaking work and an engine to support it, 
Black mesa feels; lackluster. 
I played the preview back in the day upon it's original release. 10 years of development bottle necked by the original source engine. The game does not at all hold up to the newer standards. 
Yes, it's an independent mod, yes it's a low profile studio, but for the decade of development this game has been in, this feels beyong underwhelming from the original mod I played for free. 
If games like metro can release a free version of their updated game to their users; why can't black mesa do as well?
In regards to the source engine, i've seen children as young as 16 release garry mod gameplay that was more involved and better presented. I'm disheartened. It is half life, it is half life with better textures, but a decade of consistent development and this is what we get? Nothing blew me away. And in that regard, with an understanding of gaming development; I'd recommend the original over a medipocre game released with competitive titles in the era matched with it's release date. This game is a retexture, while certain components are critically changed mechanically for the playthrough, nothing about this screams modern, nor updated. This sucks, this is disheartening. If you're looking to experience the series as a gamer who has seen the way gaming has changed between the 1990's to late 2020's, this game is disappointing.

A nice remake and reimagining of a classic.

The combat is like HL2 on crack, with the variety of HL1, enemies are faster and more aggressive, this compliments the Sprint taken from HL2 and makes the fights more fast paced and react based, BUT with less planning and THINKing! Some enemies like Vortigaunts, Alien Grunts and Controllers can dash and dodge to make you miss shots, the Alien Grunts can charge you, the Controllers can actually control aliens and objects, WHY DID THEY CHANGE THE HOUNDEYE SOUNDS!? The Human Grunts use tactics that will really hurt you if you are slow or don't pay attention, flanking you, throwing grenades if you hide for too long, rushing you if you come close or are near death; sometimes with sound cues and warnings so it doesn't come too unexpectedly, maybe they are TOO coordinated, more than the Combine hive mind it seems. These mechanics makes for some intense fights and encounters. But still, the AI will sometimes get stuck for a second or alternatively it will kill you really easily because they can ATTACK WHILE MOVING now (something that in the original would be an integral part of the combat balance and tactics, if they attack, they can't move, and viceversa).
Strangely the barnacles don't die with one hit from the crowbar like in HL1 and HL2. Although is very easy and fun to throw a grenade into their sticky tongues thanks to the grenade coming from the middle of the screen, better than HL2 where it comes out at an angle making you miss sometimes.
Ammo capacity has been lowered, the first game gave you a lot to work with but here you can find more ammo if you take a moment to look for it. Still the Revolver, Crossbow and SMG Grenades are very limiting which is bad in my opinion.
Another annoying thing is that the Shotgun sometimes doesn't shoot instantly while reloading like the original game, or after a quick reset like HL2, this happens because of a realistic mechanic I think (Explanation in Comment), but it's annoying because the faster speed of the game doesn't match the slow reload, the same could apply to the Crossbow.
A few parts have been shortened or skipped, I think because the original's pace was a bit slow in some parts and to some people it was badly desingned, but it feels dissapointing that some sections you remember from the original game that you are expecting to come up are missing or never show up. C'mon is a remake don't take things out, improve them and add them!
Sometimes it's a bit hard to maneuver, you jump lower here like HL2, a few times I got stuck on some props or maybe there are some bumps on the walls that messed up some jumps or escapes.
Some puzzles are easier (even though they weren't hard in the original) and there are a bit too many plug puzzles (ESPECIALLY IN XEN), like the block the laser safety puzzle in Questionable Ethics is a plug puzzle now (you just need to unplug it lol), or the box pushing to get to a high ladder moment early in Office Complex is skipped (you can just climb it from the ground), although it would have been perfect for the Source Engine![spoiler]
The original Half-Life didn't give you a lot of ammo and enemies for the Tau Cannon and the Gluon Gun so players didn't get the chance to use these weapons that much, here in the longer Xen chapters the scientists teleport supplies to your location and later you will encounter green energy crystals that replenishes your uranium ammo giving you more time to fully explore these weapons, in the last parts of the chapters there are arenas filled with green crystals and enemies, and sometimes there are straight up endurance tests, when, coupled with the music, can make for an intense finale as you fight against the last lines of the alien army, although some sections are too tough and ridiculous.
The last boss Nihilanth is very different, the original game had him just shoot electric orbs and portals, but here, he can do all sorts of attacks, like sweeping lightning across the arena, airstrikes, big charged up shots, launching rocks at you, raising the floor trapping you, shooting walls of fire at a pattern. I think that there should be a mod that makes the fight look like a top-down shooter and it would look great. One thing I don't like is the lack of verticality, in the original fight it felt like you were getting on his level when you jumped up to take a shot at his exposed weak point but here you stay exclusively on the ground, Really!?[/spoiler]

The graphics are fantastic, really impressive what the developers took from old and sometimes bare levels and reimagined them to be fully furnished and detailed locations with realistic lighting. Obviously the Source engine is a bit rough now but they still manage to squeeze it and make the levels breathtaking (at the cost of FPS). Some models are very detailed but some look a bit out of place sometimes, a few models have cheap reflections and lighting or look weird through glass, the Human Grunts and Aliens look very good, the guards and scientists are sometimes off, like when they're standing still, their arms go a little through their bodies, the scientist bodies sometimes seem a bit bulky and the guard's arms skinny, sometimes their face can have weird shadows or their clothes don't react well to specific lightning, the worst is unfortunately Kleiner, sometimes his face looks terrifying with some shadows making him look like he has lumps all over.
The animations could use some work now, specifically the friendly NPC's, sometimes too stiff or jumpy, other times they clip a little though themselves.
The lighting looks pretty realistic, a few times the game was a bit too dark for me, ironically the first half of Power Up is such a good idea that it makes the original's chapter feel like it lacks something in retrospect. The flashlight is a bit too wobbly with the shadows that it casts when you move around and sometimes if you crouch through some rubble or walk near boxes it blocks the light.[spoiler]
Surface Tension is wonderful, longer, full of detail and with beautiful graphics. The setpieces are gonna leave you in awe as the war between you, the Marines and the Xen creatures look intense accordingly, it shows more the power of the Xen forces and it explains better the retreat of the Marines from the base.
The Xen Chapters show off the creativity of the team behind this game, there is new flora and fauna, new gameplay additions, but the length is a bit too much, this feels like you are visiting a new world with different ecosystems and life, but the point of Xen was a quick mission in a small nexus world (although it felt like you were teleporting around randomly), even Gearbox understood this!
You start far in the outdoors natural areas, then to human scientist camps, to alien villages and then to the controlling factories, it's a good progression, but some parts inbetween feel like filler. The scientists teleport supplies to you making them more concerned and useful, rather than them just sending you out and praying that you do it with all the ammo that you find is from dead science members like the original. I would have like to meet scientists in Xen, maybe to explain some things and to make you feel less lonely.[/spoiler]
The gore is a bit exaggerated, it's a little immersion breaking seeing that every time you use the shotgun's double barrel shot on something, it always loses all of its limbs and head leaving a nugget body all the time, or when using a mounted turret all the enemies instantly explode also, I think that should happen only to smaller enemies and when explosions happen, or use a less extreme or more sophisticated version.
Some gory momments from the original now use this system wich can look dissapointing, the worst is probably very early in the game, in Unforseen Consequences there's a guard that in the original gets cut in half by a laser, but here as soon as the laser touches him Bam! Nuggeted.

A very good fan remake of Half Life 1. Every level and interaction got reworked to the point that even the original level designer of half-life series prefer to play this version.

The gameplay is really smooth, and while I don't get some of the design choices of the team (like introducing a weapon after the ideal scenario for those weapons, like the Shotgun and the Offices), the overall experience is solid. I like the introduction of lore elements into gameplay, like the fights against controllers and vortigaunts (which was a minor detail mentioned in Half Life 2), and the inclusion of energy reloading in Xen. However, the AI seems dumber than the original, with enemies standing still doing almost nothing.

Xen got expanded to the point that is almost half of the entire game, and while I like the idea, it overstays its welcome. The first hour of that was Zelda's Magical Forest something something. What were they thinking? The good thing is that Xen is way more varied now than the original.

The music is a hit and miss. Contrary to the original, the music is more of an epic orchestra rather than rock/tech music. This change is very noticeable in Xen, and IMO it doesn't fit really well.

Overall it is a pretty solid game, it exploits almost all of the Source engine capabilities and looks almost as good (and taxing) as modern games.
It's cool but it lost the source engine SOVL.

With some 45 hours on it (most of mine offline; I played on Steam Deck), I can confidently say that Black Mesa is one of the best games I've played, and easily the best FPS. The constant increase in scale of power, environment and enemies left me in awe, wonder, and sometimes even terror. More importantly, as the music escalates with these amazing setpiece battles where the fact that you're alive is miraculous, I began to think, who the fuck is this guy?? Which, it turned out, is exactly what I was supposed to ask. There's no difficulty slider, and this game is hard, so overcoming challenges felt insanely rewarding. This game basically pits you versus the world and the unknown and expects you to survive, and it is glorious. The pacing is largely great, weaving in slow exploration and exhilaratingly fast gunfights, although I think Lambda Core and Interloper could've been cut down some. Even while playing on lowest settings so my Steam Deck didn't explode, Black Mesa stands out as quite pretty. I can't say it performed perfectly, but shaky performance was better than not being able to play it, and the few major FPS drops I had were not in combat zones, so it was usually ok. Playing on controller was never a problem, although it's clear the game is tailored for mouse and keyboard, so if you can play on a PC you definitely should.

After playing for 8 hours, I regretted it and stopped playing because, first of all, when you start, it feels like average campaign gameplay; you do objectives and so on. However, after several chapters, the game feels like repeating itself, and besides the source engine's default entity system coming with the Hammer Editor, I see nothing more than architectural modeling in its maps. [strike]Half-Life[/strike] Black Mesa is as classic as you can get... Wait a minute...

Black Mesa is a fan made remake of Half-Life, and to be honest, it's my prefered way to experience this classic.
Everything that made Half-Life great makes Black Mesa great.

Black Mesa still has the base of Half-Life's methodology "Run, Think, Shoot and Live", but it is enchanced with thoughtfull changes to controls and movement. Weaker chapters have been improved upon with more tuned level design; weapon tweaks make the whole arsenal more appealing and already excelent setpieces and excelent sequences were improved upon - something I thought was nigh impossible.

The pacing of the campain is excelent, from one encounter to another encounter, the flow of everything is on par or sometimes greater than in Half-Life. Still escaping the failing facility through it's different sectors, finding survivors and discovering more and more about the facility; it's still all there and witnessing the fallout of our actions is still captivating.

And Xen chapters itself are impressive - they are no longer bad!
Reworked and completely redesigned into something new while retaining most of the beats the original had and conveying them better than ever. Beautiful alien enviorment with sparse interference of Black Mesa temp-facilities scattered here and there, that are joy to explore and retaining all the level design principles and knowledge that Half-Life is known for.
Problem of slowly depleeting resources in later chapters are absent thanks to frankly good move to make scientists from overworld sent you care packages, making them actually help you.
Interloper chapter has still little pacing issue, but it is not bad as it is penultimate chapter and it being longer feels like final stretch to reach finale, so that basically resolves itself.

I would still highly recommend playing the original HL before Black Mesa to appreciate video game history and what an amazing game it still is. But Black Mesa is better and absolutely amazing. A worthwhile play!

What if you take the worst parts of half life, make it approximately 10 times as long and still make sure it's tediously boring? You get black mesa.
Before getting to the post Xen chapters of this game I would've given this game a thumbs up, with minor gripes, like weirdly sticky ladders, grenade throwing which is somehow worse than the original half life, and the overly long and unending Surface Tension. 
But God, things that took 10 minutes in the original take 2 hours now. And yes I get it, it looks way better. But boy does it lose novelty fast.
Who wants to do platforming for an entire hour on Xen with barely any combat. 
Who wants the 10 minute battle with Gonarch to become an artificially scripted hour long slog where you just run.
If you thought that Black Mesa stretched Surface Tension too much, wait till you get to interloper. Unlike surface tension which gives you really good and rather difficult combat sections that force you to master the combat mechanics, in interloper, you get EXTREMELY TEDIOUS PLATFORMING.
And just like the other stretched out levels, this one is twice as long.
The original interloper also had platforming, but it also had challenging combat. But in this game? It's just tedious platforming that is absolutely unending.
WHY DO I NEED AN HOUR OF CONNECTING CIRCUITS THROUGHOUT THE FACTORY?
Why am I fixing the production line for alien slaves to proceed in the level?
I have not finished this game because interloper is just sheer pathetic boredom.
No amount of improved graphics justifies how pointless the post Xen sections of the game are.
They've truly managed to do the unthinkable, take the already criticised Xen levels of the game, and make it somehow unbearably worse.

EDIT -  I did finish the game, and the end of interloper did get better, but not by much. It has this repetitive pattern of introduce a new puzzle element, then make you do it again with a bit more complexity, then another with further complexity, and then a 3 part puzzle where you have to solve three of the same puzzle to proceed, it becomes such a repetitive pattern it's almost funny if it wasn't so boring.
What this game needs is an editor, who can trim the fat and just keep the good parts of the game, because the Xen parts of the game are needlessly long and boring.
One part I forgot to mention about the game, is that the Hound Dogs and Bullsquid have for whatever reason been made far more annoying than they were in the original and I have no idea why. 
The final boss fight against Nihilanth is actually pretty fun and exhilarating. G-man voice acting was an attempt for sure, not a whole lot good about it. But my opinion still stands, Post Xen really ruins the flow of the game and makes it way too tedious to complete.

[h1] Black Mesa - 2024 review [/h1]

I've never had the chance to play the original Half-Life. I've played everything else, including Alyx. With the Overwhelmingly Positive review average on Steam for this fan remake, I knew I had to try it out. I'm very glad I did, as it looks like this game has improved from its predecessor, and I enjoyed it a lot, but I'll say that unlike the majority, there's specific points that definitely irritated me throughout my experience. Here's everything I liked (or didn't) about Black Mesa:

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*] The story is what kept me on the edge here. I'm a big fan of the lore behind the Half-Life universe, and I think it's a franchise that excels with storytelling. Black Mesa is no different. I was on the edge of my seat during the whole game, even though I was already familiar with what was happening in the first entry, thanks to numerous YouTube videos and such. I was still extremely immersed from a narrative point of view during my playthrough.
[*] The gameplay is perfect. If you enjoyed the simplicity yet the punch behind your arsenal in any Half-Life title, this game does it even better. You feel like a superhero, yet the slightest mistake or overstep can result in a punishing drain of health. The fluidity in your movement is still a big thing, and the puzzles are great (and have been mostly upgraded from the original, from what I've heard). The singular physics associated with Valve are even more polished while staying true to their roots. It's honestly a winning gameplay recipe that not a lot of games are able to reach.
[*] The AI feels great and has been improved. The enemies feel coordinated and can punish you for your mistakes (ex, reloading at an improper time). It made the fights even more thrilling. [/list]

[b] Neutrals [/b]
[list]
[*] The graphics have been upgraded, and they definitely retain Half-Life's aesthetic. Unfortunately, this remake has been in the making for so long (and they stuck with an old engine) that they do not reach the standards of realism from other games released in 2020, even Indie games as such. Nonetheless, that didn't matter to me. I was just glad it felt like I looking at another Half-Life title, even if the graphics aren't beautiful.
[*] On occasions, the game may stutter a bit. I didn't happen to me too often, but it happened most likely during key action packed moments, often resulting in losing a big chunk of health, or even death. I was playing on a high-end rig, definitely above the recommended settings, so I guess this is just a stability issue from the game. I also crashed once, for some reason, at a completely random moment during the Xen chapter. Stability could have been improved a bit, performances are great though (my FPS were nearly always maxed out with any drops aside from the ones caused by the stutters). [/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] The game's got decent level design for the most part, with sometimes a little annoying backtracking, until you reach Xen. The supposedly improved final segment is extremely annoying, dull, and feels tremendously stretched out. The mix of parkour, repetitive puzzles and never-ending invisible walls nearly made me drop the game. It's a shame since the rest of the game is so great compared to this specific part.
[*] To 100% this game, you'll need to a lot of runs with very specific demands. There's also tons of Easter Eggs nearly impossible to figure out on your own to get all the achievements. You'll definitely guides, blood, sweat and tears to unlock everything. If you're going for a normal run and don't care about achievements, you'll probably feel like the game drags on for a bit too long (maybe 2-3 hours more than required?) because of the last Xen segment I already mentioned. Be ready to face a more tedious part at some point before going in. [/list]

[b] TL;DR [/b]
If you like story-driven FPS, you'll like it. If you like the Half-Life franchise, you'll probably love it. But there's some downsides to it, and I feel like most of the reviews here tone those down. Just be aware of them before purchasing it. I feel like even with some major complaints, the pros overwhelm the cons and you'll end up having a great experience, thanks to the immersive story, the snappy gameplay, and the nostalgia brought by such an iconic franchise.

[b] Rating: 7/10 [/b]

I played Half Life for the first time about a month before experiencing it again in Black Mesa. It's a fantastic recreation of the original that was already so good, but with many improvements of its own. I enjoyed Black Mesa's attention to detail that added to the immersion, like wacky experiments going on in the labs and the much more expansive world of Xen. I would go as far as to say Black Mesa even improves on the story, making it all make more sense, especially the last 3-4 chapters. Many of the additions/changes bring the Half Life spirit to a modern FPS audience. If you don't have the patience for the graphics and technical limitations of the 1998 classic, this is the perfect way to be introduced.

My short list of complaints include the last couple chapters drag on a little to long for my taste, the movement can sometimes be a bit floaty (this is especially irritating when you are trying to get somewhere quickly, i.e. Gargantuan run), and the 4+ achievements requiring the player to stop having fun and carry a stupid object through the entire game - clearly a nod to the Gnome achievement in HL2E2. These kinds of achievements may be funny/memey, but can really ruin an achievement hunter's time.

black mesa is a love letter and a message to all developers as to how to do a remake of a classic industry standardizing game right, this game is a fantastic retelling of the well established bread and butter of half-life, it cannot be stated enough how much thought went into this game, every level has been rebuilt and hand-crafted to not only feel like the original game, but also make drastic improvements to the design and the environmental story-telling of the original, all the while making sure not to step on the toes of the groundwork that valve set all those years ago. Black Mesa, the fan-made remake of the iconic Half-Life, is a remarkable achievement that pays homage to the original while elevating it to new heights:

1) Visual Overhaul: Black Mesa‚Äôs graphics are a breath of fresh air. The Source engine brings the environments to life, and while some textures may show their age, the overall improvement is undeniable. The sterile halls of the Black Mesa Research Facility feel more lived-in, with environmental storytelling adding depth to the experience.

2) Gameplay Refinement: Combat in Black Mesa is smooth and satisfying. Gordon Freeman, clad in his iconic orange power suit, feels like an absolute beefcake tank when fully charged. The crowbar swings with manic speed, and the weapons retain their classic feel. Real physics enhances the immersion, even if they‚Äôre rarely used for puzzles or combat.

3) Liberties Taken: The development team wisely trimmed annoying segments from the original Half-Life and injected more of what works. NPC interactions, well-acted and peppered with in-jokes, add flavor. The game‚Äôs pacing feels tighter, making it a joy to revisit the interdimensional invasion.

4) Nostalgia with a Twist: Black Mesa evokes nostalgia while introducing fresh elements. The loading screens, though occasionally jarring, transport us back to the late '90s. The original music, while not always a perfect fit, finds its place on the alien homeworld of Xen.

5) A Triumph of Fan Passion: Over eight years in the making, Black Mesa stands as the most impressive fan game ever created. It‚Äôs not a 1:1 remake, but that‚Äôs part of its charm. It‚Äôs a lovingly crafted take on a pivotal moment in PC gaming history.

In summary, Black Mesa isn‚Äôt just a replacement for Half-Life; it coexists alongside it, offering a modernized journey through the Black Mesa Research Facility. So grab your crowbar, suit up, and relive the adventure! üöÄüî•

This thing... Oh wow, what can I say... This...
This is one of the greatest games. EVER. 
1. Visuals: The VFX are stunning, altough HL2 used source mainly for the water and some gun effects, Black Mesa absolutely milked every possible particle (and for good reason). A game like Half Life, which unlike HL2 is full of futuristic stuff like machines, gizmos and what not needs some great effects. Shaders are crazy, at some moments this looks like real life. Unreal Engine? Nuh uh, Source is the way.
2. SFX. These developer blokes are crazy, they found actors that sound EXACTLY like the original VAs. It's really weird when you first hear something thats 8-bit turned into crispy, crystal clear ear massage. Weapon sounds are great, and I enjoy the fact that they changed the sound on that Xen jumping pad thing.
3. Chapters: Before Xen, this game basically copied everything from Half Life and maybe made some places bigger (like the sattelite launch platform) and added a lot of teeny tiny details and secrets that would be impossible with GoldSRC. Now, Xen chapters... A lot of people HATE the fact that they made Xen, Gonarch's lair and Interloper 10 times longer, but I absolutely respect that. Xen has so much potential. A potential that was absolutely impossible in 1998. Now Xen looks absolutely staggering. I really love the fact that they turned Xen from a group of small floating islands to a bunch of huge floating islands. Most of the chapters seemed easier, including Lambda Core and even Nihilanth, which had beautiful visuals but didn't quite feel like a boss battle. Instead, Gonarch's lair which took me like 2 hours feels a lot harder. 
4. Gameplay: As I said, most chapters felt easier. I enjoy being able to G R A B objects, just like in HL2, but this time in a facility, full of laptops, computers, monitors, everything you can think of. One thing that was weird was that in Apprehension, you had to put some barrels under a bridge to make it float, just like in HL2. You also had to grab some cables and put them where you need to to divert electricity.
In conclusion, this is a bloody masterpiece. Half Life was already a masterpiece, but Black Mesa absolutely blows it away!

[Review after the Playthrough]
I've enjoyed the game so much until the end. The Crowbar Collective have done an incredible job overall, Xen was also so good! But Interloper chapter + the final boss fight has definitely killed the game for me. The Interloper chapter was way too long and too tedious and simply not fun. They've improved the game by shortening the On a Rail chapter but then added Interloper which is much much worse.... After all that frustration completing Interloper, I was looking forward to face the Nihilanth, but the end boss fight was so over the top, the made the Nihilanth such a bullet sponge, it was simply ridiculous, I thought I was playing a completely other game... So, I still recommend playing this game, but do yourself a favour and don't let the balancing issues spoil your fun and go for the god mode if you need to get closure...

After so many years of development I totally understand them to want to finish the game but, with less content and less exaggeration, they could have made the ending match the rest of the game in terms of quality...

[Final Release Review]
Black Mesa became such a masterpiece. Grunt AI has really been drastically improved, and also all of the graphical glitches I've encountered in early access versions have been fixed. Oldschool (in a negative sense) and frustrating parts of some HL1 levels have been improved and modernised. All of it without losing even a tiny bit of HL1 vibes
This is a true love letter to the HL1! 
Well done Crowbar Collective, your longterm commitment has really paid off!

I didn't have a chance to play original half-life, but I knew that the story is great and one day I decided to buy Black Mesa as it was a more modern approach to telling the same story. 

While playing the game I couldn't help but noticed lots of tiny details that make experience much better. It was clear to me because of the that developer put lots and lots hours of care, love and hard work. It was much more obvious when, after completing the game, I looked into some compression videos and found out for example how was redesign xen, all the boss fights, lots of single objects and details they had to add to make every single room more believable, more realistic and more live. I respect the original game but after so much time you should agree that there was not much to go off. 

Sound design is also great, lots of music turns out I was listening to remixes before knew about the game. Huge rework and redraw of all weapon, characters and locations, while trying to preserve the same feeling and same map as was before. 

For me as a guy who didn't play half-life games (just half-life 2 a little, and huge fan of portal played all games and mods) it was so fresh going around 
 without objective task, minimap, compass or arrow to next task. You always had to figure out yourself, but the clues is always there either it be a green light near the next door or path you should open or go, or red something blocking the way. Overall level design in my opinion was great and I caught myself on an that idea especially in the beginning to middle of the game. (except few minor moments but more on that later)

Crowbar collective did a tremendous work, especially for such a cheap price and this game imo was a great force to invest me into the half-life story.

The game is not all shine and rainbow, but hat's just a few minor hiccups that killed my love to the game a little bit, still game so good I can forget it easily.

It's a great remake and it's even more impressive when you consider it's a mod. It's probably the second best fan remake I've played (AM2R probably being the best). The game, however, makes a lot of changes from the original. Some are welcome. Some of the more tedious aspects of the game are made a bit more bearable, for instance. Some changes are odd. There's a lot of changes that seem to be made just for the sake of being different. A lot of areas are just different in a way that doesn't add or subtract anything. Some changes are outright terrible. Many areas and encounters have been significantly simplified. Puzzles are changed. Some are made way too easy, while others have just been made unintuitive. Xen goes on entirely too long and some of it is actually worse than the original (which is funny considering the original Xen was a rushed mesh). If it sounds like I'm being unfair, remember this mod costs money so I'm going to hold it to the standard of a paid game.

Still if you like FPS games or you just want more Half-Life this is a good option. The developer clearly put a lot of work into it and it's well worth the money, despite it not measuring up to the original. The big caveat is that the original Half-Life is just a better game in almost every way. You should probably play that before this one. This one just looks a bit nicer.

I had my doubts the first time I tried this on a real craptop. I'm talking "shared" video memory of 128MB. A shameful memory (oh ho ho what a crap pun I noticed upon proofreading) but time makes fools of us all

After getting an upgrade a good while later, something in the back of my mind kept drawing me back to this. Maybe it was the high acclaim, the promised source port that would give us ragdoll scientists or a combination of that and my love for the series

But there wasn't a Xen yet.

So I waited, checking in every so often, hoping to god they finally did what a lot of us hoped we'd find on the other side the first time we played - or even watched - the OG. No longer a woefully rushed video-gamey play area with mismatched textures

Then it finally dropped, and went on sale shortly after. I was on that like a c()ked-out cat on a laser dot

Yeah yeah, the Black Mesa facility itself is cool and a lot of the environments look much better and more realistic which immerses you more than the original ever could, in my opinion; but I just finished the thing and my bias is about to begin

It took a good while and even a long hiatus, but I finally got to see what I'd waited so long for, and I don't care how long it may take to get through, Xen is absolutely glorious. It truly feels like a living breathing ecosystem clinging to rocks in an endless void of stardust. 
Do the octo-dogs even wanna be there? 
Damned if I know, but the environmental design sells the concept so well that I can only describe it as inspired

I've been in so long that it feels like I was last in the Black Mesa facility a month ago, but I never minded once

I didn't realise just how good the Source engine could look when given to the right people, but I enjoyed every second of it and took an ungodly amount of screenshots. Bad habit but I'm justified this time. 
It almost felt like a completely different game at times but they did a fantastic job of keeping it grounded in the HL universe and the odd familiar site brought it back. (Trust me, they changed a lot, and for the better) 
I even stayed invested during some of the puzzles I bungled so many times. My fault, not theirs

The fight with the Gonarch felt a million times more thrilling and it truly felt like a titan you can only delay from fighting until the climactic confrontation in its lair. An *actual* lair that doesn't feel like a tiny room but a gosh damn cavern teeming with albino crab babies

Speaking of, the music elevates so many moments in this game that I'm in love with the original tracks for the memories they've helped create. Especially in Xen. *ESPECIALLY* in Xen.

Then Interloper started and explored the concept of Vortigaunt slavery better than the inference of the slave collars in the OG and not only shows you, but throws the thing in your face, and makes you feel satisfied when killing the Controllers, instead of relieved at killing the annoying floaty enemy

I detected a little inspiration from DOOM (2016) at this point, especially when first entering the place, and that's all good in my books. After five minutes they just made it their own thing. Makes you wonder just how big the Combine is if all of what you see in this chapter is a doomed last-stand

The climax feels awe-inspiring too, beating down those airborne fetuses with zero remorse and destroying everything that moves - machinery especially - and feeling yourself getting nearer and nearer to the particularly big fetus who was sending aliens all up in Black Mesa's business.
Good lord I spent an egregious amount of time tonight stuck on one of the final gauntlets. I had to be sure I didn't accidentally sunburn a vortigaunt with the Ghostbusters Proton Pack

The final fight itself is leagues above the original, feeling more like a fight for your life and everybody else who got zapped in hometown BM. I particularly liked the creative way they justify getting more ammo but like hell I'm spoiling something so insignificant

Then bam, I lasered a big baby in the cranium until God - or something - had enough of my overused jokes and [REDACTED, seriously play the game already. If you're even vaguely into FPS's and somehow find games before 2013 ""unplayable"", then just jump into this and let it be your introduction. I won't judge]
 
Then asthma man told me to step out of a moving tram and I felt pretty good for getting through ceaseless genociding. Also by the time I was on the very last section of Interloper, I truly believe that Gordon Freeman must have severe PTSD by this point

No wonder he went mute after that

It [was] midnight but I feel compelled to profess my love for this and just how much it exceeded my expectations, Xen especially since more is better when a whole sci-fi concept or ten has a lot of gameplay and story potential

This is absolutely what a Half-Life retelling should be and I'm so glad I got to experience it.

This is a review from someone that was too young to play Half-Life 1 back in the day, so this review is nostalgia free.
I tried the original game, but found it painful to play modern standards. I think this game is much, much better than the original if you're a modern gamer looking to experience the classic game in an updated package. 

That being said, if I were to judge this game on its own merits, not knowing that it's a remake of a classic, I wouldn't be impressed at all. There are rampant technical issues: save corruption, soft locks, weapons turning invisible, sound effects playing 5 seconds too late, your altered settings resetting themselves to default in the middle of a play session, and the list goes on and on. This is one of the most janky games I've played in a long time. 

The gameplay is also severely mediocre. It's better than trying to slog through the original, but that's not saying much. The game also over stays it's welcome by quite a bit. It should be half the length and even then, not much happens. Constantly waiting for the game to load the next level section also gets quite old. 

The only reason I finished this game was because I played Half-Life 2 as a kid and I was always curious what happened in the first game. Well now I know and the answer is a very generic bare bones story with mediocre gameplay. Half-Life 2 is orders of magnitudes better than this game. 

Overall, I can really only recommend this game if you are desperate to play through the HL 1 story line. In that case, this game is the best way to do it, but it's still not worth your money or your time in my opinion.

[i]I forced my friend to play this with me watching. Sadly I'm unable to play these kind of games anymore due to a handicap. [/i] 

[h2]An absolute classic modernised [/h2]
When I think of classic FPS's, Half-Life is certainly one of them. Much slower paced than Doom and Quake, and in a true science fiction setting. The game starts quite ordinary, as if the real world. With the fantastic opening sequence into the Black Mesa facility. But, going back to old games can be tough. So when HL2 released, fans recreated HL1 in the new engine. I remember early in 201X I downloaded the game and the soundtrack from their website. I never got to playing it. Since Valve allowed fan-made HL games to be published on Steam, Black Mesa could come to Steam as well. 

Compared to the original a lot of artistic extrapolation is required. Most original levels are near empty, relying on sprites on walls. Many rooms are bigger and more furnished, because now we can. But, the game pushes the old engine beyond its ability many times. No matter what computer or settings you use, the game stutters at times. And this is a shame, seeing how beautiful everything is created. Maybe a future recreation? These type of games warrant faithful recreations forever, because a classic like this is gaming history! 

85/100

REVIEW #77
Black Mesa
-------

The most fitting thing that I can call this fan-made remake of the original Half-Life game is "an obvious labor of love." Many years went into the development of Black Mesa, and it clearly shows in its presentation. The graphics are stunning, the voice acting is superb, the gameplay and combat are highly engaging, and the environments feel real and "lived-in". It's a fantastic entry point for players new to the Half-Life series, but those who have played the original HL1 should also be very pleased not only in how well the original environments have been re-designed and rendered (to the point where some feel like a big step up from the originals) but that Black Mesa includes a few surprises, including a couple of new enemies and environmental hazards as well as a completely revamped section of the game.

On the negative side of things, those who are considering purchasing this game do need to be aware of some bugginess with the physics engine, which can occasionally include things like "teleporting" NPCs and elevators that cause your body to explode when they move. Also, make sure to save often, as sometimes, you'll get saved into a bad situation like partially in a wall or right at the moment of death, and you may need to backtrack to an older save point. It's annoying, but for me, it didn't break the experience completely.

It's also worth mentioning, too, that some combat scenarios (especially when on the higher difficulty) can almost feel like mini-rage games sometimes, being incredibly brutal and overwhelming on occasion. With that said, I never felt frustrated while playing and instead felt encouraged to try a failed enemy encounter again but with different weapons and tactics.

To conclude, I told a friend before I wrote this review that, after I had finished Black Mesa, I felt like I had experienced an epic event more than like I had merely played a game. It's fun to play AND very cinematic and polished in presentation. I highly recommend this one, especially to Half-Life fans.

Black Mesa

	Developed by Crowbar Collective, Black Mesa is a re-creation of the original Half-Life in the source engine, announced way back in 2005. For the longest time, the game was nearly complete, but just lacking the last few chapters set on Xen. Being the final obstacle Gordon Freeman had to overcome in the original game.
	After fighting your way to the center of the Black Mesa base, you had to cross over to the borderworld, Xen, to kill the alien leader, the Nihilanth. The quality of these last few levels have been a point of contention ever since the game's original release in ‚Äò98. People were anxiously waiting for what it would look like in this remake.
	And after several years, it was released. And though I am very late to both Black Mesa, and the Half-Life franchise in general, these levels are millions of miles ahead of the original game, so that's what I want to spend this review talking about.  Whenever replaying the original game, I tend to stop playing after finishing Lambda Core, just because of how bad these levels actually are. 
	Xen in the original game felt very rushed. It had sloppy platforming, a huge difficulty spike out of nowhere, and unnecessarily dragged the game on for another few hours, when it really shouldn‚Äôt have. Even people who worked on the original Half-Life (Gabe Newell included) said that they weren't too happy with how Xen ended up in the retail product. This makes sense, as you only need to play it for about 5 minutes before you realize how sloppy it actually is.
	Starting off awkwardly long jumping from poorly-textured platform to the next, and if you missed a single one, you would either die, or suffer crippling fall damage. When researching, Crowbar Collective spent all this extra time on the worst parts of the original game, I didn‚Äôt have too much confidence. Somehow though, these guys managed to make the Xen chapters actually fun to play.
	First thing you notice once you actually land in Xen, is the visuals. And I‚Äôm going to be honest, this is the best the game has ever looked. The first area you get dropped into is simply amazing. There is also this really great ambient soundtrack that almost feels at odds with the chapter‚Äôs violent undertones.
	The music for the entire game was composed by a guy named Joel Nielson, whose work in the other chapters felt very hit or miss at times. Most of his stuff throughout the Xen chapters though, really seem to work well. They also somehow managed to mix things up pretty well also from area to area. 
	You will long jump across floating platforms, explore caves with basalt pillars, and there is often alien algae hanging from the ceiling or from massive stalactites. Combine it all with the gorgeous lighting and water effects, and you have yourself a pretty damn good-looking game. 
This comes at the expense of the performance though, and there are some spots where you can expect the game to chug along. 
	I think artistically, these new chapters are just fantastic. Can‚Äôt really fault the performance issues when it looks so good. Definitely different to the original levels, but I think that's for the best, as most of those levels were pretty unremarkable.  In what is a simple, but very effective change is the long jump module is now bound to tapping space bar twice, which makes way more sense then pressing crouch, and jump at the same time in the original game. 
	You will also be putting this mechanic to use, by either effortlessly leaping from platform to platform, or in combat, as it makes a pretty handy dodge move during boss fights. There is very little to actually complain about, with the exception of it looking a bit more aquatic than alien at times. Something I really like about these earlier stages is that it does a MUCH better job at establishing that Black Mesa had really explored this place before Gordon‚Äôs arrival, which is something they only kind of touched on in the original. 
	In Black Mesa, you will come across various camps and makeshift labs that help establish that the Lambda Team really set up shop here. As you get deeper into the levels, these outposts become fewer and farther between, emphasizing that at this point you really are in completely uncharted territory. 
	My only real complaint with these first few areas is the overusage of the Houndeyes. There were a few of these in the original game, but not THIS many. On top of that, there are also brand new variants. Including smaller ones that explode when killed, and a bigger armored kind as well. There is this one area, where you have to avoid a bunch of trip mines that make no sense lore wise. Why the hell are they even there?
	Still, these first few levels are pretty enjoyable and creative compared to the original game. Combining platforming, combat, and some basic puzzle solving. Moving things along at a nice pace and never feeling bogged down. First impressions are definitely the most important, and Xen is off to a good start on that front. 
	Up next is the boss fight against the Gonarch. Again, this whole area is very visually impressive. Maybe even more so than the first chapter. She won‚Äôt show up until you turn on these switches, but when she finally does in something of a cinematic, it plays out pretty similarly to the original game. By that I mean you need to hit her with every single one of your best weapons before she runs away. Something I like is that you have to actively use the long jump to avoid her projectiles. On hard mode, this first phase is an absolute challenge. Getting hit by her once or twice is back to the start of the phase, and you need to be a lot more cautious with how you approach things. 
	Like before, after you deal a bit of damage to her, she runs off and you go pursue after her. However in the original game, you got back to fighting her almost immediately causing the fight to go super quick. Only being about 10-15 minutes. In Black Mesa though, you play a lot of cat-and-mouse. This chapter alone tends to take about 30-45 minutes compared to the original.
	At the end, it plays out pretty similarly to the original game, just blasting her until she explodes. This whole chapter was decent. All the stuff in-between the Gonarch fight was definitely the highlight, as otherwise the whole confrontation would feel identical to the one in 1998. Interloper though, is where things start to fall apart.
	Interloper starts off as you move through some more alien-looking landscapes, fight through some rank cave systems, and then start getting chased by a few Gargantuas, where you really just need to haul ass out of there, and some points definitely had a sense of urgency and tension.
	Then you get to the factory, and that‚Äôs where it all goes to shit. Moving up all these never-ending conveyor belts, shutting down force-fields, and a bunch of really repetitive cable puzzles. This was also where I experienced the most bugs, and got so frustrated that I had to take a long break from it after completing just to get my head straight.
	Despite most people already knowing it, I don‚Äôt plan on spoiling the end boss, but I will say that they thankfully turned the whole thing around for the finale. The final boss has been tweaked slightly to be less tedious, which I appreciate. The low gravity is gone, so it doesn't feel like you are moving underwater, and the boss doesn't shoot the teleportation portals anymore. It also puts the long jump module to use strategically to dodge all the attacks that are used, and there is a definite charm in seeing the ending getting redone in the source engine. 
Black Mesa is a real ‚ÄúSum of its parts‚Äù kind of game. If you look at Xen by itself (which is what I‚Äôve been doing this entire time) It is very easy to nitpick things and find all of these faults, but in the grand scheme of things, the remake as a whole is phenomenal. Fixes pretty much all of the issues the original had. 4.5/5 Stars. Probably the closest a fan game will come to perfection.

[h1]Relive The Half Life Experience[/h1]
Black Mesa is a 2020 first-person shooter game developed and published by Crowbar Collective. It is a third-party remake of Half-Life (1998) made in the Source game engine. Originally published as a free mod in September 2012, Black Mesa was approved for commercial release by Valve, the developers of Half-Life. You are Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist at the Black Mesa Research Facility. When a routine experiment goes horribly wrong, you must fight your way through an interdimensional alien invasion, and a bloodthirsty military clean-up crew in order to save the science team... and the world!


[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td]Black Mesa uses the Source Engine (same as Half Life 2, Counter Strike Source, etc) and I have to say that the game looks incredible. This is a remake of Half Life 1 and my goodness they nailed the visuals perfectly! The atmosphere is much darker than the Half Life 1 and it‚Äôs a needed change. The lighting is superb, the weapons and character models look incredible (especially on the Source Engine). Xen (the other world) had a complete overhaul and it looks 100x better than what it did in Half Life 1. The UI also looks modern and really good. Honestly this is a fantastic remake visually and I can't find one complaint in terms of graphics.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td]The gameplay is pretty good and quite similar to previous Half Life games. You have some creative platforming puzzles, good gunplay, many challenges, etc. You have some really cool weapons to use here, and the enemy redesign is fantastic. The level design is pretty similar, but you will see some drastic improvements in some areas. Black Mesa takes advantage of the Source Engine and gives many creative puzzles and the big bump in level design is incredible. The overall gameplay is a huge step up and It‚Äôs just hard to find a flaw here. Xen is completely overhauled. Many chapters feel different in Xen and I think they did a fantastic job. The final boss design looks really good and many sections before the final boss is truly challenging and a huge step up. In Half Life 1, Xeno was a complete chore to go through as it was both uninteresting, ugly, and has the more lousy level design in the game. Here it‚Äôs a completely different story, Xeno is fixed and it‚Äôs beautiful, filled with mystery, and even has some fun sections. Only one chapter called ‚ÄúInterloper‚Äù dragged a bit, but besides that Xeno is a near masterpiece improvement compared to Half Life 1. The only flaw in terms of gameplay is the Helicopter boss fight. The helicopter moves way too fast for the rockets at times. The Rockets move extremely slow and can be frustrated as h*ll.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üìúStory[/td]
        [td]The story is much better here. Has anything truly changed? Not really, but with the better dialogue and voice acting, it truly feels much more filled with life. You will see more cinematic scenes and overall give the characters a feeling of importance. I enjoyed the story a lot here, way more than the original. Maybe it‚Äôs the cinematic, maybe it‚Äôs the voice acting, but it just feels like a huge improvement in my opinion.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]The main story is around like 15+ hours. It‚Äôs a pretty good story mode (in terms of Length). You also have many mods in the Steam workshop that can add tons of replayability as well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]I love the sound design. The music is so incredible! The soundtrack is really high quality and AAA material. The voice acting is a massive improvement compared to the original. The weapons sound good too. They are punchy and all sound unique from each other. The only problem I have is that there is no dialogue sound option in the audio settings. At times the voices can sound pretty low.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td]I have not really experienced any bugs from my gameplay. Maybe some minor clipping issues but nothing really serious. The game felt pretty optimized in terms of bugs.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîÖPerformance[/td]
        [td]Performance was pretty solid. I was playing on max settings and rarely had any issues. I had some rare fps drops (although minor) in Xeno during one section, but besides that it was really good. I did have some crashes when I changed many graphical options (this was not every time, but did happen).[/td]

This title started off as a ground-up remake of the original Half-Life 1, arguably one of the progenitors of PC gaming as we know it today, and a fond memory for long time gamers such as myself. Completely fan-made, one wouldn‚Äôt always expect greatness from a title paying homage to another, but this game always first comes to mind when I talk with anyone about quality remakes of games.

Black Mesa is fantastic, solidly loyal to the original material of the first game while bringing in new elements, upgraded visuals and engaging gameplay. For those who haven‚Äôt played the original, you play as Gordon Freeman, scientist at a top secret underground laboratory in the desert. It starts off as a normal day, until a massive rift opens up and aliens start pouring through ‚Äì not the best start to the working day! The labs are quickly compromised, and you essentially work your way through the labs looking for a way to escape and saving as many colleagues as you can.

The game is an FPS with a subtle blend of action, horror and platforming with a few puzzle elements thrown in, and is pretty linear in its progression through Black Mesa. Segments of the game are clearly separated depending on what the objective is ‚Äì you‚Äôre met with dark atmospheres and tense echoing silence during horror sections, head nodding techno mixes during gunfights and science fiction synth as you take in sprawling new areas.

This games big moment for me, without spoiling anything, is when you get to the end of the labs. There‚Äôs a bit of a debate whether the new version of this section is better or not, but I personally think the remake did an incredible job reimagining this section of the game, though I will agree that a particular area of this dragged on a little too long (the conveyor belt section). That said, the parts leading up to that were so intensely atmospheric, engaging and otherworldly compared to the original, I can‚Äôt consider it a detriment to the game at all.

A must buy for any fan of Half Life or story-driven FPS games in general, and an absolute steal during sales. I think I purchased for around $5 which is insane value for money!

An excelent remake, a fun game and dare I say a worthy tribute to the Original. Black Mesa aims to impress graphicaly, improve areas where Half Life was rushed, be it in level design, lore or gameplay.

---the plus :

The game runs well, it's graphics aren't on par with current AAA games but I never felt it slow down or loose framerates.

the enemies are decently rebalanced, and the NPCs are well voiced with a welcome cameo, (although distracting for some, which I can understand)

the art direction is quite good, if a little less cartoonish than what Half Life aimed to present, which doesn't serve it's dark comedy moments. there's also a few more lens flares than I would have liked, but that's just me.

finally the music, and especially once in XEN, is phenomenal, and has earned a permanent spot in my playlist.

it's easy to mod too, some mods like Blue Shift even offer a whole new (WIP) campaign, other replace the [Redacted] with Dr Coomer from HLVRAI (also worth a look)

---the bad :

A few levels however, and especially the second to last (Interloper), feels rushed also. the improvement on gameplay and art direction sill left us with a bloated and confusing level, where the texture work is honestly a bit ugly and some puzzles could, and should, have been cut entirely.

a few of the effects, like the blood particles coming out of destroyed bodies, feel a bit dated and cheap. as well, the body parts feel to rigid and samey, like a Lego character was just disassembled.

---conclusion :

buy the game. buy it because you loved Half Life, buy it because you want to discover Half life. buy it because oyu like fun shooters with awesome music.

As a Half Life 1 Remake, I'd say Black Mesa checks all the boxes you'd want.  Everything Pre-Xen/Endgame was REALLY FUN and very faithful to the original game.  The shooting is fun, fast paced, and the quick weapon swapping's probably my favorite addition.  Despite having a really old PC, Black Mesa performed really well while also having impressive visuals.  

Enough of that, Black Mesa's a fantastic HL1 Remake.  HOWEVER, i found Xen/the last few levels pretty dull and here's why...  
- not enough combat/shooting stuff
- too many puzzles and platforming
- performed like dogpoo & got real back framreates during specific sections
Now, I'm very biased 'cause I generally enjoy fast paced shooters with zero cutscenes and constant action.  I can't even fault the developer of Black Mesa for this.  While Xen in the original HL1 was different, it still included tons of platforming.

I'm still overlooking my lackluster opinion of Xen because the rest of the game was so much fun.  If you played the original Half Life 1 and/or it's sequel, then it's frankly a no-brainer to pick this up.

ALSO/FYI: the asking price of $20 is insanely good value for what you're gettin here.

I remember following this project when it just started and being super excited about it. I played one of the first "full" versions where you downloaded free packages from their website and installed it using Source SDK. There was no Xen at that time. And now when the game is finished, Xen completely ruins the experience. It's unnecessarily long and boring; all the fun environmental puzzles they come up with are duplicated many times, so you are sick of putting the same three cables into some machine or shooting a red blob to unlock another leaf.

[h3]Playing on Steam Deck[/h3]

I played in desktop mode, and the performance was terrible. Everything before Xen I was able to play on Low settings with 4k resolution with most of the stuff disabled, getting 30-40 fps. Xen and everything after it - a complete lagfest. I had to drop the resolution to full HD and disable everything, and still only getting 15-30 fps. Other Source engine games run significantly better.

On top of performance problems, I was getting constant crashes. Sometimes these crashes happen during autosave, making this autosave broken, so you have to replay some parts. So I had to Quick Save constantly

Really nice. Just finished my first play-through. What a ride to play this reimagined version of the classic Half-Life story. It's an uncanny experience, but in the best possible way. The familiar setting of Black Mesa is populated with HL2 style npcs in the way Halo Reach assets were reused in Halo CE Anniversary, the music is different, the lighting is different, and yet it all looks so familiar. The difference is in the emotion. It was totally redesigned through darker lighting, the lack of comedic deaths, and the music. The music in particular. A sense of dreadful sadness haunts you through your journey. By time you are in Xen, there's a real strong vibe of "Gazing Into the Abyss". In all, it's a brilliant reimagining everyone should bother trying.

Wow I gotta say out of my 15 hourish playthrough I probably had fun for 2-3 hours of it, I was miserable begging for the game to end after about hour 8.

The puzzles were kinda fun at first but every puzzle is copied 2-3 times just to make you do it 2-3 times like why?! All the charm and excite meant is gone after the first time but they're still gunna copy and paste it a few more times don't worry.

The level design is extremity unintuitive never following the rules it sets for more then a few minutes before throwing what you thought would be a consistent mechanic out the window. Not to mention throwing countless forks in the road at you for no other reason then a dead end of wasted time.

I understand the physics engine is old but there is no attempt to add setting to try and help it function on modern hardware; there's no frame rate cap in the settings and the game constantly jumps around between 180 and 250 FPS causing it to just fall apart half the time launching me into a wall or 100s of feet in the air killing me or preventing me from continuing without loading a save.

The jumping puzzles wouldn't be so bad if the game felt any bit responsive, there's constantly jagged hit boxes around terrain that doesn't even come close to the actual textures leaving you to bonk your head or side causing you to miss a simple jump and reload yet again. Then half the time your climbing the "intended" path the terrain has so many jagged edges that climbing up a simple ledge is a horrific jump spamming mess.

Xen was cool for about an hour and now I'm the most miserable I've been in the game yet. It's long, visually and puzzle repetitive once in the factory, and the sense of direction is thrown out the window.

Maybe if you're an old school gamer this was cool or revolutionary but, to play this as a normal gamer in 20234 was a long from fun experience, I just wanted it to end.

In an age, where AAA companies keep remaking their old games, to recapture the glory days, in comes Crowbar Collective, making their own remake of the original Half-Life by Valve, and it BLOWS all other remakes out of the river. Black Mesa took around 15 years to complete, and it was well worth the wait, as almost everything has been improved upon.

[h3] THE ENEMIES AND WEAPONS [/h3]

Crowbar Collective did a magnificent job remaking the Half-Life 1 roster, as well as adding some new ones, like the Alpha Houndeyes, Explosive Houndeyes, Water Barnacles, etc. The weapons all work as you'd expect for the most part. The MP5 feels a lot better than its HL1 counterpart, killing things a bit faster. The Gluon Gun is an absolute beast, that disintegrates things even faster. My only complaints being, that the rocket launcher has slower projectiles, and the hand grenades feeling janky to use.

[h3] THE ENVIRONMENT AND WORLD BUILDING [/h3]

The environments in Black Mesa have been expanded upon, giving them a much more lived in environment, as well as selling the seriousness of the alien invasion more. A lot of the friendly NPCs were given distinct personalities to distinguish them from one another, which in turn made me feel more invested in them. And Crowbar Collective clearly knew everyone hated On A Rail, because they rightfully shortened that chapter, while making others longer, especially Xen, but that will get its own section. Overall, I love most of the changes that were made... Interloper is still a pain in the ass, though.

[h3] THE MUSIC [/h3]

Joel Nielsen did an excellent job with the sound design and soundtrack. The music ranges from fitting ambience, sad melodies, and action-packed rock and/or metal tracks when the need arises, while Xen has its own take, with the angelic choirs. Also shout out to his wife and her ass, for providing some of the "sound effects" in the game.

[h3] XEN [/h3]

For most Half-Life fans, Xen was always the most disappointing part about the OG. Not Black Mesa. After 5 years of just working on Xen, it came out perfectly. Black Mesa's Xen is absolutely beautiful and much longer, having its own ecosystem, as well as labs set up, showing that the science team was there before. Gonarch's Lair in particular easily became my favourite chapter of Black Mesa.

[h3] THE PAIN [/h3]

Black Mesa is almost a perfect slam dunk, but there are some things that drag it down. Interloper has WAY too much platforming, and it honestly felt like it was overstaying its welcome. The hardest achievements in the game? The hat and pizza ones? Suffering. Ignoring the fact, that it was absolutely painful to drag those through Xen, if you also try to grab the hat/pizza and immediately start running afterwards, you just drop them. You need to wait a good two seconds before you start sprinting, which can be difficult, if you're being chased by a Gargantua or Gonarch. Also, for some reason, in Interloper the hat decided to ignore the laws of physics and flew all the way into the sky box, just to add some more pain into the mix. Thankfully, this is mostly a perfectionist's pet peeve, and most people won't even go for these achievements.

Overall, I give Black Mesa a 9.5/10. The 0.5 point deduction was due to the achievement pain. If you're a fan of Half-Life, or a newcomer to it, I'd highly recommend. The Crowbar Collective are incredibly talented.

Incoherent thoughts ensue: 

Somehow Surface Tension feels like it drags on for less than usual but it's still a slog, nevermind with the harder military grunts. A lot of mixed feelings on the lighting obscuring buttons/levers/valves up until Lamba Complex, particularly in Power Up. Changes to places like On A Rail (one of my favourite chapters) are understandable, but it also makes navigating them more of a joke, the atmosphere is impeccable but it feels like the level design in that chapter is patronising, instead we're just focusing on "plug this into this and unplug that" HL2-ness. Oddly enough this is done in a stellar way in Xen. Walking until We've Got Hostiles feels nice and moody/atmospheric, then you just hope you don't get hit by a shotgunner/grenade/pinpointed by something. Thankfully ammo and health are plentiful so restocking is not an issue (especially for HL1's fall damage at times), but I also don't want Gordon to be feeling like a battered walking tank. As much as the game wants to be accessible in places like Blast Pit and the aforementioned On A Rail, then it throws buttons that can't be unpressed and cause a soft lock if you know, you're taking your time in the nicely looking atmospheric action-and-sometimes-platformer. Which again makes it so wild that Xen, completely remade, is just done basically flawlessly. I really like HL1 except for Surface Tension and the Alien Grunt spam in Lambda Complex, and considering how long these pre-Xen chapters have been out for I'm surprised that they've mostly been downgraded and stretched out in their re-imagination at about the Blast Pit/ post Blast Pit point. The "press buttons until it works" in Residue Processing or "I guess violence is the answer" in Questionable Ethics is also weird. Also what's up with the buttrock OST that requires you to also play with subtitles because the audio mixing is absolutely horrendeous (again, the Xen OST is really well done, I cannot stop gushing over the atmosphere and at times ImSim-y done platforming and puzzle progression). "Gordon, you saved us, but you got ambushed, can you hear us over the buttrock? Gordon! Come in!". I guess no bulletsponges are a welcome sight for Hard playthroughs as a positive note to end for. 

I am very mixed on this package but it is ultimately a recommendation with many caveats, just play HL1 on anything but Hard mode, then play Black Mesa Xen. We've got a well done atmosphere, puzzle solving, platforming, chase scenes, the whole thing.

Black Mesa is a fan-remake for the Half Life game from 1998 with improved graphics,new areas and some bits of story changed  but with the same original atmosphere . The question is should you play the original or the remake? 

The answer is different for everyone ,it's up to you to decide. For me it was simple ,i went for the remake for more content and better graphics. Made with Half-Life 2's Source engine,this was the perfect foundation for me to start a entire Half Life series playthrough. It's amazing Black Mesa is allowed to be sold as a standalone game, Valve earned a lot of respect and popularity from gaming community because of this. 

To be honest Black Mesa was my guilty pleasure to delve into the Half Life universe,a perfect excuse to try an old title for the first time and a perfect introduction to Half life 2. 

What stands out from the original game is the final chapters of the remake for me. The Xen section and some boss fights are on another level of quality and design and some areas are completely new. The visuals are breathtaking ,you just don't expect something like this from a Half Life remake. 

Experiencing the story for the first time was beautiful,it's sad they don't make games like this anymore. The multiplayer lobby most of the time are empty but from time to time you'll find some people to play with.

In my opinion this is a must-play ,if before people like me had an excuse to skip the Half Life 1,with Black Mesa remake it's almost mandatory.

I did not enjoy my time playing this game.

And that's sad, cause I really wanted to. I never played Half-life when it first came out. Everyone has always told me how amazing it and the sequel were. I thought this would be a fine way to get into it.

It wasn't.

The settings menu was a mess. 
The sound mix was off from the start. For some reason the noise made by the icons in the game's menu is THE loudest thing on the face of the earth. Unfortunately, unlike many games these days where sound settings are divided into 5-6 bars you can balance separately this only has 3 (Master, Effects, Music). Which isn't really enough when I'd like to hear characters speak but also wouldn't like to lose my hearing if I need to navigate the menu.

Even when you do get things the way you like them, you'd better take a pic as the settings menu will forget what you set it to when the game closes and reloads. 

First person platforming. 
Who? Who in the history of the WORLD thought first person platforming was a good idea?
IT'S NOT! First person platforming is not fun! And there's one chapter in this game that's practically ALL platforming from start to finish. It's NOT challenging, it's NOT fun and it's NOT interesting, It's just a tedious slog.


I like the weapons.
I DON'T like how cumbersome switching between them is. This is especially painful when you're in the midst of a firefight with a dozen scumbag soldiers and 3 of their near-omniscient turrets that can hit you a mile away if you so much as show a hair.

Again, I really....really wanted to like this game. But after 9 hours I just want my time back.
I think the worst part of all this is that I can see a really cool game here. The game I heard so much about. A game with a nice story, look, and action. But what's here is just not good enough to offset the negatives.

Perhaps there's a combination of mods that effectively assassinate these flaws. Maybe in the future, I'll look for some and perhaps give this game another go.

But for now, I'm done. It's just not fun.
