Black Mesa takes everything that was good about the original Half-Life and turns it up to 11, while expanding the later Xen levels such that they unexpectedly become a highlight of the game. Overall, it's not just a case of the visuals being spruced up, but also the first-person action feels more intense and immersive, the platforming feels more reliable, and the character animations are much better. Would I recommend playing the vanilla Half-Life before this? Probably yes, considering it's available cheaply these days and has continued to receive updates, and discovering the revelations Black Mesa brings to the table afterwards feels great. But if you liked Half-Life and are a fan of FPS games in general you owe it to yourself to try this out regardless.

Black Mesa, from my POV, is Half Life 1, but redone the same way CAPCOM remade ResE 2/3.

Same source engine, (mostly similar) game. The gameplay is similar to how HL1 did it, you can either run around screaming, shooting everything, or play smart and plan. The main idea of HL1 still there and you can tell tons of effort was put into keeping the core elements of HL1 intact while also changing some things say Xen being completely remade while keeping the same timeline.

Played this game in 2023 for the first time and enjoyed almost every second of this game (sometimes more then I would with a new triple A game). 

Negatives: 

- Even though they reworked the last chapter, which looks so much better than the original, it still doesn't feel great to play and feels a like a bit of a slog (especially on second playthrough). 

- I had to do some serious re-routing of the button layouts in order to play this with a controller, I was able to find good settings eventually but it took a while to set-up and get right and I feel this could have been streamlined a bit more. 

- Long loading screen (which I'm willing to ignore a bit seeing as this game is clearly a labour of love)

Positives:

- This game gives you freedom in ways that lots of modern games fail to understand

- The environmental story telling is really on point and I love how it's always clear where to go without any map or character blatantly telling you where things are. Everything is clear without long text to read or conversations that go on.

- Exploring the areas is lots of fun and very rewarding

- The original game was ground-breaking, and the renewed graphics of this game make it possible to re-live a piece of history that inspired so many game, and does it in a very pleasing way.


So, all in all, even with the negatives I would definitely recommend this game.

Amazing re-make of my favourite game of all time. The best way to experience Half-Life.

Black Mesa is popular for a reason, it is an amazing recreation/reimagining of the original Half-Life. The project took more than one and a half decade, but the final product is one of the best Half-Life related media, in my opinion almost rivaling Half-Life 2 and it's episodes. 

The game runs on the Source Engine, but it is one of the best looking game using the engine, and you probably wouldn't realize by just looking at it that it uses a 20+ year old game engine. Although the Source Engine jankiness and physics appear sometimes, just to remind you how much work has been put into this game, to have it look like this. Black Mesa doesn't replace the original Half-Life as some things were done differently. The biggest difference is the Xen part, I personally hated that part of the original game, and I still don't like it to this day, but in Black Mesa it is one of the many highlights of the game. Xen looks gorgeous, and the music elevates it's beaty even more. The music is also one of the parts that Black Mesa does much better. 

All in all Black Mesa feels like what the original Half-Life would have felt like, if it was made in the second half of the 2010s. Everything feels polished and has comforts that modern games provide. 

With all the graphical improvements comes greater system requirements. The Source Engine was streched to it's limits with Black Mesa, and it can be felt sometimes. I haven't played it with my new GPU, but my RX480 had a bad time with the game from time-to-time. I never dropped below 60 on the highest settings tho. The Blue Shift remake is even worse from this stand point, as it was literally killing my GPU sometimes for no obvious reason. 

All in all I cannot recommend this game enough for the fans of the Half-Life series.

A beautifully crafted game, THIS is what a Remaster should be, not whatever the sorry excuse Bethesda and FromSoft call a remaster. If these guys remaster the Opposing Force and Blue Shift, they could easily rekindle the love the internet once had for Half Life. If they ever get to HL2 and it's episodes, then I think Valve may just find the team to create Half Life 3. Easily worth every cent off-sale.

I bought this game thinking it was an entirely NEW game focused on the Black Mesa complex like Opposing Force or Blue Shift.

When I started playing I quickly realised it was the original Half Life 1 just with slightly better graphics. I was disappointed at first but found myself slowly falling back in love with one of my all time favourite games from way back.

Upon completing the Black Mesa storyline and being teleported to the alien homeworld I was excited to finish an old classic and put it to rest with more pleasant memories.

** However, to my dismay, the game didn't end. **

The alien planet was seemingly redone and was now another 12 hours of ridiculously tedious jump puzzles and brain teasers.
There were bare fragments of attempted lore from the alien side which you could piece together or miss completely, all the while the Vortigaunts are constantly mumbling the same line, over and over in your ears without adding anything extra.

Yes, you CAN kill them but I'm not a monster (you can figure it out pretty quick they're not evil).

Honestly, I almost quit playing, multiple times during this waste of time but I hate to leave a formerly great game unfinished. It just kept dragging ON and ON and essentially ruined the enjoyment I collected from replaying the original story.

If I could go back, I would not have purchased this remake and left a fond memory just the way it was.
What a shame.

Being a PC player since Spectrums, somehow in all these years I've never played a single Half-Life game. Yeah I knew it's a must and a milestone and all that, I realized the scale of effect it had on modern world PC gaming and yet it never occured to me to play it.

And yet, now that I play it, I am AMAZED at how addictive a game without microtransactions, skins, journal of side quests, hot waifus and such, can be. I just can't stop playing it. It feels like I'm back to my home town to meet my best friends that I've been friends with my whole life, only in this case I've only met this friend a few days ago. The game manages to be subtle about its gameplay and only push the "hell yeah" button in rare moments that truly deserve it. It doesn't have neither the "story mode" nor the "nightmare difficulty" but it doesn't treat me like a baby. It somehow manages to switch between the puzzle, the platformer and the shooter modes without being blatant about it and I only realize I'm at the puzzle stage when it's almost over so I never get frustrated over overextended sections of gameplay.

Would I recommend this game to other players? Hell yeah. Three days ago I was looking for a top-notch 2023 shooter that would make my GPU melt but here I am hitting headcrabs with a crowbar and having the time of my life.

I loved Half-life 1 and 2 so I was quite excited to try Black Mesa. I just finished the game and wanted to share my impressions. 

Positive points:
- The reproduction of Black mesa is really well done, a lot of details and animations, as a HL fan it is just a pleasure to re-discover the environment done with the source engine 
- First part of the game follows almost perfectly HL1 and is quite smooth 
- I really enjoyed the action during the game, the game is quite dynamic and the fights with enemies are quite fun
- The Xen world is just amazing, I think just for that part the game is worth it
- The musics were overall quite good

Negative points:
- I had an issue with the flashlight that was not working properly for most part of the game, very annoying in dark places, it is to me a critical issue as it could block many players from advancing.
- Some issues with the textures 
- The Xen part felt extremely long and repetitive with too many puzzles, you spent most of the time connecting cables
- Not always easy or obvious to know what to do or where to go, maybe it is an issue to know HL1 so well as I was most of the time thinking to solve puzzles in the same way but the solution could actually be diffrent in Black Mesa
- Music sometimes a bit too loud

I would like to give a big thank you to the community and to the developers for the amount of work put into the game, I had overall a great experience.
Then I would probably recommend this game for Half life lovers, for the others I would recommend to first start with the original which is simply a master piece.

Not even just FPS games, though it's insanely important to the entire genre for being one of the first to not be arcadey (a-la Doom or Quake) and to merge a coherent story with gameplay to make a whole experience. Before, you'd get a text crawl if you're lucky, or else you'd just have to go to the manual. Or there'd be Cutscenes. The game itself is a masterpiece in almost every way, so in 2005 or so, a group of crazy people wanted to remake the entire thing in the source engine (as opposed to Gold Source which was built off the quake engine) and the results we have are Black Mesa.

What can you say about a game that so lovingly recreates a game like Half-Life. It doesn't change what made Half-Life good, even keeping in jank like crouch jumping and other similar quirks of the source engine. It looks and plays like a dream. It follows the game to the letter but sprinkles in some added stuff to make it stand out in a way. The biggest addition is the expansion of Xen, which I'm torn about. On one hand, it feels great and looks beautiful. You can see how much effort into making the alien world look as breathtaking as it does. It's long enough to feel like it's own game separate from the rest of running around Black Mesa. On the other hand, it still kinda has the same problems Xen had, that being that it's not really a satisfying conclusion to running around the Black Mesa compound. Making it longer just has the same issue.

Another issue i had was getting it to run. It gave my dang 3060 ti a run for its money and i was chugging a lot at some spots. Particularly during the outside segments and some parts in Xen. Granted, i was playing on the highest graphics but still, be weary.

Overall, i would say to play the original Half-Life first, but don't skip over this if you're a fan. It's a 15 year love letter to one of the most important games ever made. You can feel it in every inch of the game. Cant wait for them to remake it in Source 2 now in another 15 years.

Great game

Positive: 
- Fantastic job in the design of the world/areas. Large open spaces with great atmosphere.  
- The sounds are well done, and the music is good. 
- The story is well done. 
- Puzzles that make you pay special attention to details, leaving you to really have to think. 
- Fun combat. 
- Including some of the best sci-fi worlds in all my gaming experience. 

 
Negative:
- Walking is rather fast.  
- Controller does not automatically work. *Remember to select a controller profile through steam.  
- No navigation radars.  
- Controls are fine but there are drawbacks to using controller such as weapon changes where you must use a keyboard for over two items. 
- No objective menu, so you had better pay attention to hints.  
- Some parts are hard for anyone with sensitive vision (screen vibrating). 
- Enemies are not always very memorable. 


 Conclusion:

Black Mesa really took me off guard. Despite a few challenges, most of the game was quite well done. At one point, I thought it had reached a satisfying ending, but it was solely a primer to what was about to unfold.  

The environments in the last few levels were some of the best I have ever experienced in Sci-Fi gaming. They were magnificent and majestic with some parts being gloomy, translucent and organic. I can still hear the sounds and almost feel the unique atmosphere. A+  

I had frustrations getting the game set up but in the end it was fine. I also had a moment where I felt the game had ‚Äústopped being fun‚Äù, which was related to one challenging puzzle. Apparently, I am not the only one with this experience. *It may just be a controller issue. 

Putting aside my complaints, this is a must play title for any Sci-Fi FPS fans. 

 

RECOMMENDED  9/10

Black Mesa is a comprehensive remake of Half Life 1. The story, progression and gameplay, remain the same but all the assets are new and the maps have been modified. The original used an improved Quake 1 engine (1998). The Source engine version used (2013), obviously allows for vastly improved graphics, animations, facial expressions, AI, physics, more expansive maps and gameplay features such as more NPCs and carrying items. Almost certainly many of the improvements were desired by the devs of original game but not possible to implement due to engine and hardware limitations.  The 75% of the game that occurs on earth has mostly been left intact. The devs did alter most of the maps to varying degrees in order to improve gameplay. But this is debatable. For instance, they reduced "on a rail" and altered object placement so that the cause and effect of some puzzles could be immediately correlated . But maybe "on a rail" was meant to be long and tedious, and I found it gratifying to do something, then backtrack some distance to observe the result of my action, as in the original game. Nevertheless, the earth part is cohesive with seriously engaging gameplay and recognisably HL1.  

Where the devs really exercised their design chops is in the Xen parts. In implementing their vision of the border world, they kept the original four chapters, but these are (much) longer, more expansive, more expository, and more detailed. Xen was rushed and incomplete in the original (the HL1 devs talk about this in the HL1 25th anniversary documentary). Crowbar Collective also consulted the original game's Xen design spec (much of which was left out in HL1). The result is a breathtakingly beautiful and immersive border world, a pleasure to play through, explore and discover, and a natural extension of the game, probably closer to the original vision, all accomplished whilst not exceeding their poetic license.   
 
No game is perfect. HL allowed backtracking in most of its chapters, something I appreciate and enjoy. So the levels where this is artificially prevented (unexpected rockfalls blocking an exit, lifts whose buttons frizz out when the destination is reached) break the suspension of disbelief and degrade the experience. Unless forced due to an engine limitation, I really wish this wasn't implemented, even if it is just mimicking the original game (with a vastly less capable engine). The same goes for fleshed-out rooms with locked doors. Let us in if doesn't break gameplay! I don't care if this is done so that players don't get lost and confused; games of this era didn't hold your hand much. My other bugbear is that some of the puzzles in the Xen level were not intuitive.  Even when demonstrated in a walkthrough, I didn't see how the player was meant to discern the solution. 

Audience #1: Want to replay Half Life
BM is the obvious choice. You get to experience the environments and events of the research facility again, just in a more detailed, realistic environment, with more NPCs and interactions. The iconic story, progression and core gameplay remain the same (in fact, gameplay has been enhanced; I don't recall being able to physically carry items, including excess hand- and gun-grenades, in HL1, and use items as weapons by throwing them at enemies). Foregoing the massive improvements of the remake in order to indulge in the pure nostalgia of the original version (even the 25th anniversary edition) is too high a price.  I was in awe of BM's graphics and stunning vistas, and the outdoor map sizes have increased significantly,  and that's before Xen.   You will not experience the border world as it was originally-intended, and will miss out on a hugely improved experience of it, if you don't experience Black Mesa.

Audience #2: Played HL1, undecided if it's worth replaying it in the BM version.
Yes, it is! This is me. I played HL1 years ago, and have no hesitation in recommending that you experience it again, in this version. And did I mention Xen?

Audience #3: haven't played Half Life.
Half Life is seminal. A fps gamer not having played through it is a contradiction in terms. If you want the 1998 experience, play the 25th anniversary edition (it's close enough). After which you'll fall into audience category # 1 or #2.  If you're not a purist, go straight to Black Mesa. And if you haven't played any of the Half Life series, BM leads you seamlessly into HL2 (and yes, HL1 or BM is a prerequisite for HL2). 

To summarise, Black Mesa is a stunning and refreshing remake of Half Life, and probably closer, in parts, to the vision of the HL developers. I recommend it as the default version of a seminal and compulsory fps experience and regard it as a necessary HL2 prerequisite. And as I discovered, it's well worth reliving the events in the research facility and the border world through the eyes of the Crowbar Collective.

Edit 1: The two major changes are the massive expansion and graphical tour-de-force of Xen. There seems to be very little disagreement that this is an improvement over the original. I am more ambivalent, however, about the chopping of "on a rail", wondering if this wasn't exceeding their artistic license. I understand the devs motive (they felt it was way too long), but in retrospect I would rather it was included. After I finished the definitive edition, I subscribed to "the definitive on a rail uncut" (OaR uncut & the loop mod) in the steam workshop and thoroughly enjoyed playing through it. According to the OaR uncut  dev it is not finished, but I was but I found no errors, other than I could not continue with the next chapter once I'd completed it.  I absolutely recommend it.

If you life Half-Life, you‚Äôll love Black Mesa. Everything Half-Life does, Black Mesa does better, and it‚Äôs incredible. And if you didn‚Äôt really enjoy Half-Life, Black Mesa is a major improvement on Half-Life in just about every regard, so I‚Äôd recommend giving it a shot.

It should be noted that Black Mesa is a remake of Half-Life, not a remaster, and some people don‚Äôt like that. They just want Half-Life but with actually decent HD models, which is fine, but if that‚Äôs the expectation you go in with, prepare to be disappointed. The music is different, the maps have been changed (some areas are significantly different), the NPCs have more lines, and of course, Xen has been completely reimagined. Basically all the changes are for the better in my opinion, but if you‚Äôre a purist, you have been warned.

I will admit that I was not the biggest fan of Joel Nielsen‚Äôs score at first, but it has certainly grown on me, particularly the Xen soundtrack. Another change I was not fond of at first was the HECU, as being Combine-based, they are far more intelligent and formidable a foe than the Half-Life HECU, and they are present in far greater numbers than in Half-Life. But as I kept playing, I came to realize it was actually a great decision: because it‚Äôs so much harder (even on Easy), they actually feel like, well, Marines ‚Äì a well-trained, professional fighting force that seemed to be able to handle just about anything, at least until they met the inhabitants of Xen...

And speaking of Xen, I cannot understate just how much I love Xen in Black Mesa. In Half-Life, it felt unfinished, and Interloper in particular just felt like a massive slough for no good reason that really made you worry about your ammo. Then the Nihilanth battle happened and it was just annoying with all the teleports. It felt anticlimactic, which was especially ironic given G-Man's lines after you beat it.

Black Mesa's Xen, by contrast, actually feels lived in, like a real place. Rather than a place that‚Äôs been explored by a few unfortunate souls, it‚Äôs got an entire research outpost for their deep incursions into the territory. Gonarch is actually challenging and kinda scary, Interloper is still a slog but an interesting slog with some really fun areas where you get to go ham with the Gluon Gun like a classic boomer shooter power-trip level (Half-Life‚Äôs dearth of ammo for the Tau and Gluon meant I rarely used either, and they never really got their time to shine as a result), and it‚Äôs also gorgeous. Plus, the Nihilanth battle is both stunning and difficult, even after you learn the "easy" way to kill him for the [i]Late for Work[/i] achievement.

Another thing I enjoy about Black Mesa is that it actually encourages the use of the entire loadout. In Half-Life, you could get through the entire game with the MP5 and shotgun, but Black Mesa‚Äôs strategic ammo placement basically forces you to use everything, and I enjoy that a lot. They all deserve a time to shine, and Black Mesa is very careful about encouraging just that.

One of my favorite things about Black Mesa is its attention to detail. Obviously, Half-Life set the bar quite high in this regard, but Black Mesa went above and beyond, particularly in its environmental storytelling. Having read a fair amount about Half-Life‚Äôs development, some of the biggest challenges they faced were the limitations of both GoldSrc and the hardware of the era, and I think Black Mesa really takes advantage of both Source and modern hardware to amplify the original story of Half-Life.

Take the HECU‚Äôs chatter ‚Äì in the original, there were only a few areas you heard the grunts say much outside ‚Äúsquad, report in,‚Äù ‚Äúsquad, get Freeman,‚Äù ‚Äúsquad, stay alert,‚Äù etc. But in Black Mesa, there are lots of places you get to hear the HECU talk amongst themselves, and it really humanizes them and makes you feel bad with how badly they get routed, especially since you get to see how good at fighting they are. In Half-Life, during Surface Tension, I was like, ‚Äúfuck yeah, the military is screwed!‚Äù In Black Mesa, by contrast, I was like ‚Äúoh fuck, the military is screwed‚Ä¶‚Äù

And speaking of screwed, one of my favorite details of Black Mesa is in its radio broadcasts. Radios are an underrated indirect exposition device in my opinion, and if you‚Äôre just rushing through, you‚Äôll miss most of them, but Black Mesa includes several radio broadcasts from both the military and civilian side which are entirely original and they are honestly chilling.

In Office Complex, Blast Pit, and Surface Tension, there are civilian radios broadcasting emergency alerts, and it does a great job of communicating just how utterly screwed humanity is. It starts out as a 75-mile evacuation order by local authorities for an unknown disaster, which soon expands to a 150-mile evacuation order by the state government that lists out symptoms of radiation exposure (since they were still trying to cover up the incident), but by the time you get to the end of Surface Tension...

[quote][EAS sign-in tones] The following message is transmitted at the request of the United States Department of Defense. This is not a test.[/quote]

At this point, the DoD is ordering the entire state to evacuate, the president has declared a national emergency and acknowledged the true nature of the disaster, and they are asking anyone with a gun to help with the fight because the military is so hopelessly overrun. That broadcast was genuinely frightening (the only time I‚Äôve felt that way from a video game), and it really drives home just how bad things have gotten, and a harbinger of what‚Äôs in store for the rest of the world.

It makes me wonder why more games don‚Äôt use the Emergency Alerts System like this. Those tones are designed to be unsettling and attention-grabbing, and you can lay down some truly devastating exposition with them.

Follow this up with a grunt asking for help while bleeding out over the radio shortly thereafter, and I was in tears.

Overall, having played this game multiple times through and having earned every achievement, I only have a few minor complaints:

[list]
    [*]The native Linux build is trash so I have to use the Windows build under Proton, which tends to crash a fair amount.
    [*]Some of the captions have minor deviations from the lines and some captions do not consistently trigger (e.g. breaking the window on some doors only results in a glass breaking caption when done from one side).
    [*]Interloper should be tightened up, like On A Rail.
    [*]Some of the achievements are a bit buggy. For example, I had to redo Interloper multiple times before it acknowledged that I had, in fact, earned [i]Laser Immunization[/i].
[/list]

The story of Half-Life 1, but with everything I love about the Source engine and the enthusiasm of the Half-Life fanbase. And it has achievements. It's a remake so good I play it more than the original.

With that being said, [b]this game is graphically intensive[/b], even on decent computers. It runs on the same game engine as Half-Life 2, a game that performs perfectly fine on most of today's computers, but Half-Life 2 was released 20 years ago. Black Mesa has very high resolution textures in comparison, and there's usually a lot more things happening on screen at any given time (volumetric fog, lots of dynamic lights, clouds of particle effects, enemies gibbing everywhere, more models to render, more post-processing filters, etc). While the game is gorgeous on max settings, not everyone can run their graphics that high without getting random frame drops, especially in Xen.

If anyone has performance issues, you can try turning your graphics settings all the way down, [b]except for the model and texture quality, which should both be set to at least Medium if you don't want to play Half-Life: Source all over again.[/b] You can also try going to the executable file and checking the box labeled "disable fullscreen optimizations." From what I can tell, it helps everything run a bit smoother, with the only drawback being that any text on-screen may not look quite as sharp as it did before.
Needless to say play this game. Either the old school Half Life 1 or this truly masterful remake. Either way you will not be disappointed.

I think this game is worth playing.
In hearing that, you may be confused as to why I would then deem the game "not recommended." Really, it's for attention.
Obviously, if it was really between playing it and not playing it, you should play the game. Black Mesa is very cool, and at times it is definitely very fun. The developers clearly loved the original Half Life and you can feel their passion oozing from every corner. However, there are so many things holding this game back, that while my overall experience was still positive, I can't help but think about what this game could have been instead of what it is.

Let's start with my first gripe, which is the smallest. The game is generally very dense with content, and different things that you will encounter and have to deal with. However, once you get to Xen, the game suddenly becomes a walking simulator which spans several hours. I found myself becoming bored with all the walking and platforming that you must do, and especially sections like the incredibly long conveyor belt section went on way too long and more than overstayed their welcome. But thankfully, movement suddenly becomes a lot more fun once you get to Xen, which helps this "walking simulator" section a little, though it still tends to be tedious.

Secondly, some of the puzzles are too vague. There were [i] several [/i] instances where I got stuck on a puzzle, wandering aimlessly for several minutes until I stumbled upon the solution. Granted, I never had to look up a guide, but there was a lot of the aforementioned aimless wandering until I figured out what the game wanted me to do. Some mechanics were very poorly explained to the player, if at all. Some more clarity would do the game wonders.

Thirdly, the crashing. I lost count of how many times the game would randomly crash for no reason, and near the beginning of the playthrough, it would wipe all my settings to default and force me to set them all over again. This is borderline unacceptable, especially for this game being nearly 4 years old with these issues not being fixed. It may mean having to fight Source Spaghetti, but again, no game should EVER have to deal with crashing during [i] completely normal gameplay. [/i]

Now, fourthly, and most egregiously, the combat. Now, this game has lots of different weapons, and definitely encourages being creative when it comes to encounters what with the limited ammo. However, the enemy AI in this game is some of the worst I've ever seen. The soldiers are the worst offenders by far - their reaction times are quite literally instant, they can see you through walls, and they have nigh perfect aim. Most other enemies also have pseudo-aimbot or are heavily affected by RNG, making it essentially impossible to not get hit. Certain enemy AIs are also incredibly sporadic in how they move; particularly the dogs and female soldiers. They lack any sense of momentum and change speed / direction on a dime, making it impossible to predict them and completely breaking immersion. It's perfectly okay to have fast enemies, but again, they need to have believable momentum. Certain sections of the game make it feel like getting hit is the intention, or that it being impossible to not get hit is okay because there are health pickups scattered about. But a player should never be encouraged to take damage, and it should always be realistically possible to use skill to avoid damage, because otherwise it is quite literally unfair. Designing a combat system where the player is expected to become complacent with taking damage is incredibly silly. And keep in mind, these complaints aren't coming from either of the harder modes. These are things I gathered from playing on normal mode. If normal mode combat is unfair and undodgeable as is, how can I be expected to realistically complete - and especially have fun playing - the harder difficulties? The abundance of health pickups will only work as a band-aid fix up to a certain point.

And that's everything I've got to say, for now. Again, this game is definitely cool and worth playing, and the developers clearly cared about the product they were crafting. But there were so many things that I found wrong with the game, it was very frustrating at times. This game is almost 4 years old; with it being so flawed after so long, I would hate to have experienced it at launch. But I really hope this project isn't dead in the water; I would be over the moon if the developers could create more patches and continue to fix issues, and possibly even address some of my points. This is a definitive, near-perfect way to experience Half-Life. It tweaks the game in the right places and preserves the bits that made the original work. The free Zen area, which was the weakest area in the original Half Life game, looks gorgeous and is 1,000 times more interesting. It has a more than reasonable price tag. What more do you want aside from absolute perfection?

More details:

The thing to remember about this game is that it's ¬£15.00. So we're talking an extra story pack DLC sort of price.

Pros:

- Things that made the original great like the physics puzzles and variety of gameplay is still there. In some cases, it's actually refined and there's more of them

- Although Zen isn't perfect, it's actually a substantial addition for the asking price with lots of interesting world-expanding ideas. The developers clearly knew what Zen was meant to be and it was a joy to explore, look at and do the new puzzles.

Neutral:

- Graphics. This is tough. The actual objects look freakin' awesome. Just look at the screenshots... but the engine is old and holds back some animations slightly. For the price, it's fine.

Cons:

- Engine for a 2020 game is outdated, so the physics could be better but it's not awful

- One or two uninteresting new areas. Sadly, one is on the new Zen area even though Zen is overall a substantial improvement.

The true definition of both a remake and a remaster. Takes all the best aspects of OG half life and preserves them while simultaneously improving on the insane negatives from the original and giving EVERYTHING a fresh coat of Source textures. While I do recommend you get it, be wary of the fact that many of the settings are rather taxing on hardware so make sure you tweak them the first few times you boot up the game.

(Reviewed on hardest difficulty)

In short, buy if you want more HL2.
It's pretty good from a gameplay perspective until the more annoying segments of Xen.
The choice to cut content (On a Rail) and then drag out other parts (all of Xen) is a strange and a downside to me.

Bugs and glitches- Source jank is not completely eliminated and sometimes walking through prop-strewn areas will send the player flying, or a seemingly empty area will be impassable.
Occasional deaths will result in a CTD, ex during the assassin arena fight.
Some scripted sequences have issues, for example standing back and watching a zombie crawl out from a hatch in Unforeseen Consequences allowed me to kill it, but after a reload being close to the sequence rendered the enemy invulnerable. Similarly, some set-piece animations are unavoidable and play even when they make no sense, eg an MG nest being blown up despite my having removed the responsible HECU first, or the out-of-control tram that locks you in place even if you want to let it run and get out.

NPC wrangling can be difficult or impossible, with NPC-impassable invisible barriers in places. Enemy interactions are also reduced, with infighting no longer happening between "Nihilanth" forces and "Xen Fauna" creatures- for example Vortigaunts and Bullsquids will ignore eachother and work together vs the player. Not yet confirmed whether headcrabs follow this behaviour too.

Enemy placement also suffers from a lack of care, for example in an ambush during On a Rail HECU will spawn in directly in view of the player, denying you the chance to snipe them from afar. Similarly, tactical opportunities are denied the player through mapping mistakes or decisions- during the rocket launch site fight, there is only one way to enter the arena, which is demarcated so thoroughly the player is not allowed to fire through fences which you would normally be able to, or break the (previously used and signposted as breakable) lock on a gate to make yourself an alternate angle of attack. The railroading obsession extends to subverting established behaviours of existing mechanics like explosive barrels and spawning enemy encounters twice (both can be seen in the Apprehension 3-crusher room, where the bullsquid will appear twice if you backtrack WITHOUT a loading screen inbetween, and if you try to use a barrel creatively to avoid the "puzzle").
Expanded map sizes make things look good, but combat suffers as a result- almost all weapons are short to mid range only, while the AI has no trouble attacking you at long range. This forces the player to make poor decisions and is balanced towards lower difficulty run-and-gun tactics.

Autosaves are made in extremely inconvenient spots such as during a firefight or seconds before death, depending on how you play.

Art direction is pretty good until Xen again- it's nothing like the original, a total reinterpretation.
There's some really excellent and immersive model/texture work, like being able to read the instructions and markings on medkits. Level design also suffers in Xen with repetitive "puzzles", over-complicated geometry and irritating platforming segments requiring manoeuvring onto very small moving parts.

Worst however is the immersion-breaking inclusion of modern elements to set dressing in a game depicting the 00s- the concept of "boosters" didn't exist until 2020 and seeing those posters really took me out of an otherwise excellent experience. I play videogames to get away from current affairs and want none of it in my escapism.

Of additional concern is the apparent inclusion of spyware to the game- having the good grace to include a privacy policy about it doesn't absolve one of the issue. I'm already using Steam, isn't that enough?

This game is a bit of a mixed bag. Visually it looks great, and if they had just kept it at that, this would have been an excellent fan remaster, but instead they decided to give their own spin on Half Life and that's where they lost me. Simply deciding to cut out huge sections of the game like the chapter On A Rail because it "was confusing and too long" and then making the Xen chapters half of the game are just mind boggling decisions. As many have already pointed out, the Xen chapters are visually stunning and add a lot of depth over the original, but it gets extremely repetitive and quickly overstays its welcome. It also feels like too much of a departure from the original and is practically its own game at this point. Trying to "reimagine" such a beloved game when all the fans wanted was a next-gen graphical update was really stupid. Also the soundtrack is just awful, there were several times where I wanted to mute the music entirely. I don't want to trash this game too much since it is very impressive and it would honestly be fantastic as a free mod, but as a paid standalone game, I don't think it's worth the money, even at a discount.

Excellent game. Beautifully made, much needed, update of Half Life using the physics and game engines of Half Life 2. It's long and full of action, puzzles and changing environments. Designs is great, with some outstanding art. The long second half, in the alien world of Xen is way better than in HL but it should have been heavily edited to cut overlong, repetitious sequences. Overall, I admit I find the Xen world (in HL and Black Mesa) a bit vacuous, as the complete unreality and disconnectedness of this physics-defying world, means the writers have no plot constraints or journey logic to follow. It lacks the gritty post-apocalyptic, real-world atmosphere of HL2, which made it almost unique. Plot is pretty feeble throughout Black Mesa, with none at all in Xen, other than the basic goal to get through all the challenges to a tough boss battle at the end. For example, it's a shame that the plight of, and new relationship with, the Vortigaunts is unexplained. There is none of the engagement with characters and plot, which made HL2 so rich and memorable. But that's really a criticism of HL itself. Black Mesa is still a great game to play and definitely worth the low price.

I could have sworn I had ideas for a more elaborate review, but honestly I'm coming up blank...
Yeah I mean, it's a remake of the original Half Life, what can I say? Apparently this thing's been in development for like, 15 years or something but as far as I understand it's mostly finalised at this point?
Anyway, Half Life is, like, a [i] really [/i] old game. But it's also considered a pretty revolutionary one. Having played it, I don't really know exactly [i] what [/i] was revolutionary about it, but I guess you kinda had to be there, since it's likely a lot of the things I take for granted in games today were started there.
Now, the original Half Life had a lot of pretty great things that still hold up today, but it also had some maybe not so great things. I am happy to say that this game handles updating this classic very well. For some parts, it's pretty much Half Life HD, and that's pretty cool. Other parts have been changed and streamlined a bit where they may have been confusing or otherwise questionable, which is also pretty cool. The end, however, has seen a [i] massive [/i] overhaul, and frankly just blew me away. It's the one place where they shied away from just recreating what was in the original and instead took the ideas that were there and made them into something of their own, and I'm happy to say it turned out incredible.
If you're a fan of Half Life, then you probably didn't need to read this review to know this is a must-buy. If you're just looking to get into Half Life, this is far from a bad place to start, though if you'd rather try out the original that broke grounds all those years ago first, it wouldn't be a bad idea either. As someone who just got into the series this Summer, I opted to do the latter, and played through the entire original series before coming back to this. I think it was a good way to experience Half Life, but the choice is up to you. Honestly this game holds up on its own, but you would be missing out if you let Half Life 2 go unplayed.
This is a game that hits all the marks on what it aims to be. If you're interested at all in what's advertised, you won't be disappointed. I know I wasn't.

Im giving this game a thumbs down not because the game is shite. The game itself is amazing, a great throwback to Half Life 1 and most definately a worthy "spiritual twin brother" to it. From the Valve-worthy custom soundtracks, impactful weapons, amazing graphical updates, smarter AI (Well considering HL1 came out in 1998, I guess its no surprise that AI would've been a huge leap better. But they're still amazing even by modern standards), cute tiny quirks and easter eggs, excellent voice-acting that easily puts some "AAA" game to shame.

So why am I giving this a thumbsdown? It's because of these horribly lazy devs. Bear in mind that Black Mesa was initially avaliable since late 2011 (before official launch on moddb). That till its inception for sale on Steam, 3 years had gone by. and between its inception on steam and now, so has another 3. That's roughly 5+ years (i'm counting 5 ish because it was in its final state towards the end of 2011) with nothing but small improvements and tiny bugfixes.

Back before they released this game for sale in 2014,  I could get that because they're unpaid (eventhough they were accepting donations, of which plenty including myself have done so over half a decade ago), they couldn't work on it 24/7 like regular studios. However, i find it utterly inexcusable now that even after launching this game with Valve's blessings 3 years ago, they are still not done with the Xen levels (Xen, Gonarch's lair, interloper and Nihilanth. Also endgame mini level i suppose). This year alone in 2017, a single update. [b] ONE [/b] "update".

Honestly any of you who are still gullible to believe their lies that Xen level takes over 4+ years to develop (thats atleast 1460 days mind you) are just pathetic sheeps. I guess its so easy to look good while not doing anything. Just trickle an [i] "update" [/i] with some vaguely written words and "production proof" every couple of months and the average gamer will eat the excuse up. 

If I sound bitter throughout this post, you bet I am bitter about this. I've personally known two friends who had passed away since BM was out for the general public. And boy were they huge fans of Valve games. One in early 2016 of a skiing accident and one recently last March from accidental electrocution while bathing. 

And to those of you wanting to cite Valve's own treatment of HL3/HL2:EP3 to "defend" BM devs behavior, its differen't. I get that we may never see the light of day of HL3/HL2:EP3 from Valve because from a business standpoint, they have no incentive to do so when Steam, Dota, CSGO and virtual item market in general are significantly more profitable. In hindsight, Valve aren't lazy about it, they just don't want to make it. And i can get by that. Moreover, they have not sold us an incomplete game. Imagine if valve sold Half life 2 but it only contains 3/4 of the entire game. And even after 5+ years, that remaining 1/4 is still not finished. You see the difference now yes?

In short, I can get by with lack of motivation or lacking reasons to push foward for a product when since it doesn't make much sense from a PR (Valve are still generally considered one of the more benevolent devs out there) and financial (They're making load of money through building the E-sport scene, virtual economy and their online store platform Steam) perspective.

But laziness, that's utterly atrocious and disgusting. Absolutely disgusting practice. And to think people bash CD Projekt RED for taking 4+ years to make Witcher 3 when Black Mesa's team couldn't even pull through 4 levels (Xen, Gonarch's lair, Interloper and Nihilanth) in 5 YEARS.

edit: This negative review stays because it while the final product is practically flawless, it doesn't absolve them for being lazy for nearly TEN years ( Counting since moddb launch, and by their own admission on articles/forums over the years, coined "busy" by them despite knowing full well they took money and had no excuse after going gold on Steam) and that my friends still passed away, paying full money for a product they never got to see to the end.

Firstly, I was the right age when HalfLife came out, but did not really play it, besides one Multiplayer session with a friend. Later I  played HL2  several times and loved it. So, now Black Mesa. With the good reviews and  the need to catch up  I gave it a try.  Maybe this makes my review difficult. Because it is a remaster, I really don‚Äôt  know , what was changed. And because it is kinda a fanmade, I feel less entitled to throw shade on the makers, but I have too. It is strictly a review without a look on the original.

Playing this was a frustrating experience, most of the time. Little time it felt like a good Half Life game because of the annoyances. 
The design decisions made here, didn‚Äôt ¬¥t feel intuitive. The environment was often confusing to navigate. There were no clear objectives. No clue what to do, besides a little exposition from some npcs on the way forward.  Just advance through the level. Yes, got to the surface. Fire up rocket engine to go past an annoying enemy. Take the rail card to start a rocket. What rocket. But why? This couldn¬¥t even be considered a story. I caught myself reloading several times, because it felt like I locked myself out by not taking the right path. And then got awarded an Achievement  for taking an alternative path. But obviously I was just running around disoriented. On another note. I stopped by a radio broadcast or radio chatter in hopes for more exposition. I liked these efforts,  but overall this part was minuscule. As the protagonist with two PhDs, an HEV suit, loads of weaponry I still know less than a simple guard, who tells you where to go next., but not really why. And yes, they can go along and fight with you, but perish fast or stop at the next corner and say: This is as far as I go, Dr Freeman.‚Äú 

While trying to find clues how to kill my first boss: After unloading half of my ammo, I reckoned it is bulletproof, I strayed further and thought I skipped the fight unwillingly. After another hour running around and activating this and that I suddenly circled back to said boss and switched another switch to defeat it. Nice progress. The platforming is abominable, especially with the floaty movement. I spent over an hour and dozens of deaths in the waste disposal section looking for a way through. And when I thought I got the right way, I circle directly back to the beginning of the section. Thats not fun!!!

Enemy A.I was overly odd, often laughably bad. Marines were hitting me pinpoint from afar or shooting  through walls and boxes. Sometimes they lock themselves by shooting where I was a second ago, like a wall or vent entrance, shouting ‚ÄûHe¬¥s hit.‚Äú  One time I switched to a grenade and cooking it, while hiding behind a corner and  a Marine was shouting ‚ÄûGranade‚Äú before I even throw it in his line of sight . Same place after a reload (because of low health). Same marines fearlessly began shooting at said corner and then end blowing up themselves. On another occasion I managed to walk directly in front of marines and they didn‚Äôt  notice me at all. And their taunts are were out of place and cringe at best. Listening to marines chat could add to the story and immersion. But it was mostly idle chatter.  ‚ÄûYou got nothing. NOTHING!‚Äú Yeah, nothing to immerse me.

Weapons felt bugged too. Shotguns shots to a zombie head or a headcrab to my feet failed to register entirely, while a marine running erratically left and right was hitting me with a shotgun spread from 10+ meters (or 11yrds ;) away with every shot. Same  goes  for the  MP5. Marines can snipe you with theirs, when the recoil of your MP5  makes it a pain to shoot even on short distances.  Not to mention I never noticed a marine reloading his weapon.

Autaosave function was and is particularly annoying.  Clearly you quick save on your own, when needed. But the game makes also saves without noticing at the inconvenient of moments. Nearly every time I ended up being autoloaded in the middle of a tough fight with low health  or simply while falling to my death.

Xen, as I know, got the most remade. It was nice to look at and  I got a little environmental storytelling out of it. But really was dragged out. On one hand Gonarch boss fight could be considered intense. But  also badly designed. While getting chased by her, in some moments you see the opportunity do some damage. Too bad.  Nothing tells you, that in this particular section she simply is invincible. Oh, but later with no way out you suddenly are allowed to do damage.  At that point I didn‚Äôt care anymore.  Here the normal game loop: go there, press this button, use this switch, felt dumb, because it conveniently forwarded your progress, while it¬¥s a hostile and alien environment. Logically you cannot know what this alien switch does, but conveniently its distinguishable by a red or green colour. F*** unforeseen consequences. Here vortigaunts were stupidly unbothered by your interference in their work as slaves. In other places they actively help you. 

These overwhelming positive reviews  were written through rose tinted nostalgia glasses of our 17yo selves and how groundbreaking the original was. ‚ÄûOh, I remember this part, now it‚Äôs far better made.‚Äú  Maybe reviewed it positively solely because they appreciate the work put this remake by people, who maybe are also gamers and not developers. As we know, gamers very often make a game better.  But good intentions don‚Äôt make a good game. I can not tell you, if they made the original better. Of YOU feel so, and you liked Black Masa, i am okay with it. I can tell you, I was not satisfied playing this sorry effort at 90 percent of my playtime. At some points I wasn‚Äôt enticed to finish it particularly, when I became ware of the numerous flaws. I cannot shake the feeling,  the same gameplay with the same levels, but without being Half Life, would be far worse received. Its not a flawed masterpiece...its just bad.

Black Mesa is an awesome Half Life experience, revamping the original Half Life with far improved level and enemy design, and gameplay that feels much more fair and fluid. 

However, there are a few things that generally put me off of giving this game a third go.

The music honestly feels like a downgrade, and in choosing this modern-era version of an older game, it loses a lot of the OG Half Life charm (while still creating its own, however).

Marines and their turrets need a bit of a tone-down. Their reaction times are instantaneous and their aim is nearly perfect, neither of which were issues even in the original. It makes encounters with these enemies a little less enjoyable than they could be, although they certainly don't ruin the game.

The biggest issue with this game is the final handful of levels, those being any after entering Xen. The pacing drags to a total halt, the game preferring to make platforming puzzles and plug/switch puzzles a priority over the otherwise amazing combat. Half Life was always a part-time puzzle game, but not to the extent that it took over the helm. These levels go on for an absurdly long time and massively overstay their welcome, to the point where both times I played this game, I really felt the urge to just give up on the experience altogether.

Still, Black Mesa is, as previously stated, an awesome Half Life game and is honestly probably my favorite Half Life in the series, even if technically unofficial. Not to mention, it is the best looking game I have ever seen on this engine. For an entirely fan-made project, it is one hell of a feat.

This game is Awesome until Zen. 8/10. 

First off, play the first Halflife. The OG Halflife. You won't appreciate Black Mesa as much without that experience. (And you'll miss the Zen section of the OG Halflife after you play the Zen levels in Black mesa.)

First off. I love Halflife. I do. Admittedly, I would have to say that Halflife 1 is my least favorite of the games, but none of sequels would've existed without the first, so for that I am thankful. With that being said, This game is a remake of the original Halflife. How does it do? Well, it is definitely more visually appealing and more mechanically solid. But, Its very, very different. Some of the mechanics from Halflife 2 are present in the game. (Which I love) But It does take away from the original's formula admittedly. Also, whoever axed the train cart section, I wanna kiss you  on the lips personally. That was easily the second worst section of the OG Halflife and I'm glad Black Mesa got rid of it. With that being said, Whoever signed off on the zen levels... I want to personally gouge your eyes out. At first Zen is cool! Its so pretty and fun and the parkor, while a tad silly, is interesting! But after that, It goes downhill; quick... I get it, you had to do something to make Zen different. Zen was also a sore spot for HL1, so you didn't have much to go off of. But you took it too far with this Zen. The entire factory section was a bore. I could have lived without it. If anything, I wanted to see myself team up with Vortigaunts akin to the last few levels of HL2 and fight the Controllers and the Nihilanth and free the Vortigaunts and earn my status as "The Free Man.'' But no, Even the Gonarch fight is tedious and overly drawn out. I HATED the Gonarch fight in HL1, And I will admit I did Enjoy the Gonarch Fight more in Black Mesa, I must admit it's weird how much time we spend running from it. Lastly, The Nihilanth boss fight... Its more cinematic, I'll give it that, but it's not much of an improvement on the original. I wish the Zen levels in Black Mesa were more condensed and were shorter. The factory section did not need to be that long. Zen as a whole did not need to be that long. Other than that, This game is good. I don't want to say its better than HL1, This game is very different mechanically and structurally, but it is a good remake. its not a remaster, Its a remake. 8/10.

This game saved my life.

I am 69.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

This is a love-letter to 1998's Half-Life that somewhat brings the classic adventure into the modern era. It is a great re-imagining that mostly works and injects a new nostalgia-like excitement into the 25-year-old original. Outside of a little jankiness here and there (getting stuck on geometry, the ladders are still a problem and some crashing), if you like Half-Life, play it, it is good. 

HOWEVER, when people look back at 1998's Half-Life they tend to think the Xen chapters are weak and... they are. They are frustrating, unbalanced, and ugly. Luckily, those chapters were brief in the original game. In Black Mesa, the overhauled Xen levels are a lengthy, frustrating and monotonous slog. Without Valve's original level design as a guide, the expansion of these levels feel out of place. The initial excitement of seeing the beautifully re-imagined Xen quickly melts away as you're forced to do one PLUG PUZZLE after another. These padded out chapters completely kill the momentum of the game. Should that keep you from playing Black Mesa? Absolutely not. 

Black Mesa does do a few things right with Xen. The long jump is better, the Vortigaunts' plight is more fleshed out and the final Nihilanth battle is far more satisfying.

TLDR: Black Mesa changes and tweaks a lot of things from the original that really did not need to be changed. My biggest gripes are with weapon damage, enemy health, the pacing of some chapters, and a handful of achievements that are a slog to get. If you are playing Half-Life for the first time, you would be much better off playing the original first.

SPOILERS FOR THE ENTIRE GAME ARE IN THIS REVIEW

Black Mesa is a remake of Half-Life that tweaks the original game's mechanics, overhauls graphics and sound design, adds many new sections to several chapters, completely revamps the last few chapters of the game, and includes achievements for completionists. For a fan remake, it is a very impressive project that deserves to be celebrated as a tribute to one of the most influential video games ever made. That being said, as someone who is a huge fan of the original game (around 70 hours in the original as of writing), this remake disappointed me in several aspects. By the time I was finished with my playthrough on hard, I was glad to be finished.

The first issue I had with the game was the graphics and sound design. The environments do look aesthetically pleasing in many parts of the game and the sounds aren't annoying or intrusive, but they go for an extremely realistic look that takes away the character and charm from the original game's graphics/sound. That's not to say that realistic graphics are inherently bad, but Black Mesa lacks its own unique identity in that regard and feels generic with the exception of the Xen chapters. Most of the sections inside the facility are uninteresting, grey, and have sporadic lighting across different sections. Also, the soundtrack tries to go for a more epic vibe throughout the entire game which feels at odds with the original game's more grounded tone. The worst example for me was at the end of Blast Pit as I did not appreciate music suddenly blasting as I burned the tentacle monster. You don't need music to tell you how to feel in any important given section; that was the beauty of the original using music more sparingly.

Next, there are the changes made to damage scaling and health. Unlike the original game, Black Mesa on hard difficulty is very generous with the amount of health and suit armor you get from charging stations, and for good reason. Black Mesa's enemies can drain your health and suit armor in moments with plenty of enemies being buffed. A great example is the bullsquid, who now fires a spread shot at you instead of one projectile. This is an issue because of the numerous times you go around a corner to be greeted by a bullsquid blast to the cranium. Enemy health is also reduced, but the changes feel entirely unnecessary and makes the game completely different to play, despite there not really being much wrong with the combat mechanics in the original game. One chapter, specifically Lambda Core, replaces many of the alien grunts from the original game with vortigaunts, making most of the chapter's difficulty entirely negated by just running around and using the shotgun on everything.

The military AI is also a low point in the game's design because most of the time, they just decide to fire in the continuous direction you're in and throw several grenades at you, despite this being illogical and implying that they have infinite ammo. Rarely do they try and advance upward, which is bad because the player is left doing nothing except waiting around for an opportunity to sneak a few shots in, which isn't very fun. During one section in On A Rail, there was a point to where I waited for five minutes straight around a corner because there were six military soldiers just constantly shooting down the doorway. I eventually just decided to tank some damage because I had no other option.

The Xen chapters, while much more interesting and beautiful to go through, are also significantly longer with plenty of achievements which resulted in me spending nearly half of my playtime in Xen. Specifically, Gonarch's Lair and Interloper were elongated to include more chases from Gonarch, an abundance of plug puzzles during Interloper, and an extended stay in the factory which included dodging lasers and fighting off alien controllers. Interloper was by far my least favorite chapter in the game because it was long, tedious, and had two of the most painstaking achievements which included dodging lasers for the whole chapter and not killing any vortigaunts for the entire chapter. The chapter is hours long by itself! The Xen chapters also have you finding 64 protozoans that you have to shoot across three chapters, a Cyanogen tank you have to carry around for one chapter, and several one-off achievements that essentially make half of the achievements locked behind Xen alone. If you play the game, I would recommend just not going for achievements once you get to Xen, they're not worth it.

Speaking of the achievements, there are two achievements included that are very irritating: one involving carrying a hidden hat to the end of the game and another where you carry an open pizza box halfway through the game. I did not do these achievements because Black Mesa is significantly longer  than the original and I did not want to awkwardly carry around items through a 12 hour game twice over. I already did it for one chapter and that alone required several loaded saves.

The changes to the level design and areas are sometimes good, but I only found a couple of the chapters to be improved upon, specifically Office Complex, "We've Got Hostiles!", and Questionable Ethics. In the case of Unforeseen Consequences and Surface Tension, significant rooms are shuffled out of order and the chapters are made longer even though they were a solid length in the original. For On A Rail, they shortened the chapter greatly and removed many of the spontaneous military encounters which made the chapter engaging and exciting. Those are just a couple of examples, but if you are expecting to relive the chapters in Half-Life, you're likely in for a rude awakening.

Lastly, story elements are also missing or tweaked in this fan remake. One great example is how in On A Rail, the conversation between the two soldiers has them say Gordan is "killing marines" instead of "killing my buddies." This might seem like a small change, but it completely removes the personal touch of that scene. The Nihilanth at the end of the game is also more powerful and missing the chains it had in the original, changing it from a being something which is merely a slave to greater overlords to seemingly the one in charge, completely muffling Nihilanth's role in the greater story.

Black Mesa isn't a terrible game; if you are a fan of the original game, you can get some enjoyment out of seeing the classic stages and environments redone in high definition and seeing how the fans reimagined the scenes. Some changes are really good too, like making some cryptic puzzles in the original more obvious and making unfair sections like the snipers in Surface Tension more telegraphed and fun. My opinion is very mixed, but I gave it a negative rating because I'm curious as to why they didn't just make an entirely new Half-Life inspired game if they were going to tweak nearly every single aspect of the game other than the characters and settings.

If you do decide to play this game though, ignoring the tedious achievements near the end of the game, playing on an easier difficulty, and having sprint always be turned on are my recommendations for getting the most enjoyment out of the game (always sprint is off by default, I couldn't imagine how slow the game would be without always sprinting!).

[b]An absolutely excellent remake of Half-Life 1.[/b] 
Almost everything from the original game has been improved to such a degree that I can say for certain that this is the definitive way of experiencing it.
It's so damn atmospheric and immersive, even more so than the OG, things just have so much impact, and you're constantly with this feeling of dread and hopelessness due to literally everything being against you at every moment, with everything you have to accomplish, yet, somehow you manage to pull through and beat the odds everytime, and it's just so good.
It even has new crazy good additions, like the completely redone Xen part of the game, which is such a beautiful and vast improvement, I can't even put it into words.
I have barely anything to criticise about this, the only things that come to mind are the voice acting being a little mediocre at times and the sound design for the guns that could've been better.
But, man, this is such an amazing experience, highly recommend anyone to buy this and try it out.

This is a very good a faithful remake of the revolutionary game Half-Life, for better and worse. A couple areas where this game made some key changes beyond the graphical and engine update is the Xen levels and the music, both of which put the original game to shame. Finally, I really wish the developers didn't require you to push two buttons to jump. A phenomenal spiritual successor to a landmark title, carefully recreating the classic to suit modern standards without compromising any of the original game's quality; Which overall speaks volumes towards the passion and patience put into all aspects of its creation, with every second of its decade-plus development time well spent.

Level design and pacing through old and new are matched meticulously, and attention to detail is without question. Every voice, effect, and original music piece works in tandem for an incredible experience beyond a majority of modern-day action-adventure games.

For anyone wanting to start from the beginning of the series, coming back to experience a remaster, or curious about the recent anniversary. Nothing will set the standard of what to expect throughout every subsequent title like this faithful recreation of gaming history. 

But do yourself a favour, and choose the hat or the pizza.
Never take both.

It's the original polished Half-Life, incredibly fun combat and aggravating platforming, all included.
I really do actually enjoy the gameplay of both this and the original. I don't know if it's just me that's terrible at it, or if Half-Life is just eternally cursed to have terrible platforming. I might just be having one long Cuphead moment, but Residue Processing in both the original and this make me want to pull my eyes out of my skull in frustration. I like the visuals and design and SFX of everything I've experienced thus far, it's literally just that I can't make a jump to save my life.
Anyway, whining about platforming aside, it's very good, and I'd recommend it for the time I've spent on it.
I HOPE for a remake of the DLCs since they were also pretty dope, but I don't imagine it'll be given the green-light. Nonetheless, despite how unlikely it may be, I wait for the day when the path to paradise shall be opened.
TL;DR: 8/10, good stuff, minor complaints with platforming, plus there's a couple visual glitches and weird little things that I've noticed while playing, so it's definitely not perfect, but I'd be telling a massive lie if I said I wasn't having a good time.

Black Mesa, the Half-Life remake, offers a genuinely good experience, although my preferences still lean towards the original (non-Source) version of the game. The changes to AI behavior left me somewhat disappointed, as the original's nuances and tighter gameplay are missed.

While the remake's effort in modernizing the classic is commendable, the Xen levels, even in the original, weren't a highlight. In Black Mesa, these levels, unfortunately, drag a bit, compounding my mixed feelings about the overall experience. Despite these reservations, Black Mesa serves as a decent entry point for newcomers to the iconic series but may not fully capture the essence of the original for longtime fans. A solid effort but not without its drawbacks.

Black mesa is a great remake, the people at crowbar collective really outdid themselves, graphically wise at max setting everything looks incredible and the game is so much more detailed than the original half life. You can run the game under Proton to bypass all the issues with the Linux port. However you'll crash after a few maps loads. My theory is the game doesn't seem to free up video memory between maps, so so once you've loaded enough maps you'll fill up your video memory and the game will crash once you've run out. (AMD only issue, to my knowledge)

I managed to power through the crashes and finish the game yet again, but it was annoying beyond belief. At least my graphics card has 24GB of VRAM so I can at least load 4 maps before crashing. But it just seems like a huge joke to me that this game somehow still, is in a completely broken state on Linux. I've played for many hours on Windows, but I have since moved on from that operating system since Microsoft has made many questionable choices on their operating system over the years, and I have simply moved on from their joke operating system.

I honestly don't understand why the game continues to act like it's a completed product when you advertise Linux support. You clearly don't support it, and should simply remove that version and only distribute the Windows version. Seriously devs, play the Linux version for 20 seconds and you'll see what a broken piece of shit you have released. It's a fucking joke. 

I've thoroughly enjoyed this game since it's first release in 2012, and followed you all the way to Xen, and the definitive release. Black Mesa is a first-person shooter that‚Äôs a remake of the original Half-Life. It‚Äôs about a physicist name Gordon Freeman where there‚Äôs an experiment gone wrong where a bunch of aliens warps to their world from Xen and wreaks havoc onto the Black Mesa Research Facility. It‚Äôs up to Gordon to stop them and figure out where the source is coming from just so they won‚Äôt come to his world. This was the first video game that I played in years that I decided to return to and beat all the way through. I‚Äôve been meaning to play this because I‚Äôm a fan of the Half-Life series, and I remember this being in development for almost a decade until it‚Äôs finally released. Since I already know the story of Half-Life, I‚Äôve seen gameplay footage of the game in the facility and Xen itself where I knew I had to get it. I bought it years ago but didn‚Äôt play it due to a lack of motivation to even play video games in general where I didn‚Äôt see the point. That is until I gained over 1000 followers on TikTok where I can livestream video games where I finally have a reason to go play Black Mesa. So I set it up, played it, and absolutely loved it.

The story is relatively the same, which is still amazing. It‚Äôs relatively simple, but it gets the job done to go from point A to point B, and you‚Äôre left with the gameplay, which is the main seller of the game. The gameplay is a lot of fun that you never get tired of getting rid of the aliens and as you progress through the game, you get new weapons that look amazing in design and pack a wallop that gives off such satisfying sound effects to the weapons. My favorite weapon is the Gulon that has such an impactful beam that is an absolute delight to use that I‚Äôm glad the remake made it just as effective. The graphics are a massive improvement over the original game that I‚Äôm genuinely surprised that this is the same engine Crowbar Collective used as it was used in Half-Life 2 because of the details that you can tell they worked so hard on, and it shows.

This is probably about as challenging to play as the original, if not more so, but it never felt unfair as you have to be strategic on how you play the game against enemies that are not easy to beat. Especially when you face harder enemies in the later parts of the game that can be a pain in the ass to take care of. The score by Joel Nielsen does a fantastic job of recreating the score of the original that fits with the atmosphere of the game while also adding some new stuff that works to the game‚Äôs advantage. Especially when you get to the Xen level. My God when you get introduced to the level, not only does it feel like a different game while still keeping the Half-Life gameplay elements, but it looks so beautiful. 

When you hear the singing in the background while showing Xen at its full potential, it‚Äôs absolutely wonderful that it feels so otherworldly like you discover something on your own and cherish this discovery. While I wasn‚Äôt too fond of Xen in the original game, this was expanded like it‚Äôs nobody‚Äôs business. See with Crowbar Collective, they finished the main part of the game where you can play it for a long time, until you get to Xen, which wasn‚Äôt finished at the time. So it took years for that to be finished, and the wait was worth it. It‚Äôs a lot bigger and longer to get through where you feel the world of Xen around you that you understand why it took them so long to finish Xen. The puzzles were harder but still felt ultimately rewarding that you felt good about it. The only issue I have is that one of the Xen levels was so long to get through that it almost became a chore to beat and I just wondering how long is this level going to be. I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs terrible, it just felt slightly tedious and the enemies were becoming more of a pain in my ass. But the last part of that level was the most therapeutic part that I just felt like a God at that point. Black Mesa is one of the best remakes I‚Äôve played that I‚Äôm glad the number of years in development leading up to this that is quite an achievement.

Black Mesa is a top notch recreation of the original Half Life and was produced by a group of people, who truly put a lot of love and hardship into the project. There are way too many changes to list, so i'm going to only name the most important ones for a short overview. 

The remake adds overworked graphics including much sharper textures, new character models and better effects, revised and improved level environments (Xen just looks beautiful), enhanced gameplay including a way better weapon handling and smoother movement. You will have to overcome a good amount of cool oldschool puzzles, while listening to a very atmospheric soundtrack, that really underlines the tone of every different setpiece. 

Black Mesa enhances the original in every way possible, while also being able to preserve the core soul of Half Life. Remaking an old classic title does not always work and can lead to a completely screwed up experience for the player. Here it just worked in a phenomenal way. The people who worked on this game can truly be proud of themselves. You should really give it a try, it's 100% worth it. 

Have fun!

It is just plain awesome, has incredible graphics for the source engine and with Xen having an absolutely stunning visual style. The transformation of the maps from the original to the remake is also incredibly impressive, they really went out of their way to make it so great.

The gameplay? Expect to be much slower paced than original Half-Life but that is not a disadvantage at all, it tells the story just as great if not better sometimes and Xen... you need to play through original Xen and Black Mesa Xen to understand just how great it is. There's also built-in multiplayer though it seems most people have forgotten about it, apparently you can even play co-op with your friends too.

And then there's the soundtrack; it captivates the feeling of the world perfectly, especially the Xen tracks which just go all out on you, you'll definitely be living in the moment when you're playing through the game.

Additionally, you got the steam workshop which provides various addons on top of the existing game or flat out entire mods/modded campaigns. There might be a Blue Shift and Opposing Force remake in the future (at the time of writing this review, a team by the name of "HECU Collective" is working on remaking Blue Shift).
