Literally the worst game you could play right now. Never mix puzzle with combat. 

When you're fighting enemies, you're experiencing an adrenaline rush. In order for the game to be satisfying, the rush should slowly decay on its own, as you transition from one point to another, to then be either refueled with adrenaline, or for it to fade away completely. However, in this game, the moment you start getting an adrenaline rush, it abruptly ends in a very unsatisfying manner, while you're left there wondering how to get to more enemies. Never realizing that you entered a new puzzle. The puzzles are really annoying. The locations are like navigating a labyrinth, and combined with the confusing and unsatisfying puzzles, the whole game just starts feeling like torture. The combat doesn't help either, but it is the best mechanic in the game. That does not make it great, however.

[b]Black Mesa, a reimagining of the classic game Half-Life, delivers an exceptional and nostalgic gaming experience that feels like a refreshing journey through familiar yet enhanced landscapes. As a tech-savvy gamer, diving into Black Mesa feels like revisiting a cherished gaming era with a modern touch.

[i]Pros:
Updated Visuals: The game boasts updated graphics and enhanced visuals, revamping the environments and character models while retaining the essence of the original Half-Life, offering a fresh and immersive experience.
Engaging Gameplay: Black Mesa successfully recreates the thrilling gameplay of Half-Life, blending exploration, puzzles, and intense combat sequences that captivate players throughout the game.
Enhanced Soundtrack: The game features an updated soundtrack that complements the gameplay perfectly, enhancing the immersive experience and setting the tone for various in-game moments.
Attention to Detail: The attention to detail in redesigning levels, adding new mechanics, and improving enemy AI showcases the developers' dedication to maintaining the essence of Half-Life while elevating it for modern audiences.

Cons:
Some Pacing Issues: At times, the pacing might feel slightly inconsistent, with certain sections feeling slower-paced, potentially affecting the overall flow of the game.
Occasional Bugs: Despite efforts, some players may encounter occasional bugs or glitches that might disrupt the immersive experience.[/i]

In summary, Black Mesa excels in revitalizing the classic Half-Life experience, offering updated visuals, engaging gameplay, and an enhanced soundtrack. While it may have some pacing issues and occasional bugs, the game remains a must-play for both nostalgic fans and newcomers seeking an updated classic gaming adventure.[/b]

Don't judge a book by the cover, judge it by the hat. I could tell you so much about this allegedly wonderful game but so far I only have seen [b]The Hat.[/b] I think there were some beautiful sights on the way and this isn't even touching on Xen yet, of course as it should have, the game showed us what GoldSrc never could but it's just unfortunate for me because all I could see was [b]The Hat.[/b] I can only guess the intention the devs had on mind when they launched these primitive and uninspiring achievements to possibly ruin all the good impression that might have been of this so called amazing game. I'm sorry but in my time of dying, crying and lying to myself, [b]The Hat[/b] was all I did see in front of me. I wish but I wasn't as fortunate this time around, I wanted to enjoy the game, have fun and glaze at all the graphical advances I heard you have made but each time I threw my eye with hope I saw reflection of a clown face smiling back at me wearing that very [b]HAT[/b] on top..

[b]The Hat, The Pizza &...[/b]

You know I tried to reason but I'm only human, I only can do this much to hold it back. And when [b]The Pizza[/b] came in, I started losing it through and through. Suppose you wanted to give us an arcade, a challenge. Prolonging the hours, eh? Giving us something you somehow thought we would enjoy, I see. I don't care what the idea was, you only nullified all that impressive work you all did because all I had time and mind to care for was, you name it, [b]The Hat & The Pizza.[/b] I was too scared to lose sight of it because as we know it, this product isn't capable of sustaining itself and you can never rely on the fact that this thing costs money and it's being released on Steam, it still will crush sometimes, it will freeze and eventually crush later. All that while juggling what? Right, [b]The Hat & The Pizza.[/b] Pieces of what had left of me by that point managed to keep life in me albeit in a diminishing manner, it's at that moment that I spotted [b]The Cyanogen Can[/b] laying on the table there... I didn't want to do it anymore, the game consumed me. I totally forgot about the plot, reason and time. Felt like I was in a dream, very bad one. In hindsight I did it, but it was the ultimate worst gaming experience I ever have had, because.. Because all my life revolved around [b]The Hat, The Pizza & The Cyanogen Can.[/b] I didn't not enjoy the game, I hated it and I hated everyone who had anything to do with it. They ruined everything they worked on, to do such a gigantic job and then throw it all away on such imbecillic achievements is a feat not many can replicate. Nothing remains but the utter disappointment of what could have been and what we have gotten for a fact. You don't have even a proper mechanic for props to interact with you, to pick up and carry. It's still broken as hell. Many a texture layer isn't even physical, only visible, props go through it and get lost forever. This game is a torture, all you will ever see, do and know are [b]The Hat, The Pizza & The Cyanogen Can[/b]. F*ck you devs, just so you know, I did the achievements. Not for you to be angry, but for me to be glad. The game is a mess and it takes overlooping of special kind by special minds to not once, not even twice, but three times a charm you're adding this neanderthal challenge to this otherwise a great game. You didn't remake sh*t, you didn't revive nothing. You killed your own potential master piece with, come on kids, [b]The Hat, The Pizza & The Cyanogen Can[/b]. Hope you're happy now? It's a stinky crap!

If you haven't played the original Half-Life, or are looking to revisit the Half-Life universe, I can safely say that this fan-made remake of the original title exceeded my expectations and is an exemplary model of what a fan-made remake should achieve. While it largely sticks close to its source material, Crowbar Collective wasn't afraid to shy away from it either in an effort to improve upon the mistakes of the original title. Half-Life's universe defined my teenage years, due in part to its excellent world building, atmosphere, and gunplay. Black Mesa lives up to the standards set by Valve Software, building a world made to envelop you as you set foot in the Black Mesa Research Facility, and beyond as seen in the later chapters. As a fan, I loved exploring every nook and cranny of the research facility, there really is an admirable level of attention to detail. That being said, I think it's important to mention its faults too; I found a few chapters (notably Xen) to really drag on. Love it or hate it, this game isn't without its fair share of Source Engine jank, but to say that this title doesn't push the engine to its limits feels like an understatement. In my 20 hour journey across the BMRF, I found myself falling in love with universe of Half-Life all over again, and I owe that to the extraordinary efforts of the Crowbar Collective with this impressive remake.

Do you want Half-Life 1 with fancier graphics at any cost? This game is for you.
Do you want to experience a modernized and better polished Half-Life 1 experience? Forget it. Just download the original and use mods.

Let's start with the good thing about this game: It's really pretty. It's really nice to revisit old areas with the much better level design, and higher quality models and textures.

Now the bad. You better sit down because it's a long list. This game not only refuses to fix the old problems the original game had, but also makes some of them even worse and noticeable.

Let's start with the presentation. The devs did not think that the majority of the players of this game already played the original game to death, and the last thing they want is to sit down for 10 minutes and three loading screens and watch the annoying tram ride. And then another 10 minutes going through the labs getting your suit. Dude, we have done this a thousand times. I don't want to do this again, even with the new fancy graphics. Please, allow players to start off from chapter 3.

When the intro ended and I was ready to start smashing some headcrabs with my crowbar, here is the first disappointment. They changed the levels for the worse. You don't get the crowbar right after the resonance cascade anymore. You need to go through a ridiculous new section unarmed where you must babysit a braindead AI guard. You must use flares (??????) to light up zombies (which is very poorly done by the way) until you can find the crowbar several minutes later. Things started off bad.

The original tedious and soothing atmosphere of Half-Life received no care either. Most of the game is still dead silent and most of the audio comes from your footsteps and a few ambient sounds here and there creating soothing white noise. They could had added some new ambient music, more interesting ambient sounds to create a tense atmosphere like how Doom 3 did but nope. It was completely ignored.

When you get real combat starts, you there was no improvement at all. Today I noticed a glitch happened that allowed me to choose any chapter, so I decided to try Surface Tension and check the real combat. And for my disapointment, the marines are even more boring to fight than what I remember. Enemies are bullet sponges that poorly reacts to your attacks. Everything is exactly the same, except instead of having their own death animations, they just have generic ragdolls. Guns received no improvements and still feels dated. Games such as Left 4 Dead and Day of Infamy (also made by a small indie team with a small budget) have proven that this engine is still kicking and is capable of making great gunplay, satisfying gore, enemies that reacts realistically when being shot at. And unfortunately none of the polishment went to the combat. The bad aspects of the combat could be ignored in the original game with old graphics, but for the modern standards, they cannot. The new HD graphics makes the bad combat even more noticeable and harder to ignore.

While I appreciate the effort the devs have put to make the game look better, the things that really mattered, the real problems Half-Life 1 had, none of them were addressed, and new problems were inserted instead. And this is really disappointing. This feels more like a Half-Life 2 mod than a proper new game. It was supposed to be a remake and it feels like it came in 2010, and could already use mods and a new remaster to improve the experience.  You may notice this game has overwhelmingly positive Steam reviews. This is because all these people wanted was HL1 with better graphics, at any cost, even if the cost is making the base game worse. If this is what you want, go ahead, but this definitely not for me, I'd rather play HL1 with mods.

///////////////////////////////////////////////////

EDIT: After giving this game another try 4 years later and after several patches, my opinion still stands that this game is not fun.

Level layout is confusing. There are SO MANY doors that can't be opened. Added absolutely nothing. If you compare to the original game, most doors that cant be opened used to look visibly broken or different from ones that you can open. Here, they look all the same. Many times you will die trying to escape an Vortigaunt attacks and soldiers fire while trying to go for a door that you can't open. So many dead ends. So much pointless routes. So much pointless vent crawling. I grabbed the free version of the OG game to check if I am not being mistaken by rose tinted nostalgia glasses, and nope, the original game had none of these issues I am mentioning here.

You find out that the mappers really didn't knew how to do their jobs when you get to the freezer section early in the game. Now there is a HL2 styled puzzle of finding the missing valve for an elevator to cross the gap between vents. This wasn't here in the original game. You google "Black Mesa Freezer section" you will find out that a lot of people had problems with that. This indicates that this, and many other puzzles/areas were not added because devs wanted to improve the game experience, but just to artificially stretch the game's length and justify making this a commercial product. This adds nothing to the game. It's not fun. And most importantly, it's not necessary.

Again, the effort taken to make this is surely monumental. But the result is not something worth money.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Finished the entire game on hard. I've also played through all the Half Life 1 originals (2 extra "campaigns", from what I remember). And I've played Half Life 2 all the way through on hard. This is basically like a visual improvement of Half Life 1 of the Earth part and a remake of the Xen (alien world) part.

Half Life/Black Mesa is a game of hazards, surprise attacks, and tense FPS combat, with many various enemies in many various environments, situations, terrain, etc. It's also got a bit of "science" puzzles throughout, that you have to solve. If you're easily frustrated then you will have a hard time playing through this game, especially on harder difficulty. If you do manage to make it all the way through the game, though, you'll definitely have proven something. It's a real challenge, in many different respects, that I don't think I've experienced in any other games I've played. The storyline is somewhat compelling as well.

Just keep in mind: Be ready to save and load a lot, and die repeatedly in a couple of areas; that just comes with the nature of this game. You can be extra careful, and still end up dying a lot. You can move quickly, and die because you were moving too quickly and rushed into danger; you can move slowly, and die because you were moving too slowly to avoid harm. You can look around, and get whacked in the head by something while you weren't looking ahead; you can have tunnel vision, and something will jump out at you from the side or behind. You can conserve ammo, and lose your battles; you can expend ammo, and run out. It's all annoying, complex, difficult, challenging, hard to predict, and tense; but, that's also why I like the game, there's not really any one "right way" or "best way" to play the game. You just have to kind of learn and adapt and have a multifaceted approach to beating every type of challenge the game throws at you. Definitely pay close attention at all times (what am I missing? what do I still need to do? have I looked around for enemies? is this area safe?), and be ready for tense combat, in which you need to move, hide, run, strafe, peek, snipe, aim, shoot, reload, jump, etc., all in a few seconds.

Most of the Earth part of the campaign was more-or-less the same in this, as far as I can remember, as it was in the original. It's probably better than the original just for sheer improved graphics. The Xen part of the campaign (alien world) is like 80+% different than what I remember; it definitely resembles many aspects of the campaign from the original, but it's still different. Worth playing through, for sure, even if you played the original (and liked it). (P.S. The Xen soundtrack in this game is great!)

One thing that is pretty cool in Black Mesa is that it bridges the gap between the one type of aliens going from our enemies in Half Life 1 to our allies in Half Life 2 (and no I don't really consider that a spoiler). In the original, they're purely our enemy, throughout the whole game; in Black Mesa, it shows how they're actually kinda not. If I say more then it would be a spoiler, but suffice it to say I liked what they did with this concept in Black Mesa. It's also kinda cool how they show a lot of Xen things to be the equivalent of something that you interact with on the Earth side, even though they look completely different or whatever. It makes it feel more familiar even though you're on a totally foreign planet, a very interesting dynamic.

Black Mesa is still buggy, and a few times I've had it crash on me, even repeatedly; but, that's nothing that going back to a prior save won't fix. Make sure to set all your settings that you want and then restart the game immediately, so that in case it does ever crash you don't have to set your settings again.

i think a lot of people approach this game the wrong way, there is absolutely nothing so fundamentally wrong with the original half life that would make it "unplayable" by today standards and this game is not aiming to replace it. what this game does well is integrating itself into the larger world of half life and adding details that we now know as a result of the events that take place after the black mesa incident, it doesn't fundamentally alter the story of the original in any way that goes beyond adding simple nods or changing the feel of a certain scene, it is still the same story retold through the lens of a loving community. the gameplay and difficulty are different from the original but still very half life with a higher enfasis on its weapon variety and enemy ai, i found it to be a much tougher experience than the original with a more relaxed pacing in certain areas but it certainly holds up and the added npc interactivity and dialogue is a nice touch that truly grounds black mesa and in some cases really made me care for keeping my npcs alive, most of the time they will be completely disposable just like they were in the original but ocassionally theyll say something thatll make you want to tag along for just a while longer, without spoiling anything it really cements the presence and beacon of hope that you the player have become to the people of black mesa something that i never felt as much from the original.

TL;DR
its a retelling of the events that took place in black mesa with its own identity (gameplay, artstyle & music) that has a very rich understanding of the original and the larger world of half life.
to me its storytelling is one of its biggest strenghts and the gameplay is also pretty fun and challenging, although i may preffer the simplicity of the original, i only say this so that people also consider giving the original a try,  its definitely a great starting point if youve considered playing through the half life series

If I was only reviewing the first half (to about chapter 11) this review would've been negative.

Lack of attention to detail, badly scripted events that didn't work well, npc's waiting or getting stuck during scenes.
The crowbar feels like HL1 which is for the better, except almost all material properties have been set wrong.

I always adored the attention to detail in Half Life 2 where hitting something with the crowbar would sound right. Plastic would sound like plastic, metal like metal. Dirt, sand, bricks, flesh. All would have it's own sound.
Much to my dismay a lot of the rocks in Black Mesa apparently consists of plastic, as does many of the flesh and metal pieces in Xen. Hell the metal elevators in xen even made plastic crate physics sounds when moving which can only be an oversight. 

I gotta admit I was turned off. Recycle bins that would tip themselves up again, like there's a force added to their upright parameters, Random can sounds often playing.

I got stuck in on rails due to a bug where I couldn't go back and get the train cart for a part where it was necessary. I couldn't find a save, nor any way to know how far back it would be.

I've seen better G-man impressions than the voice actor for him in this game.

Weapon feel could be better, and I miss the vacuum sound of the gluon gun. But weapon feel is just the source engines default.

Leaving the negatives behind, seeing the game for what it is and it's price. It's actually good. I began enjoying the game in the latter half, from around chapter 12. 
I wanna praise the hard work you did on Xen and keeping it out till it was finished. It was the right call. Xen is amazing, and the music feels great. The twists of Xen seem amazing too, it feels like what Valve would've done if they had time. A great interpretation that I would recommend over the original game.

I think Black Mesas biggest issue is not deviating even more from the original - would've loved more fan-lore in Xen. The deviations are actually the strongest points of the game.
Xen and the chapters leading up to it is why I will recommend the game. Being fair it'll always be worth 14,99 - especially if you haven't played half-life 1 before, or you wish to revisit it.

Don't get me wrong, from a technical and artistic standpoint, this is amazing for a fan game, running on source even more, but when it comes to gameplay, it barely resembles Half Life. While the original had a focus on taking advantage of enemy patterns to make a move, Black mesa makes it so the enemies constantly attack you, giving you very little window to plan your own strategies, this being specially evident with the HECU soldiers, which were only able to attack while standing still in the original, making their moves when needed, thus, giving the player time to kill them more securly, making thinking and shooting the most important part of the game. Black Mesa in comparison, resembles too much the combine from Half Life 2, just being hitscanners, making their combat arenas more of a glorified cover shooter than a fast paced one.

Xen is certainly and improvement over the original, but it just drags on for way too long, by the time you encounter Gonark you already begin fighting Nihilanth in the original, and sadly most of it just feels like filler, considering Xen was the climax in the original, it made sense for it to be short, the player had already gone thru a lot, so most of Half Life's cards were already shown, there really isn't that many new things to encounter aside from the bosses and the alien controllers, so for it to be so long just makes it more tedius than interesting specially considering this is a remake, so most players already played the original and just wanted to revisit it.

I love Half Life, but Black Mesa as a remake sadly doesn't quite reach the highs of the original, If you are a player who has not played it before, and plans to experience Half Life, In my honest opinion it's just not a very good option, I's suggest playing the original with MMOD which is listed in the community mods page on steam, in my eyes original will always be the superior alternative, still better than Half Life Source tho.

(Edit, like it even less now, also optimization is pretty ass in xen, runs at like 40 fps in some sections, makes sense due to the held together by duck tape nature of the game, I add this because I have better pc parts now, even with a good cpu, performance is just pisspoor, considering, if u ask me, that the interloper chapter of Xen looks terrible, please make yourself a favor and pick up the original, that's it, updated score)

I was told to give black mesa a go as it wasn't a direct remake it was a major "re-imagining" version of half life with modern features and to be honest, i've tried pushing myself into it and it's just not clicking for me.

This is very much a product for those that already loved the original half life, I have played every half life game, and when HL source came out, I expected that to be like half life with the HD pack from blueshift but in the updated engine and it wasn't even that.

So when I had people telling me from day one where this mod was going I thought awesome for them, half life fans will love that.

Then it became a charged commercial product...... which again I get, it's become a fully fledged game.

But unless you live and breathe half life..... it really feels like "we have half life at home" where a lot of changes seem to have been done to avoid infringing, and a lot of other stuff just feels off.

While I can appreciate the work done to make this...... it feels like someone who could have made a completely new game, made an off brand half life.

After forcing this far into it, I played the anniversary addition of half life... and that feeling playing that game for the first time where it's not doing anything new, it's the same game that I played back then where I was like yeah is is ok, others will love it more. It has that feel, it feels like half life.

Black mesa really doesn't.

This game completely dethrones the original. Black Mesa's Xen is sooo much better then the Half-Life's Xen, the music it incredible, and the storytelling is also done a lot better. If you loved the OG Half-Life 1, then you will love this even more. Please play this game. I can promise you that you wont be disappointed.

While it doesn't quite have the quirkiness of the source material, Black Mesa is still a pretty fantastic remake of Half-Life. The atmosphere is still potent and the level design only feels stronger, with some sensible improvements here and there to punch up the experience. Combat is satisfying and as varied as its progenitor, enemies and NPCs lovingly recreated with some quality voice acting.

To compare the two directly would be a bit of a folly, I believe. It's been 25 years and, after Valve's lacklustre attempt to recreate their classic title in Source, Crowbar Collective make it work in a satisfying and rich experience. I'd still encourage others to play the original, but there's so much that Black Mesa does right - Xen, for one, though seriously longer than its predecessor - feels like the build-up and dramatic journey it should be to the climax of the narrative. 

All in all, a great remake. Fantastic price point too, I'd encourage everyone to dive in and tear through.

Excellent fan-made remake that gives HL1 a new makeover while significantly reworking some of it with very interesting results. Visually, while a bit dated (probably due to the long time it had been in development, around 15 years!) it has a ridiculous amount of detail and it's a vast improvement over the original while staying faithful to its design. 

Sound-wise, the voice-acting is fantastic and has a lot more lines than the original did. The soundtrack is movie-worthy, although it lacks some background tracks and can be a bit too sudden and on the nose at times as it goes from 0 to 100 and then to 0 again.

While On A Rail was too short for my taste and Interloper was a bit repetitive, the sections that have been reworked are generally very good. Besides everything else it does well, the game would already be worth a buy just for Xen alone; the visuals, audio and level design in this chapter are stunning, and it plays much better than the original did; I also loved the added visual storytelling in the final chapters which gives encounters a little more meaning. The changes to the bosses were also great, although Nihilanth was underwhelmingly easy even on hard mode.

I did encounter some pretty glaring bugs which I did not expect considering the game had been in development for so long. The worst offender were the buggy menus, but I also encountered layering issues, a couple of crashes, floating props, got stuck after loading the game, a few holes to the void in walls... 
However, they weren't enough to ruin the experience and it's possible there has been significant improvement in recent updates.

The M134 Minigun is an American 7.62√ó51mm NATO six-barrel rotary machine gun with a high rate of fire (2,000 to 6,000 rounds per minute).[2] It features a Gatling-style rotating barrel assembly with an external power source, normally an electric motor. The "Mini" in the name is in comparison to larger-caliber designs that use a rotary barrel design, such as General Electric's earlier 20 mm M61 Vulcan, and "gun" for the use of rifle ammunition as opposed to autocannon shells.

"Minigun" refers to a specific model of weapon that General Electric originally produced, but the term "minigun" has popularly come to refer to any externally powered rotary gun of rifle caliber. The term is sometimes used loosely to refer to guns of similar rates of fire and configuration, regardless of power source and caliber.

The Minigun is used by several branches of the U.S. military. Versions are designated M134 and XM196 by the United States Army, and GAU-2/A and GAU-17/A by the U.S. Air Force and U.S. Navy.

History
Background: electrically driven Gatling gun
The ancestor to the modern minigun was a hand cranked mechanical device invented in the 1860s by Richard Jordan Gatling. He later replaced the hand-cranked mechanism of a rifle-caliber Gatling gun with an electric motor, a relatively new invention at the time. Even after Gatling slowed the mechanism, the new electric-powered Gatling gun had a theoretical rate of fire of 3,000 rounds per minute, roughly three times the rate of a typical modern, single-barreled machine gun. Gatling's electric-powered design received U.S. Patent #502,185 on July 25, 1893.[3] Despite his improvements, the Gatling gun fell into disuse after cheaper, lighter-weight, recoil and gas operated machine guns were invented; Gatling himself went bankrupt for a period.[4]

During World War I, several German companies were working on externally powered guns for use in aircraft. Of those, the best-known today is perhaps the Fokker-Leimberger, an externally powered 12-barrel rotary gun using the 7.92√ó57mm Mauser round; it was claimed to be capable of firing over 7,000 rpm, but suffered from frequent cartridge-case ruptures[5] due to its "nutcracker" rotary split-breech design, which is fairly different from that of conventional rotary gun designs.[6] None of these German guns went into production during the war, although a competing Siemens prototype (possibly using a different action), which was tried on the Western Front, scored a victory in aerial combat.[5] The British also experimented with this type of split-breech during the 1950s, but they were also unsuccesfull

A letter of love to the original Half-Life by its fans, Black Mesa is not without its issues, but it also has some genuine improvements that the more modern approach to game design and more resource capabilities allow.

Some small notes:

First, I would definitely not recommend playing this game on harder difficulties. The enemies can become quite bullet-sponge-y, which is especially a problem for human soldiers who have extremely good accuracy even while running (something that they couldn't do in the original), chewing through your health and HEV suit in seconds. Sure, you could say it adds challenge, but in practice I just sort of cheesed most combats through various means whenever I could, because otherwise it either required too many tries or left me with health that was so low that it would require too many tries in the next combat.

Second, there are, unfortunately, still some minor glitches. Most aren't a problem because of the ready availability of quicksave/quickload functionality, but some can be quite sneaky: for instance, I got cheated out from one achievement because one NPC just disappeared at some point while I was on a different map.

Lastly, some of the added content can feel a bit repetitive, which is especially noticeable in the largest departure from the original: the Xen levels.

Yes with a few Caveats, one put the dynamic shadows to medium, the game is a mod and it has trouble overloading the engine with that, once I did that it ran far better on my new supercomputer with everything set to high with the supported options, otherwise it dramatically slows down in Xen with all the lighting from the glowsticks, fauna and the like

two with the xen levels the first section before the gonnarch's layer is just way too long, and honestly I would skip it and get right to the fight, as it needs to be trimmed down to a third, same thing with interloper, like theirs alot of great world building but theirs just too much

and my brain instantly knows what the developers thought process was behind Xen's art style, and in knowing that from the time period when the game came out, the original back in 99'

its kinda hard to not notice that and have it cut into the enjoyment of it

also I'm reviewing this 3 years past when Xen first came out, and finally allowed players to finish the game, and you can tell it was a passion product thus causing those issues

ironically timing this on the 25th aniversary video OF half life that valve just released as I was going through this and finishing it up, where they go into a wonderful amount of detal about the thought process

(at the very same time I was doing on a rail and then had them flatout say they electrofied the rail in the orignal to keep the player with the cart or they would walk the entire stage without it, which is exactly what I did to avoid the traps! like sometimes they missed things like that)

anyways the main thing being what they did back then was got all the levels together and said is this fun and then strung it together, or got rid of it, and alot of it in xen could have used that, as the tempo only really picks up in the latter stage of interloper, then dies out

and then finally starts to build in the final crecendo towards the final boss battle, which is very well done with how chaotic and amazing it is, its just alot could have been cut or simplified and condensed in the two prievious levels to get there and it would have built to a far stronger ending like the original had

so overall I recommend it, but know it is a mod and a passion project, and Xen is where they went off script to build it upon some of the old concepts, and it shows, like the game could use a directors cut to try and mimic it better

and dont feel bad about not having everything maxed out or the anti aliasing not hiding all the rough edges, and sometimes flat out really rough textures in interloper at 2560 x 1440, namely, shockingly with the grates when you get to a camp of Vorts after the flying islands with the tenacle monster from black mesa making abit of an apperance, where its abit like how did they miss that

as remember its a mod taking place in a 20 year old source engine that had to be completely rewritten for Alyx in 2019, with them even finding reminants of the old 2003 source engine code still in it, and me finding that grate that was definitely a texture taken from the level just before black mesa east

as I've played it enough times to know where it came from, but thankfully in the entire game, that was literally the only time it ever happened, I just really wish the anti aliasing was a hell of alot better than what it is, as that is literally the only thing holding it back from coming across as a true modern remake of the original half life

and even after all this time theirs some issues that need to be ironed out with the menu sometimes flickering as well

also I really, REALLY miss the old scientist and guard voices at the start, like towards the middle and the end it really doesnt matter as you start to get used to it given their spaced out and far apart so you dont get alot of the same guys clumped together like in the original and they have unique dialogue for their situations

but at the start you really, REALLY miss the OG VA's because of that, like they should have mixed them in or got them to do some re recording or something

as their by far one of the most iconic things about the original half life, and its abit like Eli in the original games vs half life alxy, once you get used to that tone of voice, no matter how good an impression it is

you just miss it too much and it flat out takes you out, like I almost would say they should have done completely different tone and dialogue, just so you dont know its coming

that way its not a redo of an old joke told by a new comedian, as no matter how much or how well you land it or make it, you always know its not the original 

so the best thing to do is throw it out and do something else, 

and honestly I would look for a mod pack that puts them back in, atleast at the start, like a half and half mod of the original with the new

which would really make it feel far more like half life

An absolute triumph that gets everything that half life did perfectly and restores it flawlessly. Most AAA companies could only dream of making a game like this. Despite that, this game was originally a mod made with nothing but passion and love of Half life, which is truly impressive.

This is without a doubt one of the best games ever made and is not only faithful to the original masterpiece that is Half life, but manages to fix the small imperfections the original had. The developers clearly identify and understand what made the original game so good and nothing says this better than the Xen section of the game. 

Xen was originally the only section in half life that left players feeling disappointed. It was bland, boring and very clearly rushed, lasting only a few hours. Xen in black mesa is exactly what it always should've been. It goes on for MUCH longer, yet not a single second feels boring or uninteresting. You could even argue that Xen is the BEST section of this game, which is extremely impressive considering what it is being compared to.

The only criticism I have is that the music is generally a BIG hit or a slight miss. Some of the music in this game like "Forget about freeman" is some of the best I have ever heard. However, other music (Like the Gonarch fight/general singing in Xen) can be off putting or unfitting and is VERY loud with default settings.

I would personally love if Valve gave crowbar collective permission to re-use the original soundtrack, and add it as an option in the settings. The original is one of the few parts of the original game that still holds up flawlessly today.

While Portal 2 is graphically beautiful for a source engine game, I would have to say that this is without a doubt the best looking source game ever made. The models, graphics, lighting etc seem impossible for an engine so old.

This game is a MUST PLAY and stands right beside all of Valve's other masterpieces, which are also Must-plays.

A GREAT remake!
If you have played the original I do think that it is different enough to play this and still enjoy it, but it is also similar enough (from what i have played + heard, EXCEPT XEN*) that people who want to start with the half-life series can enjoy it without the pain of 1998 jank (no offence HL1 we still love you!)

Physics
being on the source engine it comes with the inclusion of the HL2 physics, and while it wouldn't have quite fit in with the original, the Black Mesa Devs have 'slightly' changed the levels and puzzles so that the mechanic makes sense, but as always, the typical source physics is always fun goofing around.

Bugs
While most of my experience was positive, I did have some issues with some major bugs; At one point I turned on subtitles (about half way through the game) and it was fine for a bit [spoiler] (Blast pit tentacle monster) [/spoiler] but then all the interact-able objects (and some not) started bouncing around whenever I moved, I think I fixed it by turning subtitles off but then a key item for a puzzle [spoiler] (the electrical water pit in on a rail, the plug wasn't there) [/spoiler] I fixed it by starting a new save but I never would have known that there was something wrong, if not for Walkthroughs, so that was pretty annoying. It did crash a lot when throwing grenades during those levels also, but there weren't many more bugs other than those

Graphics
Although (correct me if i'm wrong) it has been out in Early Access and then the full release (with Xen) from 2015-2020 but it still holds up beautifully against other games released recently. And obviously it is LEAGUES ahead of the original Half-Life!

Xen
While I haven't personally played the Xen levels in the original, I have heard that they were quite lifeless, but that is completely different here, It is BEAUTIFUL here in BM and i can't really imagine it being any other way, The world of Xen is a diverse place, but at some points (Looking at you INTERLOPER) went on for way too long, so it was a little stretched, but everything else, such as the long jump were awesome.

TLDR:
Awesome game,[spoiler] the pizza is a lie,[/spoiler] some bugs, Xen is beautiful,  8.5/10! best way to be introduced to the half-life franchise, Can't wait to play Half-life 2!

[b]The fan-made Half-Life remake.[/b]
There's a lot to like, but also enough to dislike and/or just not prefer when you have the option between this and the original.

Just about everything is completely re-imagined, most of it being still very faithful to the original.
The level designs and maps have been changed up, but will still feel very familiar to those who played the original. Certain events may not happen as soon as the original, puzzles may have been altered so you don't just immediately go for what you knew in the original, new puzzles being added, and so on. The map overhauls are made to make more sense realistically while still sticking to the awkward Half-Life level designs where you're doing things like walking on seemingly random pipes and inside ventilation shafts.
The game's atmosphere and lighting have gotten a major improvement, making the dark parts look like something out of a survival horror and the brighter parts showing off more of the environment with great detail.

The last few parts of the game, Xen, has been almost completely redone altogether, all the way up to the last boss, with completely new levels and almost a whole new story within. While a lot prettier-looking, they expanded upon Xen a little too hard, as it's now like, 10 times larger in length than the original. Combine that with the now-lengthy Black Mesa section of the game, it just feels like it outstays its welcome.
Probably the worst part about this remake is how it uses Source engine. While a great engine in and of itself, put that together with extremely uneven terrain and it just becomes really annoying to deal with, especially when fighting the bosses of the game. In Xen, where uneven terrain is highly abundant, it just makes for very unpleasant gameplay.

The game is somewhat prone to corrupting its own saves. If you go hard on quicksaving because you're traversing instant-death obstacles or whatever, there's a very small chance it can get corrupted, meaning the game will crash if you try to load it; corruption applies to the game's auto-saves as well.

There are also apparently some removed content and events as well.
The leech enemies you find in the water, for example, were removed, because they were apparently "too annoying" based on play-tester comments, so instead of trying to make them as tolerable like many other annoying things from the original that they actually made tolerable, they just outright removed them the game.

I'd rather re-play the original over this again. The original doesn't outstay its welcome, the physics engine is somewhat dated but silly and very easily manipulated, and crashes & save corruptions are almost non-existant.

Black Mesa is a modern, very competent first person shooter, regardless of its source material. It has everything that a more modern audience should expect from a shooter, and does some genuinely interesting iterations and positive changes to what was originally release in Valve's Half-Life (1998).

That being said, I think that this game is highly tailored for Half-Life series fans, both of the original and the Half-Life 2 series of titles. I think that some parts of the game will reward or work best for players who check out those games first. Genuinely and honestly, playing the original Half-Life is rewarding and stands squarely with Black Mesa, despite its age, and still offers a lot that new players can appreciate. Half-Life is a game I always have and will return to, and Black Mesa doesn't ruin or interrupt my love for that game. I highly encourage for players to also check out the original, and at least the Opposing Force expansion.

Black Mesa, overall, has a feeling of being "Half-Life Abridged," in that some sequences have been changed, shortened, or expedited for game flow, leading to a generally quicker play through than the original. In the original, danger was constant and the fun of combat was figuring out how to use limited skills and the environment to work through enemies. Black Mesa, on the other hand, gives the player a slight edge on enemies, even if their AI has been improved, resulting in quicker sequences, but with enough of a challenge still present.

The development team should absolutely be proud of the environmental designs, animations, models, particle effects, and sound design in Black Mesa. Half-Life was a masterclass in environments in 1998, and Black Mesa lives up to that legacy, breathing a new life into iconic set pieces. 

100%ing the game is a challenge, especially when some of the achievements are definitely there for the hardcore Valve fans who launched a gnome into space in Half-Life 2 Ep. 2, squashed all the grubs, and have committed to memory the original's scripted sequences. Because of the difficulty of some of these achievements, I would highly recommend testing a Half-Life 2 series 100% before Black Mesa, to see if you have the patience to complete it. Achievements will likely require multiple play-throughs, which can be tiresome and repetitive when going through scripted sequences and boss fights over and over again. I would recommend saving often, and keeping those saves for when you need to return to earlier parts of the game.

BUTTERMILK PANCAKES
What ya need: 

2 Cups all purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
2 teaspoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 cups buttermilk
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract (not a fan of imitation vanilla extract)
4 tablespoons unsalted butter (melted) 

What ya do. 
1. Mix the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into a large mixing bowl creating a large well in the center of the bowl. 
2. In the well of the new bowl, crack two eggs right in the center. Pour in the buttermilk, and vanilla and butter.. 
3. Mix together, do not over mix. You want it to be slightly lumpy. 
4. Let the batter sit for about 30 minutes so the buttermilk does its work.
5. After 30 minutes or so, with a large ladle take the batter and ladle it onto a nonstick skillet with melted butter. 
6. Cook pancakes. You want the panckaes to bubble on the other side. Cook on medium heat and until golden brown. 
7. Enjoy some buttermilk pancakes with either house syrup (butterworths, log cabin, etc), or maple syrup, or nutella.

[h1] Black Mesa: Definitive Edition - A Crowbar-Wielding Triumph [/h1]

Relive the Legendary Half-Life Saga in Spectacular Fashion

Introduction:
Black Mesa stands as a testament to the passion and dedication of the fan community, delivering a reimagined and refined experience of Valve's iconic masterpiece, Half-Life. With the release of the Definitive Edition and Update 1.5, Black Mesa has become the ultimate version of the beloved classic.

Single Player Campaign:
Embark on a gripping journey as Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist at the Black Mesa Research Facility. When a routine experiment takes a catastrophic turn, you find yourself battling through interdimensional alien invaders and a ruthless military cleanup crew to save the science team and, ultimately, the world. The Definitive Edition includes a completely reimagined and expanded single-player campaign, featuring new and extended Xen levels across 19 chapters. The narrative unfolds in top-secret labs, harsh desert landscapes, abandoned railways, and dimensions beyond imagination.

Features:

Visual Marvels: Black Mesa presents mind-blowing graphics and effects, pushing the limits of the Source Engine to new heights.
Iconic Arsenal: Wield an array of military hardware, scientific prototypes, and the iconic crowbar as you navigate incredibly detailed environments.
Enhanced Enemies: Face off against classic foes updated with new features and engaging AI.
Immersive Soundtrack: An all-new soundtrack and voice acting create an immersive experience that elevates the storytelling.
Multiplayer:
Challenge friends on 10 iconic maps from the Half-Life universe in thrilling multiplayer battles. Maps like Bounce, Gasworks, Stalkyard, Undertow, and Crossfire provide diverse arenas for intense combat.

Workshop:
Unleash your creativity with the Black Mesa Source SDK, allowing you to craft mods, models, and maps to share with the community on the Steam Workshop.

Steamworks Integration:
Enjoy a seamless experience with Steamworks features, including trading cards, backgrounds, emoticons, and achievements. With Steam Cloud, Steam Workshop, closed captions in multiple languages, and full controller support, Black Mesa is optimized for modern gaming.

Player Reviews:

Improved Controls: Players praise the game for refining controls, making it accessible even for those who found the original Half-Life's controls challenging.
Aesthetic Marvel: Gobsmacked by its incredible presentation, players acknowledge the game's dated aspects while highlighting its overall brilliance.
Newcomer-Friendly: Even for those who haven't played the original, Black Mesa is deemed a spectacular starting point, offering a fresh and must-play experience for both newcomers and series veterans.
Definitive Experience: Acknowledged by players as the definitive Half-Life 1 experience, the game stands out as one of the greatest video game remakes ever played.

Conclusion:

Black Mesa: Definitive Edition is a crowning achievement, seamlessly blending nostalgia with modern gaming elements. It goes beyond mere homage, providing both newcomers and longtime fans with an unparalleled Half-Life experience. This outstanding remake deserves a spot in the collection of any gaming enthusiast, serving as a timeless tribute to the brilliance of the original Half-Life.

Something that stood out to me about Black Mesa was the feeling of scale.
 
In Half Life, the chapters are a series of vastly different areas that don't make much sense leading into one another. On the other hand, Black Mesa really feels like you're navigating the remains of a giant underground facility with the placement of rooms and departments making more sense. Half Life had things like giant vats of acid a few rooms after an office complex. Black Mesa fixes issues like this by modifying the pacing and transitions between chapters.

I can't stress enough how impressive this game is, and I truly think this is the definitive Half Life experience.

I have very mixed feelings about this game. For nostalgia's sake, and for modernizing an old goody, its existence is appreciated. The soundtrack alone elevates the game, in terms of tone and sophistication, far above where the game deserves to be (I listen to the soundtrack fairly often; it's just that good). 

For the actual modernization, though, I feel like the developers didn't go far enough and some of the game just left me marveling at how stuck in the past it is in terms of playability/control and experience.

The story is the same as it was, which is fine, though some of it is made more visible, such as the actual invasion. That's nice. More depth is always appreciated, especially if it isn't contradicting canon.

The visual design is so much better than it was in the original HL, and really brings this game closer to HL2. The Xen environments are sometimes outright fantastic in terms of visual design. It's really a shame I can't finish the Xen chapters. Which leads me to:

Bugs. I can't finish this game without console/cheat tactics because "Interloper" has a massive bug that crashes the game at some point, and the saved games in that chapter crash the game as well. Since it's a GRUELING, LONG, and SLOW chapter, there's no way I'm going to restart it in the hopes that the bug doesn't get triggered the second time around.

The developers have shown no interest in correcting the bug since players are so defensive of this game and of the developers, and everyone seems to just offer the suggestion of "try again" or "load the next chapter to continue playing". I'm not interested in either.

If you want more info about this specific bug, see the discussion area for the game.

Ultimately, the time I spent on this game was a mixture of enjoyment and rage, and I cannot advise someone to buy it, only to risk a similar experience. I am uninstalling it at this point to free up room for newer games, since the developers aren't interested in fixing their own mistakes. I do not bow and scrape or walk on eggshells for developers who sell their product. This ceased to be about purely the love of Half-Life. It's a product, and I paid them for it. In the end, I cannot finish it, because they have a game-breaking bug in it that they wont fix.

I've started and stopped Black Mesa quite a few times since it originally released in 2015. I'm a huge fan of Half-Life and seeing it remade was a dream come true, but only now after completing it in 2023 is it clear just how huge a task it was and how lovingly and painstakingly Crowbar Collective have rebuilt the experience of the Black Mesa Incident from the ground up.

There is quite a lot changed here in the level design and flow of the game, but still the of the little scripted sequences and memorable moments from the original game are in here in some shape or form. A lot of the changes have been designed to either flow better or make a little more sense and I found it to be a joy to play through. The music had some absolutely insane moments, and the new replacement ending is absolutely incredible (like seriously awe-inspiring stuff)!

If you like Half-Life and you haven't played it all the way through since the Xen update then you're really doing yourself a disservice. Charge up your H.E.V. and get in there!

It's amazing. If you've never played HL1, or want to revisit it, this game is the way to do it. I remember the first time I heard about Black Mesa and just how hype the first glimpses were. Glad that the team didn't give up on it, well worth the wait.

But, it's not perfect. The textures on the walls are stretched in many cases which leads to weirdly detailed but still somewhat blurry textures. There's bugs like the ties on the scientist models sticking out a foot in front of them. The AI can sometimes act pretty dumb. 

But then again, it's not like the original HL1 doesn't have all of these problems as well. 

All in all, highly recommended, and it's an amazing experience. But there is some slight mod jank still around to this day.
Best nostalgia high.

The game definitely show it's age.

The gameplay is serviceable. The Snarks and the laser weapons were fun to use, but the rest are just standard guns and traps. Exploration consists of walking through corridors or vents with an enemy appearing or an event playing out every now and then. The worst part of the gameplay is honestly the physics. You and/or objects get stuck CONSTANTLY and it often times feels out of your control. For the first few chapters where you're just in the facility and you're surrounded by flat walls, this isn't much of an issue. But in the later chapters, this gets really annoying. There are so many situations where you have to deal with the janky physics because that's just how the game is. There's so many times where I just have to reload a save because I get stuck in something. The biggest offense in this regard is when you're trying to get out of water. Sometimes you get out of it fine, sometimes you flop up and down five times as a fish monster takes bites out of you. You also get invisible walled constantly.

The story is... fine. I probably missed a lot of subtext or whatever, but I just can't get into the story of this game. Like, I get what's happening, but I just can't connect with any of it. Freeman is a boring protagonist and none of the NPCs were memorable, save for the odd funny guard/scientist. Honestly, the aliens (as well as their world) were the stars of the narrative for me. They aren't the most interesting creatures by today's standards, but there's an air of mystery in them that I found interesting. It also helps that they are distinct from one another design-wise.

The other aspects of the game, the graphics and music, were great at the time and still good now respectively.

Overall, I can't really give the game any less than a recommendation. It's far from a bad game, and all the parts are at least average, I kind of just expected more I think.
Developers put a lot of love into this product. Necessity for Half-Life fans, for others entertaining and well-made old-school shooter.

To be honest, I didn't play Half-Life 1 until after I'd already been introduced to Half-Life 2 via the Orange Box, so not until probably 2008 or even 2009. While I don't remember necessarily not liking it, it wasn't an experience that stuck with me quite as much as HL2 and its episodes did, and I have never revisited it since. I remember Surface Tension and Xen dragging on for too long (everyone does) and I remember some bursts of fun - being chased by a Gargantua, the appearances of the tanks and helicopters, a handful of fun setpieces that were well executed despite being a little rough in comparison to more recent games. In short, I am a bad person to say whether this is the definitive way to experience HL1, but this was quite a fun game on its own.

Black Mesa is, in strict terms, a remake - it follows the structure and pace of HL1 and any liberties it takes from the original game are minor (though there are a few sequences that I think were moved around, and I know of at least one sequence that was not in the original game and I did recognize major changes to one boss fight, for the better). In my view it is a huge success - there were some parts that put a big smile on my face as I remembered the simple joy of a well-designed level where the player is able to keep pace with changing elements of gameplay, but only just barely. I remembered HL1 being punishingly difficult, so I played through on the Normal (default) difficulty, and found it maybe a little too easy for my taste - probably 95% of my deaths were to environmental hazards rather than enemies. If I were to replay this game I would probably raise the difficulty, and I don't think someone new to the series would suffer too much from turning it up a bit.

Visually the game looks great but is still a Source game at heart - you would never confuse it for something made in the HL2 era, but it still has some seams here and there, especially in the early parts of the game which were released as a mod in 2012. The latter parts of the game (especially Xen), which came out only in the full game ~8 years later, are actually visually impressive even now. There is some physics jank, which made me nostalgic for Source-era games, but would probably annoy newcomers to the series. Some (almost all) of the music is shockingly good but I had some problems with audio mixing where occasionally dialogue would get drowned out by music or loud sound effects.

The best thing I can say about this game is that it made me realize how long it's been since I've played a game with a single player campaign that is as engaging as some of the things Valve made when they were still making games (this is only sort of a joke). Yeah, it is a remake of HL1, but I don't know that I'd ever have revisited it without this remake, and the team behind it deserves commendations for carefully rebuilding an artifact of gaming without either sticking too closely to the original (thus making the remake pointless) or bringing in too many new elements (and ruining the original experience).

An excellent remake of a seminal classic. Having struggled to get through the original as a game released before my time, Black Mesa feels like the optimal way to experience the beginnings of an awesome story.

Normally I'm skeptical when it comes to remakes because they usually end up trashing on the source material. But that wasn't the case with Black Mesa. You can tell this game was made by passionate fans of the original Half-Life. From the very first moment of the game till the very end it always feels like a proper Half-Life game and not just a fan remake.

If someone told me Black Mesa was made by Valve themselves I wouldn't be able to tell the difference. That's how good it is. Visuals aren't the only selling point of this game, Crowbar Collective have changed a lot of things and for good. For example the MP5 in Half-Life could hold up to 10 grenades but in Black Mesa that number has been reduced to 3. Other than that they also added more features which the original Half-Life lacked. For example the long jump module is now very simple and straightforward to use, gone are the days of using that obnoxious crouch jumping just to get from platform to platform in the border world.

The soundtracks have also been reinvented just like everything else in the game, while still keeping the vibe of the source material. Other things that have been significantly improved include Xen, Yes that notorious xen that people used to hate on so much in the original game (personally I like the original too).

There is a long list of positive additions that I can just keep going on about so all I can say is yes this is a GREAT REMAKE and definitely worth the money. But now comes the most important question...


Is this the best way to experience Half-Life? NO ABSOLUTELY NOT, I still recommend playing the original game first, while Black Mesa has certainly been a great remake it can definitely not replace the original. IN MY OPINION you need to play both games to truly appreciate this franchise. Black Mesa wouldn't be what it is without the original.

Now for the verdict, Definitely Recommended but better to wait for the steam sale to pick it up

I have not played the original game, so I cannot attest to what Black Mesa has improved upon or done worse in, but I can attest to the standalone game play itself. The game is incredibly fun, it has the right balance of combat and puzzles. The resources are dealt out in a way that you don't have to feel to afraid when it comes to spending your ammo and taking damage, but scarce enough that you still need to put some thought into what weapons you use and when, especially in the final levels. While there is nothing particularly unique about the gun-play when compared to other fps (save a few alternate fire modes) it is still competently made and interlaced sparingly as to make it quite fun and not too bothersome. The only downsides are a handful of infuriating sequences and locations dragging on a bit to much, but that could just be due to faithful adaptation. While I don't think it offers enough for me to replay it, I did thoroughly enjoy the one play through I gave it.

Initially a mod for Half-Life 2, starting production in November of 2004, Black Mesa has gone through a long and tumultuous development cycle, seeing many changes through its incredible 15 year development. It's a labor of love that beautifully and masterfully brings the Black Mesa Incident to modern graphical and gameplay standards, and with such passion came a direct hand from Valve themselves who gave the team at Crowbar Collective their approval and the newest version of the Source Engine to them to continue development. Black Mesa pushes the Source Engine to it's absolute limits, especially noticeable in the Xen chapters of the game.

Black Mesa isn't without fault, with my biggest issues being visual inconsistency with some of it's models, most noticeably the bullsquid, alien grunt and hivehand, though all these examples are models still from when the game was a mod or changed around that time. The Workshop fixes these minor nitpicks with many classic mods, and there's even remakes for other Half-Life games in the Workshop among much, much more.

Good in places, but deserved more polish.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The increase in graphics didn't help much with immersion when the high texture resolution makes things sparkle, which looks a bit tacky, as opposed to the softer textures in the original. The detailed textures are used for comedy gags on the prop brand names, which also pointlessly undermines the immersion of what is otherwise a classic sci-fi story. The crossbow magazine appears full even if it's supposed to be empty. The bee gun seems to tank the framerate. There's floating objects (ones that clearly shouldn't be floating). Some of the effects are underwhelming (or glitchy). The crowbar generates sparks no matter what material you hit, which contrasts against the immersive detail in the original game.

[h1]Level design[/h1]
Some of the layout has been changed, but missed the opportunity to improve the flow of gameplay - the path forks off in a lot of places, which can feel more aimless than satisfying. At times I resorted to the maze-navigation trick of only taking left turns to ensure that you're eventually making progress - some bits are pointlessly confusing though, where the path of progress is obscured by being hidden above you; there's triggers that don't make any sense. Some of the forks are utterly pointless, and serve only to bloat the longevity of the campaign, but not in a good way as it gets watered down while you wander around the levels, which start feeling modular as you notice that a lot of the environment is a copy-pasted series of tunnels. Towards the end, the level design gets more and more nonsensical, where the gameplay loses any sense of flow because there's no intuition to the design, so the game feels like a chore.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Some of the voice acting feels like an imitation (particularly Eli's voice). AI voicelines often feel out of place, and the sound effects include ones heard in other games years earlier, which seems pointless if they're also mixing in some new sound effects, like the replaced houndeye noises (which I think sound worse than the original). Some reload animations feel out of sync with the reload sound. The volume across the game is inconsistent, such as the deafening menu sounds, and even if there was a setting to turn the menu sounds down, the settings don't save. The replacement music was good, but I'm not convinced it was good enough to replace the original soundtrack.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The AI is underwhelming. Houndeyes are way too janky. The boss fights are confusing when they could have been made more intuitive. The flashlight is far lower than your view which sometimes makes it useless. The train is a bit glitchy, and the guns don't always let you fire. The items (and their debris) are annoying and seem to make the framerate choppy (the game is unplayable if you blow up some boxes). Ladders seem even more awkward than the original. The jumping sections are poor (if jumping even works on [i]upward[/i] inclines (and the jumping module doesn't work a lot of the time even when it's got spare charges)). Trying to jump onto something has an annoying mechanic of throwing you over it.

You get stuck on low steps for some reason. There are invisible walls. Enemies see (and shoot) you through any concealment. If you had low HP then there'd be no point in continuing because some parts more or less guarantee you taking damage. You can die often due to nonsense, and without an SSD the deaths would be especially frustrating because you have to go through loading each time. Multiplayer is the typical Half-Life deathmatch, but with players spawning inside eachother. The achievements don't feel like achievements, so they end up being distractions. The game crashes frequently.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
It's not as interesting as the original because it's not innovative; the story (recycled as it already was) is not fleshed out any further, and it didn't spawn a modding scene. If a remake wasn't going to be polished for quality then what was the point of abandoning the groundbreaking (and nostalgic) charm of the original? Graphics were the only consideration, which is convenient to try to drive sales by making the game [i]look[/i] good, but gameplay would have been the important factor, which has been neglected - the butchered Xen gameplay is disappointing, which distracts from the effort to give depth to the environment - if you kept getting stuck and had things thrown at you before you had a chance to react to them then it's difficult to get a sense of enjoyable immersion from it. The game feels overrated, particularly because the Xen section drags on.

Black Mesa is a love letter to the granddaddy of Steam, oozing with passion and polished to a mirror finish. Every AAA studio cranking out low effort "definitive" this and "remastered" that should be taking notes.

For new players: a high quality, puzzle filled, platforming shooter with a compelling story and elevated to a modern standard. The inspiration for Black Mesa was universally acclaimed for good reason. Plus, you can avoid the shame that was Half-Life: Source.

For old players: Black Mesa is like mainlining nostalgia, but seasoned with the perfect amount of innovation. This is not a one-for-one reskin of the original-- Levels play different, puzzles are new, yet feel the same. There is a remarkable fusion of classic and modern that consistently stays on brand, carefully arranged by a team that loves Half-Life.

If you've never played Half-Life, or enjoyed it in the past, Black Mesa is a home run.

[h1]An insult to the Half-Life franchise[/h1]
Remember the celebrated Half-Life with its seamless gameplay, riveting narrative, immersive ambience, thrilling shooting sequences, and more? Brace yourselves because its recreation in the form of whatever this game is, is far from the original, morphing it into a gaming catastrophe.

Infested with gameplay and performance issues, Black Mesa stumbles and staggers, completely overlooking the fluidity that was the hallmark of Half-Life. With perceptible input lag interfering in the experience, firing a weapon, for instance, could take an exasperating 500 milliseconds post-clicking the left mouse button.

Random crashes, after reaching the Xen section, add to the mounting frustration.

No functional fixes can be found.

Is the game visually appealing? Yes, but its visual appeal doesn't make up for these massive problems.

You may be swayed by positive reviews from seemingly devoted fans, but let my review serve as a reality check. The game is indeed as calamitous as I've depicted, and I invite you to experience it firsthand if my words seem dubious.

Unfortunately, Black Mesa is far from a recommendation and, in my opinion, [b][u]mocks the esteemed legacy of the Half-Life series.[/u][/b]

I purchased this way back in 2016, before it was even finished. This game has come a long way, and for a life long HL fan, this game is a thing of beauty. While the game is a bit more relatable for newer gamers than the original Half-Life, I don't recommend this be the first experience someone has to the franchise due to several factors I will mention in this review.

The shooting is very slow, the shotgun is unusable due to it's low reload speed and the amount of time it takes to pump. You basically soak in non stop bullets while you try and run up to an enemy for it to be effective. Honestly one of the worst shotguns out there, and about as fast as the infamous Doom 3 shotgun. The crossbow is a far cry from the original game's and the revolver loses it's one shot capabilities leaving you needing to reload to finish up your third enemy, which takes a while and again you soak up bullets. Your enemies are basically bullet sponges, with head shots having no noticeable effect, and while that was the case in the original game as well, that gets a pass as it was the late 90s. i don't remember the original game having so many weapons feel useless.

This game is confusing at times, and in all the wrong mundane places. Yes the original game was confusing at times as well, but again that was the late 90s and map layouts have come a long way. In the 20 some years since the original you think they could make some of the little pathways or vents a little more obvious. This game is not a 1:1 recreation of Half-Life, so why do i find myself getting stuck in some mundane hallway or canyon area because I couldn't see the small teeny tiny switch? Honestly because of the lighting and textures of the time, it was easier to find my way through some of the more confusing areas in the original game. In a modern game there shouldn't be those frustrating lulls in game play that just kill the experience, especially when this is an homage and not a facsimile of a game from the late 90s.

All that said it is still worth a play through, even if it is more of a pilgrimage than a fun-filled vacation. Eli and Dr. Kleiner have dedicated skins in this, and it really does feel more connected to HL2 than the original game did honestly. While it surely is no replacement for Half-Life 1, this game provides a much appreciated modernization of one of the greatest PC games ever, and it's faults are no more than the original games.

EDIT: Just played through again as part of my Half-Life 25th anniversary pilgrimage, and the gun play felt much improved, I had a wonderful time with it. I still wish head shots with the glock/smg packed more of a punch on marines though. Xen was much more enjoyable this time around as I vaguely remembered most of the puzzles, and combined with the soundtrack was as breathtaking as the first time I witnessed it. Recommend at the highest level!

Half Life 1 was a groundbreaking masterpiece of a game with it being the master of enviromental story design all while having engaging combat and excelent level design that doesn't require an objective tab or translucent arrows to point you to the direction you're supposed to go, however in spite of how great of an experience one may have with it, the ending chapters, the outdated visuals, the immersion breaking bugs, AI, dialogue and not to mention the final chapters feeling unfinished, unrefined and more or less flipping the game logic on its head means you end up with having a rather boring experience towards the end and the story suffering as a result of that and the other issues listed above.

Black Mesa rectifies the issues that had more to do with the technological limitations that Half Life 1 had to deal with and remakes chapters that most people seemed to either claim were boring or just outright hated, it expands upon what the original attempted to imply story wise with its final chapters and doesn't just make you forget everything you were taught up to this point for the sake of thematic elements, keeping in line with the gameplay design taught to the player in the early chapters.

Black Mesa shares however, in terms of gameplay design and story beats more similarities with Half Life 2, which is intentional, the devs wanted this game to serve to people as an entry point into the Half Life series and not feel like you've just suddenly swapped genres from horror-survival shooter to fps-gravity manipulating shooter.

Finally, the graphics of Half Life 1, are to a lot of people untolerable mostly due to the movement speed and the old graphics causing simulation sickness to some users, Black Mesa, obviously, running on a far newer engine which even today looks formidable and beautiful, however outdated it might be and this is the primary reason why I choose to recommend to my friends this game as their starting point into the Half Life series, I've had some experience with friends just outright dropping the original Half Life due to them feeling sick just watching Gordon move at mach 5 while blowing up everything in sight.
