Outstanding Remaster ‚Äì A Definitive Recreation of Half-Life!

This remaster stands as a testament to perfection, seamlessly blending authenticity with a refreshing new style. The meticulous attention to detail by the Black Mesa team has transformed the classic Half-Life into an unparalleled gaming experience. Undoubtedly, it reigns as the paramount remake in gaming history!

A labour of love produced by a studio made of the fans of the original series, that comes with Valve's personal approval.
This game not only does everything the original did just as well but brings a lot more to the table. Flawless level design, storytelling and puzzlecrafting make this game a thrill. With overhauled levels from the original game that were incomplete or cut, the exquisite modern day graphics for the Xen levels are nothing to scoff at.

The levels are well designed with attention to detail to interaction with objects and even most of the NPCs and a heck ton of easter eggs for the Half-life nerds.
The gameplay is smooth responsive and quick paced thanks to the newly added movement mechanics. The immersion is just as good with a silent Gordon being embodied by the player.

All in all, a must play for fans of the Half-Life series and great modern introduction to the series for newbies.

This is the way to experience the original Half Life in the 21st century.  The Half Life is an iconic title and it is an incredible game for its time but 25 years later, it is honestly difficult to play.  Black Mesa updates the graphics of this game to bring it well into the 21st century and makes it a pleasure to experience.  On top of that, Black Mesa adds small tweaks (and in some cases large tweaks) in gameplay, level design, and more which enrich and enhance the experience.  They completely (and very thoughtfully) reworked the Xen levels making them FAR more engaging, much more powerful, and really fun.  Ultimately, this game feels just like Half Life and in many ways feels even more like it belongs with the other games in the franchise than the original does.  It is a great improvement upon one of the best video games ever made and is an incredible achievement.  If you have played Half Life before, this game is still worth playing and if you haven't, I would consider playing Black Mesa instead unless you are a real purist (but let's be honest... if you were a purist, you would have played Half Life by now).

I have 3 points of critique:
[b]1. There are a bunch of fake doors, valves, buttons and machinery that looks interactable.[/b] That's really annoying, when you're trying to find that one switch, that isn't just decoration. It's probably no issue for people who are very familiar with the original, but I just wish there was something better to put on a blank wall than a locked door.

[b]2. Not every pebble on the floor needs to have collision.[/b] Especially in the Xen Levels there is a bunch of janky or weird collision, I found myself unable to jump or getting stuck quite often. It's probably best to keep the floor collision as smooth as possible, or at least add some sort of "stair-effect" to smaller obstacles that are lying around. It becomes frustrating after some time.

[b]3.[/b] Probably a skill issue on my part, but [b]a bit of coyote time (or a bit more, if it's already implemented) might help with certain jumps[/b]. I found myself quicksaving like a madman, whenever there was a gap, because there was always something weird about the leaps you have to take. I was also bumping my head on all sorts of random things while trying to jump over stuff, maybe cut down on the collision on ceiling decoration and tiny pipes or whatnot as well.

All in all, a must have for every fan of the half life series, and also for those who want their minds blown by the sheer, obscene beauty an independent team of fans can create in their fucking spare time.

It‚Äôs been almost 22 years since Half-Life was released by the then unknown developer Valve as their debut game. Since its release it has spawned a sequel with 2 follow up episodes, two companion games Poral 1 & 2 set in the same universe, the imminent release of a flagship VR title and an unimaginable number of mods some of which became games in their own right. 

Black mesa formally known as Black Mesa: Source started off as one of those mods. It was developed and published by a group of eager fans that now go by the name of Crowbar Collective. Black Mesa is a ground up recreation of Half-life that utilises the newest version of the source engine.
The project was initially announced in 2005 after the developers wanted a better experience than the source port of Half-Life that was offered by Valve. It was partially released as a free standalone mod in 2012. Anyone could download it and play as long as you owned Half-Life 2. It Then got green lit on steam and entered early access on May 5 2015. Valve was allowing the crowbar collective to sell the game on their platform and as you could imagine this was great news for both the fans and developers.
The only thing was‚Ä¶ at this time the game was not complete. These initial releases did not contain the final chapter ‚ÄòXen‚Äô. It would be another 4 years until the Xen chapter would be released to the public on 24 Dec 2019. A sort of Christmas present to the fans. 
  
The Crowbar Collective were sometimes silent throughout the last 4 years of development but would drop some information or a screen shot every now and again to show off small pieces of what they had been working on. There were multiple engine updates, to improve both visuals and sound bringing the games look and feel to a 2019 standard. They were hard at work releasing fixes and there were even mods from the community created in this period but what we were all waiting for was Xen and the final release of the game.
And it was worth the wait.
 
The game puts you in the shoes of the silent protagonist known as Dr. Gordon Freeman, a scientist working at the Black Mesa research facility. The first chapter sees Gordon starting his day like any other, making his way down to the test labs and suiting up in his HEV Mark IV hazardous environment suit. His day takes a strange turn when all hell breaks loose as the experiment he is involved in results in a ‚Äúresonance cascade‚Äù. 
From here Gordon will fight for his and his fellow scientists lives as he battles strange aliens that are being teleported into the facility and earths military that are trying to clean up the disaster including any witnesses‚Ä¶ And let us not forget about the mysterious G-Man.
The combat in Black Mesa is superb. There is a pleather of weapons to choose from ranging from military grade, experimental lasers like the Gloun Gun to alien bio technology. When you are not fighting you will spend your time over coming environmental puzzles ranging from shifting boxes to get up somewhere high to dodging mines in a mine field or powering up systems by completing small tasks. Black Mesa tried really hard to utilize the Havok Physics used by the Source engine by incorporating it into a lot of the puzzles meaning gravity, movement and timing play a huge part in succeeding in this environment. 
 
While the combat and puzzle solving are the main elements the keep the player engaged what I personally really loved about black Mesa and Half-Life before it was how the story is told. Black Mesa does not utilise cut scenes or videos. The narrative is told through the environment and the dialogue from the NPCs around you. From the very start of the game you are drip fed information by either speaking to people, reading signs and computers or just exploring the halls and watching people go about their day. The story builds and grows as the character does. These three elements are what made Black Mesa and Half-Life what is still considered one of the most influential games of all times. 

Black Mesa did a fantastic job of modernising a game that is over 20 years old while staying true to the original feel and atmosphere. The team over at crowbar collective have achieved something truly amazing. This Game was a labour of love‚Ä¶ and we sure do love it.

This is not just a 1:1 Remake with nicer graphics.. 

It leaves the core gameplay and key moments intact. The stuff that worked in 1998 is still here, The enemies got some new tricks up their sleeves, but the combat is just as thrilling as it was back then.

The things that needed changing (especially some pacing issues like in "On a train") have been changed for the better. There are some changes where your mileage may vary, like the rework of the MP, the implementation of Half Life 2 style puzzles or the changed controls of the long jump module, but I think these are good changes/additions.

While most of the experience is on par with the original, where this game really takes the lead the Xen chapter. Not only does it look gorgeous, it is a completely new experience that is actually worth playing instead of getting it over with to finish the game. While it had it's frustrating moments on my first playthrough mostly due to not knowing what I was supposed to do, the second time around it went a lot smoother . It is still not perfect by any means, but nowhere near the nose dive in quality the original Xen used to be. It does overstay it's welcome though. There is probably a good third that could have been cut for pacing reasons and it gets very "gamey", especially in the factory.

Special shoutout to the music people. The tracks that are playing in key moments are very atmospheric, especially on Xen.

It's overall an amazing recreation of the original Half-Life, giving it tasteful changes on certain levels, textures and other stuff that bring it to mordern standars for gaming.
On top of all of this there's Xen, a chapter that on the original game sucked, here i'd argue it's the best part of the game. The wait was worth it.

[h1]A Cozy revisit of the Black Mesa facility[/h1]
As a Half-Life remake, Black Mesa does the majority of things right. Seeing the iconic moments recreated with a modern sheen is definitely something special, it reminded me of how levels like 'Blast Pit', 'Power Up', 'Questionable Ethics' etc. left an impact on me. This remake's commitment to also make the game tie into Half-Life 2 further is admirable and feels authentic in execution. The adjustment of certain characters, sprites, or some new additions to the campaign are mind-blowing, and you will greatly appreciate them if you have played Half-Life 2 and its' episodes.

[h2]Gripes[/h2]
That said, I have some minor grievances; such as how "On a Rail" was simply reduced instead of being creatively reworked to be more enjoyable, or how 1 or 2 puzzles were cut out here or there throughout the campaign. In many ways, this is still the original Half-Life so some of the issues still persist here.

[h2]Xen[/h2]
Then there's Xen, which I must admit looks great here and takes some of the more underutilised elements from the original game, implementing them further to achieve new heights. 
The early and mid levels of Xen are a solid time and help make it a memorable experience where the original game fell slightly short. Yet once you get to the penultimate level, "Interloper", it starts to outlive its' welcome. This level is drawn-out with repeating puzzles and gimmicks that make it feel like it lasts a quarter of the game's run time with how tedious it becomes. Despite the reworked Nihilanth boss fight being a satisfying way to conclude the game, it doesn't fix the damage done by Interloper, which made me think back to some of Black Mesa's annoyances, which I was able to ignore and look past due to the otherwise enthralling high effort experience that went into this work. While Xen wasn't particularly great in the original game, I think Black Mesa's version still ends up quite a mixed bag, even if some parts are great.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Still, this is a great way to experience Half-Life, and while some changes and omissions it makes are major (and not all of them stick the landing), the game feels more up to modern standards and new enhancements help elevate it in some cases above the original product.

[b] If you have never played the original Half Life and the original's graphics are too much to stomach, buy this game immediately it is still one of the greatest video games ever made. That isn't nostalgia talking its incredible in any era [/b] 

Level design is top notch, the interaction with NPCs and the little vignettes that you seen in front of you or in the sides of the Black Mesa facility tell a story better than any cut-scene. 

I'll highlight the level Surface Tension, it tells an entire story all while you the player are running around trying to survive. The marines start out in a good position, then slowly lose ground to the aliens, and you see it all play out in real time.

Another great thing is Half Life never forgets about its enemy types. You think your done with houndeyes because you haven't seen them in awhile? Guess again they come back in a way that is challenging. Finally done with the black ops soldiers who are annoying SoBs? Nope they are about to pop out of some cargo containers and akimbo you to death. 

Video games need to bring back silly instant deaths due to environment. It actually makes the game more fun and adds entertainment when you walk into a room and a random laser beam kills you, or a hail of bullets messes up your grill. 
Sustained enemy fire will kill you very quickly. Dying does not seem like a set back because of its save system, but it adds an additional level of challenge knowing that you have 10 health and need to kill a whole room of soldiers, you have the tools to do it and you can do it. 

Even if you are incredibly unlucky and have to pay full price, it is worth it for a game that respects you as a player and seeks to provide a brilliant mix between shooting, platforming, and puzzle solving. 

I really can't recommend this game enough, and I hope more games in the future take this 25 year old formula and run with it. Modern single player FPS like Prey or Control tend to follow the System Shock 2/ Bioshock formula with their RPG elements, but you don't need all those systems. 
Just design a game around enemies and then create levels that highlight those enemies' strengths. Make every gun do something different and useful. Make sure the player has stuff to do and see every 10 seconds. Make the game hard enough that the player may die at any moment, but if they change their tactics they can succeed without having to bang their head against a wall Souls style. 

10/10 needs to be in everyone's steam library

If you enjoyed the original Half-Life, then you will likely enjoy this version. It's a third-party remake of Half-Life made in the Source game engine*, and done very well. All of the assets have been upgraded/updated, and look as good as, if not better than Half-Life 2. 

This version adds and changes various parts of the game, such as (not exhaustive):

- Graphics have been improved across the board
- Maps have been somewhat tweaked, some layout changes here and there, and enemy placements have been changed in certain areas
- Weapons have been more fine-tuned and improved, including handling, spread, animations, etc
- New enemy attacks and animations have been added
- We used to get around quickly by bunnyhopping everywhere, and this has been replaced by a more modern FPS sprinting system
- Some minor enemies have been removed
- Xen, widely considered to be the weakest part of the original Half-Life, has been HEAVILY overhauled and is completely unique from the original game.

I would recommend this game to veterans of the series, as well as new players that have not necessarily grown up with the series, or just don't like the graphics of the original. The amount of work and care that went into this game is easy to see, and this game definitely deserves all the love it has been receiving.

*The Source game engine is the same engine used to make Half-Life 2, as opposed to the original Half-Life engine, which was a modified Quake engine called GoldSrc.

Black Mesa is a remake of the classic first-person shooter Half-Life, which was released in 1998 and revolutionized the genre with its immersive storytelling, realistic physics, and varied gameplay. Black Mesa is not just a simple remaster, but a complete overhaul of the original game, with improved graphics, sound, level design, and gameplay mechanics. It also adds new content, such as an expanded Xen chapter, a multiplayer mode, and a workshop for custom maps and mods.

Black Mesa is a game that respects its source material, but also improves upon it in every way. The graphics are stunning, with detailed environments, realistic lighting and shadows, and smooth animations. The sound is also impressive, with a remixed soundtrack, enhanced voice acting, and realistic sound effects. The game runs on the Source engine, which allows for dynamic physics, destructible objects, and interactive elements. The game also features a variety of weapons, enemies, and puzzles, which keep the gameplay fresh and challenging.

Black Mesa is a game that fans of Half-Life will love, as it recreates the original game with modern standards and adds new content to explore. It is also a game that newcomers will enjoy, as it offers a thrilling and immersive experience that showcases the best of the first-person shooter genre. Black Mesa is a game that deserves to be played by anyone who loves video games, as it is a masterpiece of game design and a tribute to one of the most influential games of all time.

Aighty, after 3 full playthroughs (1 pre-xen update, 2 post), I feel like I can give it a recent review. First things first, it is an easy recommend and I would even skip half life 1 if you are new to the franchise as it is simply outdated. Now, I myself would consider Black Mesa itself to still be outdated. It feels like taking half-life to 2013 maybe, not 2019. The old source level loading and certain areas of the graphics (which I'll get into later) are what make me think about it in such a way.  The overall remake is still an easy recommend since the game does what it says it does perfectly, and even improves on half-life in the areas that aren't direct remakes of the older one. 

PROS

Here I'll get in to the good. The gameplay, levels, animations, models, and enemy design are all great from a hl1 perspective and they should be good for people coming from more modern games as well. The few boss sequences in Black Mesa are good and the music is great, in fact the fact that they are used too sparingly could be counted as a con. The game doesn't stray too far away from half life one gameplay-wise and when it does, it is usually for the better. This doesn't apply to the Xen levels which are vastly different from half life 1 yet are some of the best in the game (excluding 1 part I'll touch on later). Also, performance and workshop integration are huge bonuses.

them CONS

This game isn't perfect. It has some cons that do matter. First would have to be the lack of cohesion in graphics between some levels. Some levels look great and really push the older engine to great heights while others look like old Garry's Mod maps. Another big issue for me Is the gun sounds. The overall sounds in the game are great and keep the half-life 1 vibe while also simply sounding good but the sounds for the submachine gun and shotgun sound terrible. You'll be using those guns a lot so it is quite a bummer. The last issue is the pacing in the Interloper and surface tension sections. Surface tension can be excused since it had to be genuine to hl1 but Interloper stayed it's welcome a bit much. Interloper starts great and continues to be great until the last third where it really becomes a drag and ruins the pacing of Xen.

Final thoughts:

It's a good game with a few cons that aren't nearly as bad as what it gets right. Worth a purchase 4 sure.

This is unequivocally one of the most classic FPS games remastered to be arguably better than the original. The gameplay is phenomenal, story is tried and true, the game is full of nice little secrets and Easter eggs, it's only $20, what more could you ask for? The spacing and originality of the bosses is amazing. The gunplay and rate of gun upgrade is awesome and rewarding as well. The sound is spine-tingling and the soundtrack is fast-paced and adrenaline pumping. My only real gripes with this game are the stale human AI, (though it is better than the original), the bland friendly characters, wonky ladder physics, and lack of Xen, though it will be coming soon.
It's also got great Steam Workshop full of wonderful and greatly made creations, unlike some other crap-fest workshops.
It might be the real one's 25th, but this is the best way to experience Half Life post 2020.

Although I wouldn't call this an "improved" version of Half-Life (the lack of cockroaches and the inclusion of dynamic drops forever ensures that), I will say that this game is very good, and an easy recommendation, even to those who have never played a game in the franchise!

Its an amazing game and personally a Remake done right. My only Qualm though is Xen itself now on its looks or what it does its beautiful and that's not the problem. But my problem with it is Xen is a REALLY performance taxing section I feel some more optimizations should have been made because even being reasonably above recommended specs you WILL drop frames regardless of graphic setting unless you have a High to Very High end PC.

I dont have the right to say its huge size causes it to overstay its welcome because im not a long time fan but that is a nitpick of mine. But I will say Xen needs to be broken up or optimized more for performance and if unable should raise its minimum and recommended specs accordingly on the store page because if you fall onto the recommended specs 20 to 30 fps is the norm on the Xen section with some sections in it going as low as 10fps. I am very tolerable to that but I am saying this right now to play the game at 60fps across you'll need to high ball the recommended specs in the games current state.

As for the two achievements PhD in Pacifism and Laser Immunization its very hard if you try to do that in 1 run but remember you can save and reload at any time if you made a mistake. So I recommend saving much more often to get those two because there very arduous and difficult otherwise as saving and reloading does not invalidate achievements so long as the failure was done before the save.

Sure its save scuffing but its how with quite a lot of trial and error was able to get those 2 achievements that will save you a lot of headache if your a completionist.

Also if your wondering about performance to quell any about my rigs inability these are my specs and I will compare them to the recommended. And tell you if the Recommended is Greater then [>] or Less then [<] my system to quell any, my computer is to weak comments. I was Playing the game on Medium to Medium-High settings.

On Medium to Medium-High Settings I get 60FPS most of the game 30 to 60fps on the outside sections and anything between 10 to 30FPS in Xen. And just to eliminate outside factors id still get these frames regardless of Discord Streaming or other applications outside of the game being up or closed. Despite punching twice as hard as recommended in some of the requirements when recommended means at least to me you should be fully able to play at 60FPS reliably on High and almost all the time on anything lower then that.

So what does that mean? Well it means that Xen and the Outside sections are not considered in this performance analysis and thus this analysis is only based on the inside sections which do encompass most of the game and you will get 60FPS flat in those sections with Recommended. But if you do Recommended or lower Frame loss in those later sections is inevitable so for 60 FPS flat as I said prior you WILL need to High ball the recommended for that kind of frame rate across the game.

Hence why the game is still recommended because about 70 to 90% of it is still very much playable but because of this obscene performance demand in these places when recommended SHOULD account for that on Medium at the very least. I have to drop it to a 7.75/10 because of some of the later more intensive scenes and of course Xen one of the most anticipated sections in the game is sometimes rendered completely unplayable because of that.

Also and I know this next part is off topic but it highlights an innate flaw with the specs of a game in Steam it will tell you what is required but that doesn't always apply to ALL of the game. Most of the game can be easy to run but select sections can be completely contrasting to its expected specs causing this situation where a person buys and plays a game expecting it to run fine on there rig only to run into that large section that renders it next to unplayable.

Its even worse here because Xen is at the tail end of the game so you play through most of Black Mesa and now cant beat it because Xen is a performance hog of a section outside of expected specs and cant refund it since your now past the 2 hour refund mark not saying you should if you play through most of a game but for instance if someone less genuine was to do that it would be a nasty rug pull scheme. Thankfully that is not the case here its an amazing and genuine dev team that hopefully will fix that, and I managed to get through it and beat it but still, that's pretty bad.

[h1]A Disappointing Journey from Excitement to Frustration[/h1]

I initially enjoyed Black Mesa when it first came out in 2017. My first playthrough was a great experience. When the 1.0 update dropped in early 2020, I was eager to dive back in for a replay. Unfortunately, I found myself quickly disappointed. The changes to the level design on many maps were not for the better. The HECU now feels more like Combine soldiers from Half-Life 2, which is regrettable. The alterations to the guns, especially the SMG, made the gameplay less enjoyable compared to 2017.

Despite these issues, I decided to endure until the Xen section. It proved to be a challenging and often frustrating experience. Xen, unfortunately, turned out to be the tipping point for me. While it looked decent, it was overly long and lacked the fun factor. The Gonarch fight was particularly grueling. Although the final boss fight was decent, it wasn't enough to make up for the game's overall shortcomings.

On a positive note, the music throughout the game was excellent, though I personally prefer the original Half-Life soundtrack. Half-Life 1 remains my go-to game; it feels more enjoyable to play and comes at a much more affordable price. I find myself revisiting Half-Life 1 from time to time, and I doubt I'll be returning to Black Mesa anytime soon.

The game is great, it captures the feeling of Half-Life without really interfering  that  much with the original concept, the gunplay is astonishing, weapons feel as good as any other Valve-developed fps and the tweaks that have been made to some levels to put them on par with modern day standards  aren't at all an hindrance to the experience, well, except for the new Xen. Aesthetically breathtaking but hardly fun to play the new Xen practically functions as an expansion to the base game, just not a really welcomed one. As much as I think the "old" Xen is not on the same level as the rest of the game, I, frankly, found it to be a quite fitting end to the Half-Life storyline, it was aetherial, aestethically different from any other outer space fantasy setting that existed at the time and short, in fact by then the game had already given all its potential so I think that the short duration of the old chapter was a far more fitting conclusion that the mind boggling three hours of asinine puzzles and beautiful yet boring landscapes of Black Mesa's Xen. Aside from the Xen another criticism I want to push is the fact that this game is really really dark compared to the original one, and I mean REALLY DARK, in all of the times I played the OG HL I've never used the torch so much as in this game. Sometimes ,even with maxed out lightness and my room in total darkness, I wasn't able to understand what the hell I was looking at. In conclusion, I think this reimagining of the Black Mesa's events is a great experience that any Half-Life fan can and will appreciate but can hardly replace the original game.

This is an edited review. The original review I don't really agree with anymore. I still wouldn't recommend this game because of its privacy policy stuff, but I had a much more enjoyable time on my second playthrough where I'm trying to get all the achievements. I haven't finished the game again yet but I've gotten to Xen and its been much more enjoyable. 

I kind of see why I thought this game was directionless a lot of the time though. There are some points where its not really clear how far you are from your goal. Part of the reason I didn't have as much of a problem with that this time was because I had played it before. I still did notice that some areas just had you go somewhere with no clue why or how it would lead you to your goal. And there were still only sparse moments of real progression.

Also I do still agree with my old point about some of the segments with a ton of explosives like that one building with all the tripmines. There are certain explosives that are far enough away from the others that should totally be okay to blow up safely but they're not. 

And for now I only have two other things to say:
The helicopter fight is annoying.
The pizza, purple hat, and canister achievements are horribly designed. Anytime I had to take the items up a ladder it was a struggle. Getting them through the part that takes place on the cliffs was hell and I had to reload so many times cause they kept falling off. There were some times when a door would close behind me and never open again forcing me to reload because I left my items on the other side. It's clear that no actual thought was put into these achievements and into the fact that you have to carry 2 of these items throughout the entire game. And it was completely unnecessary to have 2 items at all. It means you either need to go through the super annoying task of carrying two items the entire time or you need to do two entirely separate playthroughs. If you don't care about achievements though you can just not do it. 

I might add more to this when I actually finish Xen again.

[h2]The Full Detailed Review[/h2]

The graphics and visuals are obviously gorgeous.
Gameplay, different mechanisms and in-game physics are inspired by Half-Life 2 and upgraded to a next level.
Some parts of the game feel like how they supposed to in 1998 version which is a great thing if you ask me.
the model and textures are designed wonderfully but the lack of variety can be seen in face models which I'll allow it assuming it's a fan-made remake.
 
Now down and down and down we go...
See this is a great remake. and for a fan-made one, it's a damn good job.
BUT it's not perfect. It has its flaws. *says a fan of HALF-LIFE* that were frustrating for me and almost ruined my experience.

The first problem I had, was its shadow and/or lighting problem. the game is SO dark that my life is pretty brightened compared to it.
Idk if it was an intention or with no attention but either way, It's really annoying. it's like the game overcasts shadows and creates
unnecessary ones over/behind/top of/in front of the object. whether it being a headcrab, a box or a body.
a flashlight won't even work because using a flashlight causes these shadows and THAT flashlight is as bright as a candle.
I didn't find a single functioning solution in anywhere. and people's reactions were like: "Oh no you're lying and making excuse not to like it, I had zero issues with this game".
Here are some example screenshots:
https://ibb.co/F7YL7n2
https://ibb.co/vmK9CXN
https://ibb.co/rskh4Yz

Next problem is its nonsense conversations between two NPCs. sometimes they are planned and scheduled at a specific moment and have a purpose.
but most of the time when they are following you, they pop out some random scripts at each other in order to make the situation REALISTIC.
for example:

+ you think anybody's gonna believe all this?
- I reckon.

+ You have any idea what's going on?
- You bet.

+ What is that smell?
- I aim to.

These dialogues are nonsense and unnecessary!
I know it existed in the original game but it felt real. it wasn't random.
all of them were scripted and triggered properly.
Now cause it's random, it can be different for everyone but it'll still be nonsense.

The Last problem is it's constant frame drops which is a usual thing in games nowadays. and either has a solution or doesn't.

Overall if you're a fan of Half-Life game, give it a shot, why not?
But if it's your first time getting into this franchise and don't care much about graphics, then I suggest you the play the original one.

The most solid recreation of Black Mesa (Half Life) and Xen (Also Half Life)
that I have ever seen.

All except the actual Nihilanth fight itself.
I hate to break it to you
But I would rather reinstall HL1 just to replay that final fight, than to actually do it in this game.

The eggheads (geniuses) over at crowbar collective have really out done themselves.
Almost to a fault.

Everything has been meticulously remastered and I mean re-MASTERED using everything one could possibly learn from studying Valve Game Design 101. But when it came to the nihilanth fight, they really overdone it and overhauled the fight sooooo much that... that its a Destiny fight now.
And I think that the final boss playing out like a WoW Raid with its phases and how bullet spongy it is really misses the point of what it felt like to BE Gordon freeman.

Gordon Freeman was never supposed to be checkpoint reloading his way to narative precognition, thats D9142's thing from SCP Containment Breach. What I mean by this is the mechanics and level design shouldn't end up facilitating the NEED for constant checkpoint loading, which will happen automatically when you die constantly to a bullet sponge boss, souring the ending climax of the story. 

That will just about do it for immersion.
The Nihilanth would never send you staches of supplies.
He would throw you to another realm where you stumbling upon resources
is believable and unintended.
Sending you staches of supplies for no reason is what he does in Black Mesa's Xen though...
Makes less sense than anything else so far...It seemed phoned in. Like a short cut was taken to facilitate this development.

The original "fight" NEEDS to give Gordon this down-time REGARDLESS of player prowess or game difficulty so that its the same ending and same feeling no matter what, completed at relatively the same "pace", with no savescum triggers. The Nihilanth from a story perspective is doing to you what G-man will start doing with you the moment you beat this boss, and it ties his powers in before you officially meet him. You see what im talking about in both Half Life and Black Mesa.

Again overall, EXCELLENT GAME in TOTALITY. but remastering the very ending fight in this way misses the point everything else set up. The original ending fight was actually pretty straight forward and there was no reason to change it to what is arguably a downgrade. Like imagine not having ALL of SCP 106's pocket dimension in a multiplayer rendition of Site 19 events, and downgrading him to a touch-to-kill like every other SCP in said multiplayer experience. Obviously you need to, right? You have to in order to have the game go by faster and keep things mechanically streamlined. Its just easier on you as the developer. Thats basically the developer version of what happened. The OG Nihilanth was a Mona Lisa.
And yet another obviously well talented and well meaning artist wanted to "touch it up"
there is NOTHING wrong with the sentiment.
There just so happens to be everything wrong with the outcome.

I waited for this game since the trailer in 2008.  It's everything all of us hoped it would be and way, way more.  There's a reason it took these guys over a decade longer than they promised to finish the game.  It's because they kept raising the bar higher and higher.  Somehow, after all was said and done, they still ended up outdoing themselves.

This game is a masterpiece.  The perfect blend of remaster and remake.  They extrapolate the original gameplay, story, and level design in intelligent directions.  Everything is improved, but it's still clearly Half-Life.  This game is on par with the quality we have come to expect from Valve themselves.  

The original soundtrack by Joel Nielsen is nothing short of excellent.  His work has come a long way since the inception of this game.  The sound design in general is also great.

If you are a fan of Half-Life and this mod/remaster has somehow flown under your radar until now, this is the game you've been waiting for.  If you're not a fan and you're wondering what's all the fuss about Half-Life, I'd honestly start with this game and then go play Half-Life 2.  As far as I'm concerned, they've earned the title of the definitive Half-Life remaster.

I'm near the end of the first Xen level and I needed to take a break before moving forward. Not sure when I'll come back. Thus far, I would say I rate the game between 7-8 8 out of 10. The amount of effort put into this remake is amazing, and I absolutely love how the story is delivered in this game. 

The gameplay however is just okay. It feels dated for obvious reasons. Gunplay is serviceable but not good by any means, and most levels just seemed to drag on for far too long. I found myself starting many levels feeling excited for new plot developments and environments, but then doing the same puzzles with minor variations over and over again chipped away at my enthusiasm. I was wowed by Xen and then the level became an endless cycle of "traversal puzzle, put crystal here, connect some wires, shoot at aliens for a few seconds, repeat" I also encountered a level-breaking bug at the end of "On a Rail" where I had to completely repeat an already somewhat tedious level. 

Another reviewer described the game like receiving endless cake at a restaurant. It's great at first and then you're waiting for it to be over.

On sale, this game is absolutely worth it. It's a great fan remake of a historic game that holds up remarkably well, but also suffers greatly from pacing issues inherited from the original or maybe exacerbated by the remake process.

Fun fact: [i]Black Mesa[/i]'s development took fifteen years from proposal to release. In that time, [i]Black Mesa[/i] saw a decade-long hiatus for the [i]Half-Life[/i] series and only barely managed to release before the newest title in the same month. Crazy to think this is one of the longest development times for a game, period. If there was a theoretical Labor of Love award on Steam, this game would probably qualify for it [i](ahem, 2020 contenders)[/i].

As for an actual review, [i]Black Mesa[/i] is more or less the original [i]Half-Life[/i] with a fresh coat of paint and polish. Lots of the design, both gameplay-wise and visual, follow that general philosophy so the title can feel like reliving old memories as you remember them rather than as they were. There is a slight variation on the tone and atmosphere at times, [i]Black Mesa[/i] will at times underscore itself with somberness where [i]Half-Life[/i] opted for esoteric and darkly-comedic colors. While not necessarily being the best at its craft, these changes work well enough to have a sufficient bit of impact when they come.

Overall, [i]Black Mesa[/i] is a welcome stroll down memory lane for [i]Half-Life[/i] fans, and a great introduction to the series for newcomers.

The game starts out fine; the darker lighting in the first levels kind of ruin the atmosphere that you got from the first game, but otherwise pretty fun. Xen easily takes up half the length of the entire game, and it's filled with nothing but tedious, repetitive, boring, uninspired section after section. Nothing in Xen even approaches the concept of 'fun'. You sprint along a linear pathway for 10 minutes, then you do a braindead jumping or power outlet puzzle that a 5 year old could do blindfolded, then you do it all over for around 50 times. The level design choices that these people made while creating these levels are absolutely baffling. It honestly feels like I was scammed, that's how bad it is.

Oh, and there's multiple bugs that cause hard crashes that the devs are aware of but are just not willing to fix apparently. One of these occurred for me at the final boss which made completing the game impossible. 

Save your time and just play the real Half Life.

So Half-Life was a horror game this whole time?

Clearly a lot of work went into Black Mesa, but too much of the source material has been retooled for this [i]"Help I can't see anything! Is my monitor still on??"[/i] style of horror gameplay.

[h1]Half 1: Apprehension[/h1]
Your flashlight seems to work even worse than in Half-Life, and I don't mean in terms of jankiness, so much as it's a pitiful excuse for a flashlight. It only lights up the center of the screen and I wouldn't call a flashlight lighting up such a small area "working".

On the topic of screen space, it seems like a lot more of the screen is dedicated to the gun. So, in addition to the edges of the screen that the glow-in-the-dark watch you call a flashlight won't light up, the entire bottom right corner of the screen is [i]also[/i] a place ooky-spooky closet monsters can hide in.

And is it just me or did the shotgun's alt fire get a longer cooldown? Either it used to fire faster or I'm remembering it wrong.

Also, holy crap, what's with the sound effects for the guns?? Remember when remakes in 2010 would add way too much bloom for a stupid reason? That's what these guns sound like. Imagine if it was possible to put way too much bloom into Half-Life's sound effects. Now you know what the guns sound like.

I simply can't get used to those sound effects. That's not hyperbole. After 10 hours, I'm still put off by the noise every time I have to shoot something. I'm at the point where I'll just run past enemies so I won't have to listen to my guns.

Which leads me to: The AI is also even worse than Half-Life's. To its credit, soldiers still won't rush you when you're trying to camp and they will still throw grenades to flush you out. But when they're out in the open, they're rock stupid. They keep forgetting I'm there. They keep turning their back to me while we're in the middle of a fire fight. They'll often throw a grenade and then immediately run to where the grenade is and wait for it to explode. And the list goes on.

In one situation, soldiers were blocking my path. So I pulled back and tried to camp a corner. They never came around the corner and instead threw grenades, which is a relic of Half-Life's AI. But they also kept running to those thrown grenades, which is clearly Black Mesa's contribution. After camping the corner for a few minutes, never seeing anything but hearing lots of explosions followed by silence, I decided to peek the corner and saw they were all dead. I didn't fire a single shot. They all killed themselves.

The levels themselves have seen some massive retooling as well. I will agree that you can have a different experience and still have a fun. After all, nobody said this would be a 1:1 conversion, and that's for the best. But levels like On A Rail were the uncomfortable dips in Half-Life's gameplay, while Black Mesa's annoyingly dark shadow levels are just what annoying Black annoying Mesa's levels play like.

Or to frame this another way, On A Rail was a pain on the first playthrough, but subsequent playthroughs would show how easy it is and how much your problem solving skills had grown. But annoyingly dark levels of any game are always annoying, regardless if you're on your first or fifteenth playthrough, and that's Black Mesa.

[h1]Half 2: Questionable Ethics[/h1]
I think most of the people who are praising Black Mesa are doing so because they're afraid of being labeled a heretic for hating Half-Life.

But that's not hating Half-Life. That's hating not being able to see anything. That's hating guns that fire too loudly and not as fast as they used to. That's hating enemies that always work better when they're off screen because they're now designed to be closet monsters for a horror game. That's hating this one specific interpretation of a classic game. That's not even hating the developer(s) or their intentions. Just the final results.

Black Mesa was "released" in 2020, was "in development" in 2015, was "released" in 2012 (as a free mod), and was "in development" in 2005 (when "released" as a WIP free mod). But the important part is the game was "released" in 2020 and if Black Mesa doesn't want to be a 1:1 conversion of Half-Life because "you can still have fun even if it's not 1:1", then okay, fair enough.

But that also means Black Mesa is its own separate interpretation, which means it is its own separate game. And to grade Black Mesa by its own merits as a separate game that was "released" in 2020: It's boring, it's dark, it's annoying, I can't see anything, the AI is awful, my weapons sound like crap and are not satisfying to use, and it plays like a horror game, which is simply an experience I don't want.

Again, this point of view that I'm expressing, much like Black Mesa, is removing Half-Life from the equation. I'm not saying Black Mesa isn't good enough. I'm saying Black Mesa isn't good.

To add Half-Life back into the equation; just because you got scared while playing Half-Life doesn't mean Half-Life was a horror game.

The initial promise of Black Mesa quickly turns into a disappointing and convoluted experience that fails to capture the essence of the Half-Life universe.

While I acknowledge the significant effort and talent put into creating Black Mesa, the final result is an overly long and buggy mess that deviates too far from the original Half-Life formula. It would have been better if the team had focused on faithfully remaking HL1 in the HL2 engine, as most of the additions to the game simply do not work.

The first half of Black Mesa is enjoyable, providing a fresh perspective on the HL1 world with updated graphics. However, there are noticeable performance issues, particularly severe drops in frame rate (5-10fps!) during the Lamda Core level, significantly impacting the gameplay experience. While frustrating, this could be forgiven as a one-time occurrence.

Regrettably, once you reach Xen, the game begins to unravel in terms of story, pacing, and performance. The overly long Gonarch set piece fight and the chaotic experience of navigating moving conveyor belts while being attacked by 20-30 aliens, with body parts bouncing around the screen, detract from the balanced gameplay that Half-Life is known for. At this stage, it feels more like a Serious Sam game and never returns to the Half-Life essence until you finally meet G-Man.

The frame rates fluctuate wildly, ranging from 5 to 60, making it possibly the worst performing game I have ever played, especially on modern systems. Even lowering the resolution to 800x600 and using low graphics settings has no effect on the performance.

Due to the shortcomings of the Xen portion, what could have been a solid 8/10 rating drops to a generous 4/10. It is evident that the lengthy development time of this game was a result of overproduction and a lack of quality control, with too many individuals trying to incorporate their own ideas into a project that should have focused on faithfully recreating HL1.

In hindsight, Black Mesa should have remained true to its roots and simply served as a faithful remake of the beloved classic, without unnecessary alterations.

BLACK MESA is an successful remake of one of my most played and beloved video games of all time. Even though the game didn't manage to evoke the same emotions in me as the original, it was still a great experience to follow in Gordon's footsteps once again and relive the events in and around Black Mesa. Thanks to the Source Game Engine, the remake shines in all colors and shapes and looks way more polished than the original in every aspect. Even though this engine is also no longer up to date, it was a very beautiful  implementation. But it also shows all the more how irrelevant modern graphics can be when a good story is told in an exciting way and the gameplay is fun. This version of Half Life offers added value in that regard as it can convey the story a little more lavishly. Black Mesa shows its strengths especially in XEN, although here it feels like a completely new game. The Dash function adds a completely new game element and the developers have given free rein to their creativity. Instead of the 15 minutes of play time in the alien world of the original game, there were over 2 hours of firefights, skill tests and a lot of crouch jumping here. And I loved it, even though the last few stages felt a litte bit draged out. The boss fight at the end was an absolute blast.

Anyone who knows the original will also enjoy this game. And for the younger generation, Black Mesa offers a good introduction to a franchise that has had a lasting impact on FPS shooters. At this point a big compliment to the developers who are clearly fans of the original and you can feel that in every corner and edge of this game. And that's a good thing!

After three years I finally found time to sit down and return to Black Mesa to play Black Mesa Xen. I'd previously seen videos, heard discussions, but never done it myself...and at last I have, and I am so glad that I found that time.

Black Mesa's story is not only a success for the team and the creators within it, but a triumph for all of modding. A fantastic product, end to end, with some oddities here and there that I don't think make this not worth a play. I love the original Half-Life; I'm not the biggest fan of the gameplay of Half-Life 2 (though I think the presentation and worldbuilding is immaculate) and so maybe my biggest gripe is Black Mesa chose to modernise Half-Life's gameplay by taking notes from its sequel. It's less fast-paced as a result, channels less of that retro-shooter vibe, but in its place we get a very refined sandbox with some generally good balancing decisions.

Xen is a very interesting case. I think some of the expansion is close to flawless in its execution, whilst some decisions feel a bit off. Explosive houndeyes, naked grunts, and alpha houndeyes don't add as much to the gameplay sandbox as, say, canonising Antlions into Xen might've done (and also might've given the team even more opportunities to work with Vortigaunts; the way they're handled in BM: Xen is far and away the coolest part of the entire section). Meanwhile, plugs, plugs, and more plugs outstay their welcome, as well as Interloper on the whole eventually stretching on with its limited bag of tricks being exhausted by the end. The Nihilanth fight is climactic, though, and the music in all of Xen is an auditory revelation.

It's not a replacement for Half-Life - at least not for me, and maybe not for those who like the flow and "vibe" of Half-Life more than Half-Life 2 - but it is a way for the modern gamers who won't give retro games a second look to get into this world, and it's also another way to experience the start of a journey that for many - myself included - kickstarted a career in pursuing creative passions. With new people learning to mod this old but venerable engine thanks to Black Mesa, its legacy is already becoming similar to the game that started it all, and I think Crowbar Collective deserve that legacy through and through.

And overall great re-imagining of an all time classic. 
It stands on it's own as a pretty great game, but where I think it shines it as a companion piece to the original Half-Life and not as a replacement for it, an effort in which I don't think it succeeds in. 
The Black Mesa research facility is lovingly recreated in the source engine, but not all of it was carried over into this game. Sadly a lot was changed for the worst and some parts were cut entirely, for example 90% of the chapter on a rail. 
Some might be glad on a rail is gone, but to me it was a fun chapter in the original that broke up the combat sections from getting stale so it's a shame crowbar collective didn't at least try to re-imagine it. 
Another aspect I am not a fan of is the new AI for the HECU marines. In short they're not as fun to fight as their original counterparts. They get stuck on walls and generally are just walking turrets. The black ops  assassins are sadly even worse. I easily got them stuck in a door and killed all of them with a grenade. I wasn't even trying to cheese the fight, they were just that easy to get stuck.
But what makes up for all these shortcoming is the Xen chapters, which are a vast improvement over the original. The levels are gorgeous and really do go along way in immersing you in this alien ecosystem in which you feel like you don't belong. The Xen fauna unlike the their human enemy counterparts are very accurate to the original and still just as fun to fight. 
A common complaint is the length of the chapter interloper, which I agree goes on for far too long, but it's not something that detracts from the overall enjoyment of Xen.
My final complaints about the game will have to be some technical aspects of it. For one Anti-aliasing barely works. I had to run the game in DSR mode at 1440p on my 1080p monitor to make up for the awful anti-aliasing. Also the game, especially the research facility lacks a lot of polish, some ladders don't work well, the menu shows  up in the preview image of saves. I can go on about these issues but it seems the team has moved on and sadly they won't get addressed. Nothing is game breaking, but I was genuinely disappointed by this aspect of the definitive edition release. 
If I could have a perfect hybrid of Half-Life's research facility and HECU marines, and Black Mesas Xen, that would be the perfect way to experience the first chapter of the Half-Life saga. 
As it stands I can't recommend Black Mesa as a replacement for Half-Life, but if you just cannot tolerate the old school graphics of the original, or have already played it and beaten it, then absolutely give Black Mesa a shot.

Full disclosure, I NEVER played the first Half-life. While most reviewing this game critique the game based on how well it succeeds that remaking Half-life, my review is going to be coming from fresh eyes:

Black Mesa as an FPS game is pretty fun. There are a LOT of weapons to mess around with, decent enemy variety, and a whole lot of fast-paced corridor goodness. Very reminiscent of Half-life 2 in that regard (shocker). I don't think all the weapons are created equal and the game does want you to take it a bit slower than the movement speed lets on, but it's a good time regardless. However, Black Mesa becomes a truly incredible experience once you take in the journey you go on.

The level progression in this game is incredible. What starts as a bunch of cramped hallways takes you across a complex research station with each chapter having at least one incredible set piece or moment. The story in Black Mesa is told 100% organically and yet is still able to establish a natural progression of a dire situation developing and getting more dramatic. The music and eye-catching maps only help add to this and Black Mesa becomes one of the most engaging titles I've played all year. It's akin to Bioshock in levels of immersion as far as FPS games go, a claim I do not make lightly, and a definite must play even before you consider the legacy of the first Half-life.

Frequent crashes are encountered when adjusting video or audio settings, and regrettably, the software exhibits incompatibility issues with AMD GPUs.

The gaming experience notably mirrors that of a fan-crafted mod, falling short of the lofty quality standards established by the original title. Many of us have indulged in countless Half-Life playthroughs, making this divergence in quality all the more apparent.

I'm not too sure what this game accomplishes besides the obvious:
Graphics.

The game looks stunningly beautiful in every way, and Xen is no exception. This remake boasts some of the most enhanced environments of its kind, and they really pushed the Source engine to its limits.

This is where all of positives lie, as there isn't that much new or improved other than that and some things were made worse. Xen really brought this game (and the original HL1) down. 

Balancing: Pretty horrendous, honestly. Everything does way too much damage, and they offset it by spamming pickups everywhere to the point where it feels like there isn't enough punishment. A basic soldier should absolutely NOT be doing more damage than every other normal enemy in the game. Xen feels incredibly underwhelming and repetitive because none of the enemies live up to the danger that is the basic soldier. Xen also handicaps a LOT of weapons, mostly sticking you to the Gluon and Tau cannons. It just doesn't feel fun using the same weapon for the entire section of Xen, especially since the Gluon is so OP.

Movement: Somehow more slippery than the original? I'm not too sure how they did it, but a lot of the pipes and small jumps (especially in Xen) are extremely finicky. It's also slower than the original, but it used to be worse when it first came out.

Level Design: Xen. Xen. Xen... oh what a disappointment you are in both this game and the original. At least in the original it wasn't THAT long, but in this game it feels like it takes up about 50% of the playtime for such a terrible section. This game's Xen contains way too many repetitive puzzles (the conveyor belts... why???), and way too much platforming for it to be fun by any means. Each part of Xen just lasts too long, all the way from Gonarch to Nihilanth could've been shortened substantially. There's way too much padding in this level. 

What about the rest of the level design...?: It's okay... some of the sections are done right and others aren't.

Story: It's still all the same just with a couple more details such as Vortigaunts being more neutral.

Bosses: Same complaint as the level design, they go on for too long with no real interesting variety. Except for Nihilanth, which is way too easy in this game?? 

I'll give it the benefit of the doubt and recommend it, because it's still good for people who haven't played the original and are turned off by the old-timey graphics. Save yourself the time and do not play on hard difficulty.

TLDR: Barely started playing and my thoughts are constantly revolving around "opposing force when"? And yea, I wouldn't mind blue shift either. A job truly well done. 

If you know HL, this is a no brainer. If you don't, perfect to check it out.

Longer version:
So, graphically the game is close to HL2. Sometimes worse, mostly maybe even better. Yea, Zen is a good example of latter. Gorgeous. You can tell the devs got really into it as they got more and more experienced.

Audio is good, proper voice lines and all, some that are remakes of the old ones, many completely new ones. This is what happens when a company doesn't sit on an IP but allows talented people to do what shall be done. Action music parts can be a bit obnoxious when you want to listen to enemy movement so yea, while I like those too, gotta tune the volume down, at least at those sections.

Gameplay wise... not much changed. Yes, weapon handling is updated a tad but the game itself is still Half Life. Quite a bit of platforming and kinda iffy combat. The maps themselves got expanded, very rarely do we see anything less than the original. Everything is bigger, more detailed and while that is mostly great sometimes it can be a pain. I'm not fond of heights...

While many things got very obviously updated and upgraded, causing real joy when I noticed, it is also true that some things that could really use a bit of fixing stayed pretty much the same. Well... only combat really and even that is only mostly a problem against the soldiers. So yea, only about third of the game :) 
Okay, it's not that bad, never really was That bad but the AI while appeared quite intelligent back in the days nowadays it feels more annoying than clever. While the enemies can be tanky they are not bulletsponges - but they don't care. They rush you and care not that you will blow them to pieces, they will keep rushing. It's the typical game trope - an enemy soldier is happy as long as they can get a little bit of health off the player. 
Intelligence and tactics aside, they are the typical retro-game enemies. Stealth is rarely an option and if they notice you they always now where you are, hitting you with pinpoint accuracy. Them spawning in on screen is also an issue. 
Things like these make it apparent that this is not a new game but a remake of one of the biggest but oldest fps games ever made.

But despite things I really didn't remember fondly still sticking around I must say this is such an incredibly high quality remake that it makes any other remake I have ever seen nothing more than a shameful cash-in. The game is worth the full price any time - but if it's on sale it's outright a crime not to get it. You own that to yourself.

As much as I understand this is considered the great remake of Half-Life for almost everybody... it's a bit broken.

When the game updates often, it often does break old saves. And broken saves mean lost progress.
Like that one where you put so much time and effort into, invested almost countless of your time, all lost just because of an update to either that map you were on, or the whole game's maps.
Sure, the update's good, but [i]damn[/i] is it annoying to lose your hard work.

Starting a new chapter/map just doesn't feel like a good workaround, it often feels like it's just a band-aid over a profusely-bleeding wound.
And with me having hiatuses for games... at this point I have just about given up and went to cheat just wanting to get it all over with.

And that menu overhaul was a [i]clunky[/i] change.
When I tried loading an old save, the menu hiccuped and then the only options were either quitting the game, going 'back to game' which doesn't do anything, and the console.
The console's automatic autofill was also gone, and I can no longer resize the window, now only able to fill 1/3 of the screen from the top.

I would like the old menu back, please. [i](probably setting myself up for an '-oldmenu' launch parameter jab, but i'm ranting my stress out so give me some slack, plus unexperienced users may find it hard to revert these changes)[/i]

You know, this gave me an intriguing thought.
People talk about Crowbar Collective being better than Valve, when Valve were the ones that [i]done most of the hard work, kept persisting when said hard work was stolen, gave the community the OK to make free mods and occasionally some commercial sellings, [/i] and I'd like to talk about their works of the Half-Life series being seemingly more polished for their time but I'm afraid of some people that might get triggered by that.
Not even the greatest of Valve's works were free of hiccups, I'd admit, but last time I played their games their menus were definitely more flexible.

I'm giving this a [i]Not Recommended[/i] because all the positive reviews should balance it out, otherwise I'd just go in with a [i]Meh[/i] option if it ever existed.
...With that said, I think I should've stuck with the free version.

Not a flawless, a bit buggy and unstable at times, but otherwise an amazing fan remake that both improves upon but also offers a diffrent experience from the original, and I have to say that BOTH are worth playing.

Black Mesa gave me the opportunity to try out one of the classics of all time, Half-Life, but with a dash of new graphics, improved level environments and new challenges that were not in the original game. (I hate the purple hat and the pizza box)

I never got to play Half-Life when it originally launched nor did I know what I got myself into when I bought Black Mesa, so I can only say that, based on the reviews and feedback from many other players, this game preserves the original Half Life feeling while also improving it by either changing the level structure even if for a bit, or by altering some later levels entirely.

The game, while being centered around the idea of an FPS, it also adds a lot of flavour to its gameplay by adding puzzles and parkour sections, challenging your platforming abilities while also trying to make you aware of your surroundings. With no map at your disposal and the levels becoming more and more complex, you can easily become lost in the section of the game you are currently in. Each level tries to be unique in their own way, adding unique sections to them.

As for the gun play, you firstly begin with the good ol' crowbar, a reliable Glock 17, later improving your arsenal with a lot more damaging weapons like the RPG, Gluon Gun and Tau Cannon, giving you a lot of [b] fun [/b] ways of disposing of your enemies.

In conclusion, I think Black Mesa achieved what it wanted to achieve, adapting an old classic game to better suit today's graphics and effects, preserving the original gameplay while also improving on it, making this a really, really good game to play.

A sci-fi first person shooter that sees you trying to repel an alien invasion after a mishap during an experiment. It is a remake of the original Half Life more or less. I cannot evaluate it as a remake because I do not remember much of the original but on its own it is solid. Weapons have great feedback in terms of sound and visuals, and they all feel powerful too. The shotgun's alt-fire can gib enemies up close and that never stops being satisfying. This and other weapons that can achieve it are made especially amusing by how violently limbs from gibbed enemies fly apart. The enemies themselves also do a good job of avoiding your assaults and responding in kind. The enemy variety is decent but you will have seen almost all there is to see when the military rolls up. Progress not gated by combat is usually blocked off by simple puzzles, and being able to figure these out on your own to progress is fun, especially when the game's physics system comes into play. There may not be much to it but playing around with it can be amusing. The visuals are also generally impressive and whenever the soundtrack decides to start up it really hits hard.

Overall if you like first person shooters I strongly recommend it.

Now it's FOR SALE for $20 on Steam, with a webpage boasting about how they are a "game dev company who makes games" with nothing but Black Mesa as the sole "game" they created.  I bought this just to post this review and I'm refunding it.  I don't care if they finally released it.  They walked back every promise they made and think "overwhelmingly positive" reviews make it ok.

Black Mesa is a different game from Half-Life. It takes the developments in design from HLs 2 and onward and applies those philosophies to Half-Life 1's campaign, which is both a benefit for the modern gamer, and a fucking curse for veterans. It is a remake, not a mere remaster nor graphical upgrade exclusively. It is its own game, and you should treat it as such. It is a good game, even if 100% is obnoxious because they took HL2E2's gnome gimmick and shoved it in 3 separate times. The graphical fidelity is impressive for a source engine game, the mods are spectacular and vary from changes to mimic HL1 to full-on campaign remakes. If you want a modern remake of HL1, try this. If you want something more accurate, either play the original or try MMod.

[h1]Black Mesa is undoubtedly the best way to play Half-Life 1. It‚Äôs faithful to the original giving you the same narrative and action-packed experience in fresh form.[/h1]

Black Mesa is basically a remake of the original Half-Life made in the Source game engine. Although it started as a free mod, in time it became an actual product under the blessing of Valve itself. 

Storywise the game does not really stray away from the original. Gordon Freeman comes to work, accidentally opens up a rift in time and space letting alien invaders into his world, and then goes and tries to clean up the mess. Typical friday I guess. 
HL1‚Äôs story pretty much revolves around a few key events. In-between those what you really do is just fight through hordes of enemies and solve some environmental puzzles, from time to time meeting the same model of researcher/security guard for the 11th time. BM being a faithful remake is pretty much still the same but improved aesthetically and done better in terms of gameplay. You mostly visit the same locations, just reworked. 
The biggest advantage of this remake is probably the whole Xen act of the story which has been expanded. Not only are there more Xen levels now, but they are actually fun this time. You get a cool air dash ability which makes it really enjoyable to go and sightsee the Borderworld. And let me tell ya, there are some sights to behold or at least worth taking a screenshot. 
The painful downside to the game is the lack of the DLC content, although the ‚ÄúBlue Shift‚Äù campaign is currently being recreated by the good folks at HECU Collective as a workshop mod to the game. 

The gameplay is much better than in the original, at least it‚Äôs more to today's standards. Guns have new models, and they seem to actually pack a punch, enemies now ragdoll after death and seem to stagger when hit (that still doesn‚Äôt affect their deadeye accuracy though). Other than that, it‚Äôs still good HL action. Dashing through the Xen levels gives you a big sense of freedom and it‚Äôs just fun platforming honestly. 

How the game looks is probably the main improvement over the original besides gameplay. Everything has higher resolution textures and better lighting now. The models of weapons, enemies and npcs are much better and they have more fluid and lively animations. A shame that you still feel like you are meeting the same guy you‚Äôve met 5 minutes ago though. Still not enough unique npc models. Overall, the game looks good, at least it's not the same archaic look of HL1. 

In terms of music I was actually pretty torn up. The combat tracks often felt out of place to me. They seemed too loud and obnoxious when I had to hide behind a barrel with 6 HP, or especially when there‚Äôs like one enemy left somewhere and this epic music just goes wild while you‚Äôre just standing there trying to get what the hell is going on. The pieces are damn good, they just felt misplaced sometimes for me. 
The music actually redeemed itself for me later. The Xen tracks are atmospheric and straight up beautiful. "Black Mesa Theme" is a treat too. The general sound design is really good. 

Achievement hunting in Valve and Valve-inspired games was always fun to me, but one of the biggest sins of the developer (right after the fear of the number 3) is the introduction of packing achievements. You basically have to drag a specific item throughout a large portion of the game. It started with the damn gnome in HL2: Episode Two and it has inspired other creators to put this into their games. Now BS has [b] TWO [/b] of such items to pack. Come on man. It‚Äôs a fun challenge once and once only. Good thing that listening to podcasts made this thing bearable for me. 

Black Mesa is undoubtedly the best way to play Half-Life 1. It‚Äôs faithful to the original giving you the same narrative and action-packed experience in fresh form. The only shame is the absence of the DLC content which delivers different perspectives on the entire incident.

When the science bro taking a dump on company time asked Dr. Freeman to hand him some toilet paper, I went back to my locker to give him my Ph.D. in Philosophy from M.I.T. It pays for itself.

Id honestly recommend to any newcomer to the Half-Life franchise this over Half-Life 1. Not to say that the original is any bad, not in the slightest. But Black Mesa due to being a modernization of HL1 and has improved upon stuff like the movement not being as slippery, there being more use for each of the weapons than before due to less ammo and the graphics being on Half-Life 2 level of greatness. I'm not saying that this game should replace HL1. Since its a remake/reimagining and not just a simple graphical upgrade there is still a reason to go back to the original. But for first time players of the Half-Life games, the clunky but lovable original may leave a bad taste in some peoples mouths for just not being up to some modern standards.
In Short: If youre new to Half-Life, play this first and then play OG Half-Life.

I was excited to take a look at this game since I had enjoyed the original Half-Life, despite its flaws and jank. I wish I could easily recommend it over the original but honestly it makes both improvements and detriments to it.

The level design is usually pretty faithful but it deviates pretty often, for better and for worse. Certain sections feel less "what do I need to do here?" and are generally less obtuse but in many other instances the developers fall back on plug puzzles or finding the wheel to a valve. These puzzles are never really that hard, it just feels a bit sloppy there is such an abundance of them. There's a chapter (On A Rail) that is overhauled but its overhaul feels like it threw out the good parts of it too and it feels underwhelming in the end.

Some of the weapons are much better at their job (crossbow, hive hand, RPG) and some feel a lot worse (shotgun). Grenades are no longer insanely janky which is nice but I still found myself rarely using them. The crowbar also has a ton of range in comparison, which trivializes the enemies you're intended to use it on. 

I played the game on "Normal" difficulty (which is the easiest) on my first playthrough and found the game overall to be not super tough. While that is partially due to having memorized some parts, there is also just an abundance of HP and suit armor - I rarely was below 50 HP for most of the game. On my second playthrough I chose "Hard" and the military was consistently killing me so fast that encounters just became a flowchart and out of frustration I had to downscale the middle difficulty "Black Mesa" for the rest of the game. Just to clarify, this game's Difficulty scale is Normal --> Black Mesa --> Hard. Brilliant naming.

Before I discuss spoiler contents for the people who played HL1 already, I'll just say to play the original first and check this out after if you're interested.

Info about the revamped final act below; SPOILER WARNING!!!
[spoiler]Xen is wildly different from before, but yet again I am forced to say it's both good and bad. The long jump module is easier to use and works in several directions making it doubly useful as a dodge; it also nullifies fall damage, which is a nice bonus. 

The first two chapters improve on the awkward platforming sections of the original and have environmental puzzles, some neat world-building, and a few enemy variations introduced. The environment itself is beautiful but at the same time, I liked how hostile, barren, and intangible the original Xen felt. This rendition of Xen feels much more like a tangible region of space as we know it, which I don't really like for what's supposed to be a dimensional "border-world." It's still absolutely gorgeous though so I can forgive it.

The "Gonarch's Lair" chapter is HUGELY improved and my favorite part of new Xen. Rather than just being a bullet sponge that runs to the next arena when you unload enough ammo into it, you are alternating between battling the beast (which has much better AI) and cat-and-mouse chase sequences where you can chip in some extra damage before your next encounter. I have virtually no complaints about this chapter other than a bit of downtime in a certain part of it.

Interloper was a pretty big let-down, though. The chapter starts off promisingly by better humanizing the worker Vortigaunts, taking interesting creative liberties with the factories, and giving a new capability to the Controller enemy. The actual gameplay of this chapter after that is very slow, very puzzle (PLUG PUZZLE!) heavy, and the combat gets pretty stale. At a certain point they buff the AI of a certain enemy making it way more threatening, but immediately after trivializes every enemy by consistently giving you crystals that give infinite charge on the "F.U. Laser" Gluon Gun. This chapter ends with you slowly riding an elevator, holding your cursor and left mouse button over any enemy you can see. This chapter sucks a lot and lasts about as long as the entirety of Xen in the original game. Fittingly, this is also the chapter where most of my game crashes occurred.

The final boss is a decent note to end on though. He no longer teleports you to random obstacle courses, and has way more attack variety (the portals come back in spirit when he lobs stuff from Black Mesa at you). The fight felt a lot more focused, and I generally liked it. 

The Xen portion of the game overall is a lot longer by comparison to the OG's, taking up almost half of my total playtime, but most of that time was well-enjoyed.[/spoiler]
