I'm honestly not really a big fan of Black Mesa, I personally enjoy the original Half-Life more.

[h1] Black Mesa Review [/h1]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

I've never played Half-Life or Half-Life 2, so I am coming into this with the perspective of a new player to the franchise. I will not be comparing it to HL, and am looking to it as a standalone product. Overall, I found Black Mesa to be a compelling experience from start to finish, with great ambience, cinematic set pieces and gameplay.

[h2] Narrative [/h2]

You are Gordon Freeman, a physics whiz working at Black Mesa, a secretive government research facility in New Mexico. Performing a routine experiment at work, things go awry and lead to an alien invasion of Earth. The game is then spent clawing your way through the now alien-infested Black Mesa facility, with the hopes of finding the scientists that will be your last hope in closing the inter-dimensional portal and ending the calamity. However, you will soon come to find that the aliens aren't all that you have to worry about...

Unlike many modern games, BM relies heavily on gameplay to tell its story. It rarely grabs control away from the player, and pretty much all the cinematic moments of the game happen naturally without any awkward breaks into cutscenes. For this reason, this game feels really immersive and keeps you invested. Both the facility and the alien borderworld of Xen feel lived-in, with a good variety of environments, both cramped corridors and large open areas, that keep it fresh.
 
The story itself, whilst not particularly deep, has enough solid story beats and twists that allow it to be compelling. By the end of the 15 or so hour journey, I felt pretty amazed at all that Gordon has gone through.

[h2] Graphics [/h2]

I'll keep this part short, since I'm playing on a potato laptop with an iGPU. I played at 720p minimum for the majority of the game (Ch 1 - halfway through Ch 17) and the game still looked good in spite of that. Environmental design is great and feels realistic. However, I ran into some serious issues in Interloper, which resulted in the game repeatedly crashing at one point. From then on until the end I played on 800 x 600, which makes the game look very dated, but ultimately it was tolerable.

Again, the game does a great job of being varied even though it all takes place within a single facility. Each chapter has its own distinct look. Surface Tension is a standout as it brings you into a huge outdoor section for the first time, with dams, military outposts, cliffs and more.

And of course, how can I mention the graphics without talking about Xen? I am aware Source is now a fairly dated engine, but holy cow, the alien borderworld looks stunning. The game isn't afraid to show its graphical muscles, offering a wide variety of vistas that allow the player to stop and admire their surroundings. Xen feels perfect - both familiar and disturbingly dissimilar to our world. Xen (the chapter) does a phenomenal job of introducing the player to the wildlife, landscape and gameplay mechanics of the new environment.

And you'd think spending 5-6 hours in this place would make it lose its charm, but again the devs have managed to keep it varied, thanks to a change in the colors used and the differing environments - you start off in the natural environment of Xen, before moving into its underground caves, and then into the artificial tower of Interloper.

This all comes at a performance cost though, and I found my enjoyment of Xen to be slightly bogged down by low framerates as a result of the immense environment.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

At its heart, BM is an FPS game, and a pretty damn good one at that. The arsenal you develop as you progress gives you enough tools to tackle basically every situation thrown at you.

The weapons I found myself using most are the shotgun and SMG. The gun sounds are satisfying and feel reasonably powerful even late in the game. I like how ammo is quite limited in BM, which leads in you having to use the whole of your arsenal instead of only relying on 1 or 2 weapons. That being said, I have not used a single snark or trip mine throughout my playthrough since I never found it necessary.

Puzzles are another key facet of this game. It is inherent in the environment design, and unlike a lot of modern games with quest markers and whatnot, force you to pay attention to your environment. I liked the majority of them, though I have to say that some of them completely flew over my head and I had to resort to watching a YouTube guide. One particular moment for me was in Lambda Core and its teleporter puzzle.

The boss fights in this game, while not many, are incredible. In the Earth levels, they often involve roaming around and setting up a contraption that can take down the powerful alien beings. Meanwhile, on Xen, you take the fight directly to the enemy and shoot them down. The epic fights at the end of Ch 16 and of course Ch 18 are incredible, and paired with fantastic music, made me absolutely fall in love.

I have heard a common complaint of BM is that its Xen chapters overstay their welcome. I do agree that Ch 15 and Ch 17 can be trimmed down, however I don't think they were long enough to ruin my enjoyment of the game. I still liked them, but it may be due to how I played the game, in which I did these chapters over a period of 2 days, so I only played about an hour each time.

[h2] Difficulty [/h2]

I played through the whole game on Normal and it presented a reasonable challenge. Keep in mind, I suck at video games and I was bogged down by low framerates due to potato laptop, so I still died a lot and had to load saves often. However, it was still doable for me and didn't leave me overly frustrated. Enemies seemed balanced, not too tanky, nor too squishy, which was nice.

Veterans of the genre might prefer to play on the more difficult Black Mesa or Hard difficulties instead.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

Black Mesa is a brilliant game, and as someone new to the HL franchise, it has inspired me to check out the HL games one day. I picked it up on sale for around 3 USD and for that price this game is an absolute steal. I would dare say it is even worth its retail price of 20 USD. For that, you get a true labour of love. And it's a terrific game to boot.

No, it isn't perfect. Pacing does get a bit wonk at times, and performance can get bad late in Xen, but when this game is good - oh boy is it incredible. I'm glad I experienced this game.

P.S. First review on Steam, thanks for reading!

Black Mesa is a stellar game that masterfully balances staying true to the original's visuals, audio, and gameplay, while also offering its own unique touch. It remains loyal to the original storyline. I'd recommend playing the original Half Life first; doing so will enhance your appreciation for this game.

When it comes to reimagining a classic, there are few games that can hold a candle to "Black Mesa." This isn't just a remake; it's a love letter to one of the most iconic titles in gaming history, "Half-Life." Black Mesa takes everything that made the original great and cranks it up to eleven, creating an experience that feels simultaneously nostalgic and fresh.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Gordon Freeman, you're transported back to the eerie, otherworldly Black Mesa Research Facility. The level of detail in the environment is staggering, with every corridor, lab, and ventilation shaft meticulously crafted to evoke the sense of isolation and impending doom that the original game nailed so perfectly.

But it's not just about pretty graphics (although those are certainly worth mentioning). The gameplay in Black Mesa is top-notch. The updated controls and mechanics make the experience feel modern and intuitive, while still retaining the core essence of what made Half-Life a genre-defining title. The iconic weapons, from the trusty crowbar to the devastating Gauss Gun, all feel incredibly satisfying to use.

One of the standout features of Black Mesa is the attention to storytelling. The narrative has been refined and expanded upon, with more engaging character interactions and a deeper exploration of the events leading up to the alien invasion. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to preserving the original's spirit while enhancing the storytelling for a new generation of gamers.

The game's pacing is impeccable. The moments of intense action are balanced by periods of exploration and puzzle-solving, creating a rollercoaster of tension and relief that keeps you glued to the screen. And speaking of tension, the AI of the enemy creatures has been significantly improved, making every encounter a heart-pounding battle for survival.

Black Mesa also boasts a robust multiplayer mode that adds even more replayability to an already outstanding package. Whether you're facing off against other players in deathmatches or working together in cooperative missions, the multiplayer component is a blast.

In conclusion, "Black Mesa" isn't just a remake; it's a masterful reimagining that pays homage to the original while delivering an experience that stands on its own as a modern classic. Whether you're a die-hard Half-Life fan or a newcomer to the series, this game is an absolute must-play. It's a shining example of how to update a classic for a new generation, and it sets a high bar for future remakes and reboots in the gaming industry. Grab your HEV suit and get ready for a journey back to Black Mesa like you've never experienced before.

When I was about 12 I downloaded a copy of Half-Life from the internet, I didn't even knew what was it, just that it looked cool and was one of the only shooting games my busted up laptop could run. Yet, my short attention span drove me to more colorful and fast games, back then I got to the first surface level and left it there, I thought that was the end and never played it again. 

Years later, I keep hearing about this being one of the best games of all time, and decided to finally buy it along with all the other Valve games, perhaps as part of my redemption for my years of sailing the seven seas, and well, what other way to play but with enhanced and perfected graphics? Abandoned it to my backlog.

Until at long last I forced myself to play it, and what a game, every praise, every high score, every award this game has received is well deserved, of course most people talk about Half-Life and not exactly Black Mesa itself, yet Black Mesa is just the perfect way to play it, the original game hasn't aged very well, and while I did try it a few times as an adult, I believe anyone who wants to experience Half-Life should check this version. 

The graphics are amazing, while it does change the art direction that does not hurt the original at all and at some point it might be it's own game yet the landscapes look beautiful and give Half-Life an excellent modern makeover. Gameplay feels way more fluid and responsive. Sound effects are most if not all from the classic version, since what would Half-Life be without it's iconic sound effects. It also has achievements now!

In conclusion, Half-Life will always be one of the founding fathers of the FPS genre and with Black Mesa it has a nice new look and is a lot easier to get into for the new generations, since this is Steam, every Library should have a copy.

This isn't a bad game. It's actually good in my opinion. But I've seen many people say things like "just play this! Half-Life 1 is antiquated!" and stuff like that. I disagree, and don't like this game as a remake, here's why:

Upsides:

+Good audiovisual side (with a couple exceptions I'll get to in a bit). The orange colors outside make the Black Mesa facility truly feel like an epic warzone. Sound design is also improved. Voice acting is also pretty great, though some lines feel forced

+HECU having more radio conversations is a nice bonus

+Surface Tension is pretty good, with a couple added fight scenes between HECU and Xen aliens that are cool to watch

+Partner AI is a massive improvement (though this is a low bar since this is a 2020 remake of a 1998 game)

+There's a workshop which allows potentially endless modding 

+The HEV Zombies section in Xen was the single best addition. Was original, and had a cool atmosphere

Now, for the downsides

Combat:

For HECU Marines, the game uses Combine AI from Half-Life 2 by default. This is fine on it's own, but the soldiers keep the same strength and damage output from the original, which made it feel for me like I was fighting a bunch of walking sentry turrets. It doesn't help that a lot of arenas are copied from the first game, which results in a weird amalgamation. Most of the weapons in your arsenal have been nerfed, with lower ammo counts and higher spread. Other enemies (especially Vortigaunts) feel tankier to fight against, though to be fair this pales in comparison to how unlikeable the HECU are

Puzzles and Level Design:

There is a staggering amount of plug and valve puzzles in this game, likely 9 in 10 of every puzzle, at least from what I can recall. None of the puzzles here feel challenging or original, the only one with some thought (that I can recall) was the teleporter one at the end of the Xen chapter (that was ok). Level design isn't much better either. Crowbar felt the need to add as much visual clutter as they wanted when making these levels. There are several instances where there's a bright door ahead of you, but the way ahead turns out to be some dark vent in the corner. Don't underestimate good level design

Audiovisual:

This is the biggest high point of Black Mesa in my opinion, but there are still some problems. The soundtrack doesn't feel fitting. The fight tracks are good (and Kovalski made some good remixes if you liked them too), but every track besides "We've Got Hostiles" felt unfitting or unoriginal. I think it would've been better to not straight-up copy off but take inspiration from Kelly Bailey and his HL1 tracks. As for the visual side, I don't like how the orange glow (which looks great outside) is kept indoors, making every building feel on fire. There's also an overuse of lens flares (though this is more of a nitpick)

On a Rail:

On a Rail was not a good chapter. It was confusing and felt like a drag. But in Black Mesa, rather than try to improve it, Crowbar just cut about half of it and replaced it with a few fights. Pacing's better, sure, but it feels less like it's - well - on a rail. While I don't have any specific suggestions for how to fix it, I'm sure Crowbar could've thought of something 

Xen:

There are some quality of life improvements, like the supply drops and landing jets, but Xen as a whole felt worse for me. The unique flesh world, middle of nowhere aesthetic is gone, replaced with a recolored human jungle and later on a Doom Eternal setting. It also feels way too long, Interloper especially. The Interloper boss just feels lazy, with infinite Gluon ammo and health. Nihilanth is also a missed opportunity in my opinion, but it could've been worse I suppose

Not a bad game, but I would not reccomend playing this over the original. Play it on your own if you wish, and I'm sure you'll enjoy it

This is a remake of Half-Life 1.

And it's a damn good remake. Lots of obvious passion behind this project. Much more playable than the original.
Even Valve loved it, and acknowledges it since it's here.

Now some thoughts about the game at it's core, Half-Life 1:

-Was incredibly innovative when it came out, but is pretty dated now
-I'm not the biggest fan, nowadays it's a pretty average game, gameplay and storywise.
-Barely any cutscenes, the world is alive and people interact in front of you, which is very immersive
-The enemies are lacking.
-Environmental and tonal shift somewhere around the middle.
-Gorgeous lategame setpieces.
-Mystery surrounding the guy with a briefcase. (Honestly the main reason I played the game)

Definitely try it at the very least, and see for yourself - the remake of the game that changed the FPS genre forever.

Half-life came out when having an FPS game in real 3D was still not a given. The genre was already established, but not yet tropefied. Having only Duke Nukem 3D in mind the game about Ivan the Space Biker had to stop in its tracks when Quake 2 came out and accidentally created the ‚Äúmodern military shooter‚Äù paradigm. Valve decided not only to catch up to this story of s·¥ò·¥Ä·¥Ñ·¥á ·¥ç·¥Ä Ä…™…¥·¥ás but also to surpass its ‚Äúgritty realism‚Äù and ‚Äúcinematic‚Äù prowess. With the hindsight it is really easy to see in which order the things were tacked on each other. There‚Äôs the Quake‚Äòs Xen but better, Duke Nukem 3D‚Äòs ‚Äúrelatable‚Äù real spaces filled with intractable objects but better with real 3D, and Quake 2‚Äòs stupid-arse ·¥ç·¥Ä Ä…™…¥·¥ás, dull grey corridors and boring guns, but better.

The tram intro was absolutely amazing the first time you see it. In that era cutscenes were a reward for the gameplay and not its substitute in a form of punishment. But every time you want to replay the game the first couple of hours were a chore and a torture.

Black Mesa is too similar to the Half-Life where they could‚Äôve added something new and not similar enough where it counts. The NPCs in the intro should give more directions when you ask them, at least give the names of the rooms you are expected in. I know the outline of the game, but what new players are supposed to do? To wander around blindly or to look up a walk-through? There is so much HUD, and none of it is your Pilot PDA organizer.
Now the crowbar is even further away, forcing you to play Episode One, with flares (that are broken) and an escort mission where the civilian is you. Damn, Episode One was such a cheap trash, even on release.

I really hated the whole first part of the game. It felt like a disgusting zombie ‚Äî looks alive but is dead inside. And all the artificiality with bad physics did grind my nerves.

Then i finally reached Xen. The part that turned the mediocre Half-Life campaign into one of the best game to this day. And yep, they did remove everything that was cool about it. There is no low gravity and cool open levels. It‚Äôs just corridors and corridors and a ton of platforming. Without the low gravity you have to use the stupid booster. But the game doesn‚Äôt have aerial control and the edge-lips are still broken. So they removed the analog platforming, to replace it with discrete platforming and a broken one at that. But hey, at least it is Xen. And it is entirely new material, so i didn‚Äôt hate playing it. First part is super artificial gamey gameness and nearly a walking simulator in alien worlds. The second part is still artificial but is more combat-heavy. After you dispose of Gonarch, you participate in a ‚Äúprepare a tower sequence‚Äù, similar to the rocket engine room, the ending of the sequel and the beginning of the Episode One. Now the last part saw a significant improvement lore-wise. You meet civilian Vortigaunts who do not fight you unless forced to, and sometimes do idle scenes. Reminds me of russia, everyone who didn‚Äôt flee and didn‚Äôt volunteer into NSDAP is so enslaved and tired that they don‚Äôt even care that an alien showed up at their workplace and starts to re-arrange their industrial equipment without any understanding of consequences. Them suddenly being friendly in the sequel was weird (and also meant that great enemies are replaced with more ·¥ç·¥Ä Ä…™…¥·¥ás) and this chapter bridges that gap. Also it explains the connections between brainies and crystal, so i was prepared to a one damn good boss-fight. But alas, this is the Black Mesa in the end. So it throws away all that tutorialization it did. It trows away one of the best (but poorly explained for better or for worse) boss-fights in the history of gaming. Instead of extremely memorable, zany and weird fight we now have an utmost generic ‚Äúblob in the centre of the room‚Äù flat fight. I forgot more games that i finished than i remember minutes of my first fight against Nihilanth in the original.

One of the finest games on this platform and safe to say one of the more faithful remakes.

The graphics and levels are vividly detailed, the soundtrack is excellent, the voice acting is well performed and self contained, it follows Half Life 1's formula and materials well, it also has a mostly functional workshop *cough* Halo MCC take notes, Nexus and Assembly doesn't count*cough*. 

The team of people that made this game are very talented indeed, seeing that the game started out as a fan made project, I can see why it took as long as it did, I honestly think it was worth the wait, since the dev team seem to had undergo the daunting task of making almost everything in Xen from scratch. Xen might as well be an entirely different game.

The few cracks in this game's armour to me was that the game is slightly less scalable compared to it's previous versions and the Half Life games before it, the developer console seems less usable, at least to me, since I use commands like toggle crouch and walk, but those functions are no longer present as well as adjusting the weapon fov without mods, very minor gripes though. 

The gameplay before Xen felt a bit too easy sometimes, most weapons are more efficient at killing most enemies than ever before, I'd argue that the shotgun is a complete beast now, even at mid range. It's probably because the weapons are extremely powerful, or that the enemies are very weak, even on hard. The weapons are still overkill imo;  ammo for even the more powerful weapons feels a lot more generous compared to HL1&2 etc. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay loop and pacing is more preferable to Half Life 2's snail-paced action and I like that the enemies die quicker as a reward for proficient aim, I like that a lot, but it's a bit too easy sometimes and the enemies can feel a bit under-powered as a result. 

Lastly is that the performance in some areas of the game can tank like a mother, the game is better optimised now but you're still going to need a rather powerful machine to play the game at a consistent framerate, but I can't really fault the game for it's performance - This game is a very ambitious project and it's unrealistic to expect a game to run perfectly with this much content put into it.


All n' all, puts most modern remakes of other games to shame, it's an entirely different beast of it's own and is arguably one of the best games in Steam.

With 50,000 positive reviews, I'm gonna jump in and go with "Not recommended". Actually, it would be "Recommended for Masochists". There's a lot to love in there, but there's also a lot of glaring issues: the absurdly unfair difficulty just kills the fun, there are many instances of badly designed feedback for the player and overall the game overstays its welcome quite a bit. 

Before you go about with some "get gut" sh**, let me tell you I'm a passionate gamer with almost a thousand beaten games behind me. I'm not a "noob" and I can easily headshot enemies in any shooter game. I've played a lot of masterpiece games and this is not one of them. It's close, but it's not.

The game is seriously unfair and you'll end up dying way more than you would expect. I think it's because it's built on a game from an era when there was no "quality-of-life" philosophy behind game design, or at least not as we know it today. You will also die because of bad signs & feedback, like jumping across a gap and hitting an invisible wall midway through the air, or trying to take down a monster showing "hurt" feedback in a particular segment where it cannot be hurt (yes, Gonarch, I'm looking at you).

I said there was a lot to love here if you can stomach the unfairness. Level design is amazing, scope is epic, and I love how the story unfolds through events happening around you, and through the environments. Truly amazing storytelling all-around. But gameplay makes it hard to enjoy and I often finished a session feeling like I wasted my time. Bad feeling, really.

Tl;dr: Recommended for masochists only. IF you can stomach the frustratingly unfair difficulty, there's a lot to love here, but I don't believe it's the masterpiece people say it is. The game also overstays its welcome quite a bit.

[b]A Reimagined Classic That Defines Excellence [/b]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Black Mesa, developed by Crowbar Collective, is a breathtaking reimagining of the iconic classic, Half-Life. As a labor of love and tribute to the original, this game has masterfully brought the groundbreaking world of Half-Life into the modern era. With its superb graphics, enhanced gameplay, and dedication to the source material, Black Mesa delivers an unforgettable experience that will captivate both fans and newcomers alike.

[h1]A Stunning Visual Overhaul[/h1]
One of the standout features of Black Mesa is its stunning visual upgrade. The game has been rebuilt from the ground up using the Source engine, showcasing modern graphics that breathe new life into the Half-Life universe. The meticulously designed environments, improved character models, and dynamic lighting contribute to an immersive and visually captivating experience that sets a new standard for remakes.

[h1]Faithful to the Original[/h1]
Black Mesa stays true to the essence of the original Half-Life while also incorporating modern gaming standards. The developers have carefully preserved the narrative and core gameplay mechanics that made the original a legend. The iconic moments and level design have been faithfully recreated, paying homage to the groundbreaking elements that made Half-Life a seminal title in gaming history.

[h1]Enhanced Gameplay and Mechanics[/h1]
While maintaining the authenticity of the original, Black Mesa introduces enhancements to gameplay and mechanics. The improved physics, AI, and weapon mechanics provide a more polished and immersive experience. The refined controls and updated combat system add depth to the gameplay, offering a satisfying balance between nostalgia and contemporary gaming expectations.

[h1]Incredible Level Design[/h1]
The level design in Black Mesa is nothing short of exceptional. The meticulous attention to detail, intricate puzzles, and well-crafted environments immerse players in the Black Mesa Research Facility. From the eerie labs to the alien-infested corridors, each location is a testament to the developer's dedication to creating an atmospheric and captivating world that draws players deeper into the story.

[h1]A Seamless and Cohesive Experience[/h1]
Black Mesa provides a seamless and cohesive gaming experience, effectively integrating its improvements and modernizations without disrupting the nostalgic feel. The pacing is superb, and the narrative flows smoothly, ensuring that both newcomers and fans of the original can enjoy the adventure without any jarring disruptions or inconsistencies.

[h1]Engrossing Sound Design[/h1]
The sound design in Black Mesa complements the visuals perfectly, enhancing the overall immersion. The ambient sounds, voice acting, and iconic musical themes are expertly crafted, adding depth and emotion to the game's atmosphere. The attention to detail in the soundscapes elevates the player's engagement and enhances the overall sense of being in the Black Mesa facility.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Black Mesa is a triumph in the world of video game remakes, setting a high bar for both visual and gameplay standards. With its stunning graphics, seamless integration of modern gaming elements, and unwavering dedication to the original, Black Mesa is a must-play for both die-hard Half-Life fans and newcomers to the series. Crowbar Collective's passion and talent have breathed new life into a classic, providing a gaming experience that will be cherished for years to come.

A Resurrection of a Classic!

Stepping into the world of Black Mesa is like revisiting an old friend, but realizing they've undergone a major glow-up. Crowbar Collective's reimagining of the iconic 1998 game, Half-Life, isn't just a mere facelift; it's a comprehensive overhaul that breathes new life into a beloved classic.

From the get-go, the game feels familiar yet distinctly modern. The core mechanics, the combat, the puzzles - they all echo the original Half-Life, but with a polish and finesse that only the advancements of the Source engine could provide. The game's environments are richer, the physics more intricate, and the platforming feels more intuitive. And let's not even get started on the AI. Those alien grunts and military operatives? They're smarter, more relentless, and will keep you on your toes.

But perhaps the most commendable aspect of Black Mesa is how it addresses the original's shortcomings. Remember Xen? That slightly jarring, out-of-place final chapter from Half-Life? Black Mesa doesn't just tweak it; it transforms it, turning what was once considered the weakest link into a compelling and cohesive conclusion.

The journey of Black Mesa, from a fan mod to a commercially approved release, is a testament to the passion and dedication of its developers. Black Mesa isn't just a remake; it's a love letter to Half-Life fans. It captures the essence of the original while enhancing every aspect for the modern gamer. Whether you're a veteran Black Mesa scientist or a rookie stepping into this world for the first time, this game promises an experience that's both nostalgic and refreshingly new.

I never properly finished Half-Life, mostly because of its lack of controller support. The game's still playable, but controlling menus with keyboard and mouse controls on a controller is horrid. I prefer controller to mouse and keyboard most of the time, and I have a steam deck, so controller support means a lot to me. So seeing this game had "partial controller support", I picked it up expecting it to be playable on controller. Joy!

So, uh, that was a lie. Actual bold-faced lie. This game has no controller support whatsoever, just like the original. You're forced to navigate menus using terrible mouse and keyboard controls. I think there's hacky ways to get it in, but the fact that a Valve-sanctioned game that's been in development for 10 years on an engine with controller support has no controller support? Yeah no that's stupid. That pissed me off so much I immediately refunded upon realizing that.

I mean, seriously? "Partial controller support" means the game has at least basic controller support. But no, you can't navigate menus, you can't move, you can't look around, you can't even pause the game without mapping keyboard and mouse. What part of that is "partial controller support"? That's NO controller support. Why would you advertise the game to have something it [i]doesn't even have?[/i] I'm baffled really. I'm sure the rest of the game is great, especially if you don't use controller, but...what the hell were they thinking adding that tag? I'm happy I refunded while I did or I'd have been completely ripped off.

[h1]The right man in the wrong place makes all the difference in the world.[/h1]

That sums up [b]The Crowbar Collective[/b] who made this game.  When they said they were originally going to redo the entirety of [u]Half-Life[/u], I scoffed at the notion of it, just like so many others.  "Oh great, another mod with updated shaders and new textures" I figured.  Not that those aren't appreciated, it's just hard when someone tries to give new life to old, blocky games.  Neat, the faces look more real, despite the Minecraft square head look still.

I'm glad I was wrong.  This game is something else unto itself.  To say that it's a fan's love letter does it no justice.  The amount of thought that went into this is unprecedented.  Every last detail was thought of.  The whole game was overhauled, built from the ground up from scratch.  Not only were the graphics updated to match those of this era, the level design, mechanics, sounds and just about every other thing were completely revamped and added too.

If the apostle David himself was a masterpiece in his time, just as Half-Life was, then [u]Black Mesa[/u] is Michelangelo's masterpiece which is an ode to him.  I remember playing this through and thinking how wrong I was.  I had played up to the Lambda Core missions, where [b]The Crowbar Collective[/b] had stopped development, as they were still working on Xen.  I was disappointed, but still full of excitement and anticipation.

As time went on, I totally forgot about it.  Until recently, that is.  And my god, Xen was beautiful.  I can see why it took them so long to release that.  Honestly, Zen was my least favorite when I played the original [u]Half-Life[/u].  It seemed rushed, and under-powered, as though they had great ideas for it, but ran out of time and didn't have processing power to make the world like they wanted.

[u]Black Mesa[/u], however, made it something most surreal.  It was my favorite part of the whole game.  It was almost an entire game unto itself.  And the battle with Gonarch?  One of the best boss matches and cinematic experiences of all time.  Leaps and bounds better than the original.  Like [u]Half-Life[/u] to the power of 100.

This game is my favorite of all time.  I love [u]Half-Life[/u], but this was [u]Half-Life[/u] done justice.  A monstrous thank you to [b]The Crowbar Collective.[/b]  You made this ol' timer relive his childhood as though I was playing it again for the very first time.  You guys rock!

Black Mesa is a complete recreation of Valve's 1998 game Half-Life in the source engine, including beautiful graphics, completely redesigned levels, and a beautiful recreation of the Xen chapters.

Does this mean that its better than the original? No.

Half-Life is such an influential game that really set the bar for the fps genre. I personally think Black Mesa is best experienced after completing the original Half-Life. I might be biased, as Half-Life is one of my favorite games of all time, but I really enjoyed playing Black Mesa and looking for all the things that were the same, and what Crowbar Collective changed. 

In my personal opinion, the only thing Black Mesa does miles better than Half-Life 1 is the chapters On A Rail, Xen, Gonarch's Lair, Interloper, and Nihilanth. These chapters are mainly regarded as the worst parts of the original and I completely agree with that. However, Black Mesa completely redesigned all of these chapters and made them WAY better than they are in the original game. 

In the original game, On a Rail is a long, tedious chapter where most of it is spent on a painfully slow rail cart driving through a decommissioned rail-system inside of Black Mesa. The latter hasn't changed with Black Mesa, but they greatly improved this chapter by completely redoing it. There's more puzzles, and you don't spent ALL of the chapter on the cart. Also, the big battles with the HECU soldiers are made much better in this game than they are in the original.

The last few chapters of the game spent in the border world Xen are all pretty bad in the original, with the maps looking rushed and not being very appealing visually. Black Mesa's rendition of the Xen chapters are absolutely stunning graphically. Unlike in the original, where Xen is just a bunch of greyish green floating islands in space, Black Mesa's Xen has more islands to explore, each covered in foliage and alien like flowers that make the world feel more alive and lived in. It also improves the gameplay of these chapters, featuring more puzzles, a redesigned Gonarch boss fight, and more. Black Mesa made me actually enjoy Interloper, which in my opinion is the worst chapter in the original game.

Black Mesa is an amazing recreation of Half-Life that I 100% recommend to any Half-Life fan or anyone who's played the original. However, I don't think this is the definitive way to experience Half-Life as the original just has a certain charm to it that makes me keep coming back to it to play it over and over again.

The game focuses on reality a lot more then the original Half-Life did. Areas feel like they could exist in real life, and in Source 2 Black Mesa could take the Half-Life series to the next level. The workshop is pretty decent too. Black Mesa: Blue Shift by HECU is probably top notch, remaking Blue Shift out of Black Mesa, unlike other remake mods such as Operation Black Mesa, Guard Duty, and Peer review (still good projects though) that make it out of Half-Life 2 like the old Black Mesa mod on Moddb. Other mods I enjoy are mods like the Pre-disaster mods. The Pre-disaster mods make the BMRF fully feel like a real place. I love Black Mesa, more than Half-Life 1 2 & episodes. Some complaints I have though, are the push doors. The push doors are doors you would push to open in real life. However in Black Mesa they cannot be opened. This takes away from logic and immersion. Some are shown blown off, meaning there are places behind them. If there was a locked sound whenever you tried to open it that would be fine, but I still get irritated by it. Another complaint I have is NPC variety. There are more than Half-Life, but it still is noticeably repetitive. Also, all NPCs use the same generic voices, There could have been a few unique  ones, but they are all still the same. The NPCs in general are not a big step up from Half-Life. I still love Black Mesa, and wish nothing but love to the developers. I hope Black Mesa improves, and becomes more recognized, eventually getting an RTX remake or Source 2 port.

Black Mesa is a beautiful testament to the values that made Half-Life shine the way it did. It is nothing short of breathtaking. It is everything that made Half-Life amazing, coupled with new standards and game design practices of the modern age that help to uphold its values without making it unrecognizable.

[h1]Should I play this, or should I play Half-Life?[/h1]
This question is the most pervasive to those looking to get into the Half-Life series, and every player has their own answer. It's a hard question to answer if you are specifically saying no to the "both" option!

Admittedly, as much as I love the classic game, it has a heavy reliance on rose tinted glasses. All of what made it special way back when is now considered standard and normal now. 

If you are younger (say, around 25 or below), you know how when you revisit older games they generally have strange difficulty curves and a sort of clunky feel? Half-Life is an old game that feels like an early modern game. Simple as that. It did shape most modern game design, after all.

In general, if you are younger or you aren't looking for a nostalgia trip, you will probably want Black Mesa. You won't miss out on any story or anything, and it'll feel like a game that you are used to. If you are interested in history and witnessing the fundamental roots of all modern games, play HL1.

2 years ago I tried to play through the original Half-Life and got bored about one-third in. Pretty much the same thing happened with Black Mesa - basically the entirety of the levels in the lab were a chore to get through. Headcrabs are annoying to fight, the atmosphere is tense but it gets old very quickly, NPCs and the story bring hardly anything to the game. There were to many gadgets I never ended up using that just made me scroll my "inventory" for longer.

It does get much better with the change of setting in the second half (third?) of the game. Not only does it fully showcase the beauty of the improved graphics, but it gets more creative with the level design and the addition of double jump. It also takes the story into a far more interesting direction, and has many memorable moments overall. And you can use the gluon gun almost limitlessly, which is super fun.

While it's probably the best way to experience Half-Life, from technical standpoint it's not perfect. My PC is not that old, and yet I faced multiple FPS drops when some bigger explosions were happening on screen. There are also plenty of bugs - mostly Freeman blocking himself within the environment or in the air, but the game also did manage to softlock me when a script didn't work and a scientist froze before the door I was supposed to get through (I only realised what happened after walking aimlessly for 20 minutes and searching up a YT walkthrough).

If you've never tried Half-Life this is probably the way to go, but it's not completely without problems.

Ohhh yeah, let me break it down for ya, brother! "Black Mesa," it's like the rebirth of a legend, the resurrection of a classic, and it's got more twists and turns than a ladder match at SummerSlam!

You step into the boots of Gordon Freeman, the ultimate underdog just like when Mankind took on The Rock! But instead of a steel chair, you've got a crowbar, and you're swingin' it like you're in a hardcore match with headcrabs and alien goons. It's like if Stone Cold had a PhD in kicking ass!

Now, this ain't just a rehash, oh no! "Black Mesa" takes the original "Half-Life" and pumps it up like a 'roided-up Hulk Hogan. The graphics? They're smoother than a Bret Hart Sharpshooter, and the environments are more immersive than the crowd at WrestleMania! It's like they took the original and gave it a Stone Cold Stunner, leaving you in awe, brother.

But hold on tight, because the story's got more twists than a Steve Austin swerve. You're fightin' your way through Black Mesa Research Facility, just like tryin' to win the Intercontinental Championship. But instead of belts, you're earnin' the respect of the scientists and soldiers, and even makin' alliances with unexpected allies ‚Äì kinda like forming a tag team outta nowhere!

And the action, man! It's like if The Rock and Triple H teamed up for a handicap match against a legion of aliens. You're dodging gunfire, blasting through barricades, and solvin' puzzles that are trickier than Vince McMahon's plans. It's the kind of chaos that'd make Mick Foley smile under that Mankind mask!

So there you have it, brother! "Black Mesa" is like the Attitude Era of gaming ‚Äì it takes the original formula, throws in some wild surprises, and delivers a slobberknocker of a good time. So lace up your boots, load up that shotgun, and get ready to layeth the smacketh down on those alien candy asses. Ohhh yeah, it's time to play the game!

Black Mesa is an absolute masterpiece that flawlessly reinvigorates the iconic Half-Life 1 experience. As a dedicated fan of the original game, I was both excited and cautious about this remake, but after playing through it, I can confidently say that Black Mesa exceeded all my expectations.

The attention to detail is astounding. From the meticulously recreated environments to the enhanced character models, every aspect of the game has been lovingly crafted to modern standards while staying true to the essence of the original. The graphics are stunning, breathing new life into the familiar locations I've explored countless times before.

What truly sets Black Mesa apart is its impeccable gameplay and new locations. The level design is a stroke of genius, seamlessly blending nostalgic moments with fresh surprises. The pacing is spot-on, keeping me engaged from the very start to the thrilling conclusion. The developers have not only captured the essence of Half-Life's tight, immersive gameplay but have also elevated it with refined mechanics and controls that feel intuitive and responsive.

In conclusion, Black Mesa is more than just a remake; it's a passionate love letter to a beloved classic. 
The only negative part about it is that it ends, leaving players with a sense of bittersweet satisfaction, and a gentle reminder that the much-awaited Part 3 may never grace our screens. Nevertheless, the journey Black Mesa provides is so rich and fulfilling that it will undoubtedly be revisited with pleasure, keeping the spirit of Half-Life alive for years to come.

Black Mesa is just like how I remember Half-Life, but better.

Revisiting old classics is a bittersweet experience, where your memory keeps everything that made you love a game but abstracts away the outdated graphics and experience, as your analog brain doesn't care about polygons and pixels.
Black Mesa is a faithful upgrade on the original game, not just some high-definition mod.
Built from scratch, it pushes our well-known Source engine to its limits and beyond with truly stunning looks.
They made the original puzzles make more sense (when possible), upgraded the gun work with a more modern approach (sometimes enemies are way too smart), and kept the fast-paced combat.
The level design removed some boring elements here and there (like a super long on-the-rail), but added in others, like completely reimagining the Xeno worlds and making it a true alien-like experience and unlocking all the potential for the final chapters.
They made the Half-Life story more lore-friendly for Half-Life 2 and imported some interesting gameplay elements from it.
From someone who played Half-Life in 1998 and has been following the news on Black Mesa since 2005, it has been worth the wait.

Black Mesa is a true labor of love, made with the same passion Valve used to make games.

Unfortunately, I did not pay attention when the original Half Life came out as I think my computer at the time could not run it well.  Although I was a huge fan of Half Life 2, I could never get myself to go through the original game (mostly because of the older graphics/mechanics). Black Mesa completely changed that. I went through the story quite fast and really enjoyed the whole experience.

Definitely worth it!

Black Mesa is a fan remake of Half Life 1 but it is by no means just that, it has been approved by Valve themselves and breathes new life to the original Half Life in ways that the original players must have pictured it looking back in the day. Everything is faithfully and beautifully remade in the Source engine. You can feel the team's passion for Half Life where with their faithfulness to the original game and their improvements over the original with the most obvious example being Xen. Would absolutely recommend this game to anyone trying to experience Half Life for the first time or veteran fans wanting to re experience where the story all began

If you asked me, this is the definitive way to play the game. Sure, play the original game and appreciate how well made it was for 1998 but then play this and realise how much better it is. I really love how much more connected this feels to Half Life 2 as well whilst also keeping the original aesthetic. 

You can tell so much love went into the design of this, especially the Xen levels towards the end of the game which even includes new music which sounds incredibly angelic. However, what I will say is that, although Xen looks amazing, I will admit that it outstays its welcome a little too long and is a bit of a drag to get through to the end of the game. Obviously, that is just my opinion though.

I have also encountered a few bugs too which aren't anything game breaking but can be a little off-putting. For an example, loading screens seem to have weird black boxes flashing all over the screen, not sure if this is a common bug or if this just happens to various people but it happened every time without fail for me. 

Also, there was a specific part of the Gonarch levels that bugged out when I saved and came back in. I can't really describe the specific part of the game but I know that the thing was just stationary when I loaded back in and only triggered when I went into a specific area. Not long after this, it kicked me into the air and lodged me behind an invisible barrier outside of the map to which I had to reload. 

Overall, I am a huge fan of the Half Life series and Half Life lore and, although it's not a Valve instalment to the series, it is a faithful and brilliant modernisation of an already all-time classic. I 100% recommend, especially to someone who has already played any of the other Half Life games out there.

Congrats to the talented people who made it and I highly recommend anyone interested in this game to try it out.

I really enjoy how some of the maps have been expanded with added details, particularly during Anomalous Materials, but too much was changed, and even discarded from the original (the most mixed bag being right off, with Black Mesa Inbound - interesting added details, but strange missing elements). I feel like Black Mesa undercuts a lot of lore in favor of bringing relatively fancier graphics. Further, the weapons handle way worse in Black Mesa, even compared to playing the Half-Life port on my old PS2 with a controller (the MP5 is just awful and the Magnum fires better from the hip than down sights).

That all said, the worst part is the game-breaking bugs. For me, it was transitioning from Surface Tension to "Forget About Freeman!", wherein, upon going through the door that starts the next chapter, none of the lighting loaded. I could walk around, fire my weapons, see the muzzle flashes, accidentally kill Gordon, and see the UI, but that's it. The screen was otherwise black. I wasn't running a chapter mod, it just didn't load the lighting. No flashlight, nothin'. I looked all over the Internet and I couldn't find a fix. Reloaded earlier saves and replayed a lot -- it just did the same thing: Complete blackness upon loading "Forget About Freeman!".

This is really annoying, too, because I truly feel like the first Half-Life deserves a remake/remaster. It's such a great game. However, not only does Black Mesa miss the spirit of the original, it's just a messy, broken product that seems to miss every beat, outside of environmental/graphic upgrades.

My next stop will be playing through a highly-modded run of Half-Life: Source (the Fixed mod being a key install). I hope that's better. I just want to play a modernized Half-Life that works. Ugh.
